description:
Omg I'm so so so glad I gave Cassava another chance. 

The quinoa egg dish is a fast favorite reminding me of childhood.

I'm gonna have to resist ordering it every time I walk by.

I'm usually vegan veg but got the chicken liver pate on doctor's orders. So delicious and on Marla's amazing bread.

My friend had the seabass.

This place is NOPA 4 years ago and if it were run with a healthy Asian flare.
author: Priya S.

description:
4 course tasting dinner - Melon tomato salad, duck confit, lamb chop with white beans, hibiscus  panacotta

Fantastic service, delicious food great presentation, good menu 

Nice place for relaxing dinner or any time.
author: Ray J.

description:
Brunch only.

We came in for brunch on a weekend and thought the food was heavy. We got the pork ribs hash bowl and the Japanese breakfast. It might've been a one-time thing but it was also incredibly smokey in there, which made the experience less comfortable. Wasn't too fond of this place so I'm not too keen on coming back.
author: Sophia L.

description:
This review is for their DINNER only.

Probably the most under-rated neighborhood restaurant in the Bay Area; my date and I had absolutely no complaints after our 8pm Saturday evening dinner.  One of few examples of Californian-American food done right!

Venue: not too many seats inside, given the small space, but you definitely don't feel cramped, even if you are sitting near the kitchen.  Maybe it's because the interior is a light grey / white color to brighten up the space and tan drapery on the ceiling vs. the dark wooden tables and black seats.  We sat inside in the corner of the restaurant but still didn't feel stuffed.  It looks like a typical neighborhood restaurant, but service and food are something else.  

Service: from when we entered to when we left, the staff were very friendly and approachable.  Our waitress was particularly helpful in picking out dishes for us (trying to go with variety and telling us which ones were seasonal).  They didn't come by the tables too often, but when they did they were always approachable.  Pace-wise, I would call it "brisk"; timing between dishes was something you might find during a lunch rush without feeling too rushed.  

Food: considering how much we ordered between two people, it was quite something when we finished everything and didn't feel like we were gonna explode; everything was relatively light to the stomach.
-- Summer Peaches & Melon Salad (sunflower sprouts, verjus, sheep ricotta salata, fennel fronds, rye crumble)($13) - I don't like peaches too much but I would have been perfectly happy eating 2 plates of these!  The peaches come from a farmer's market and even my boyfriend, who loves peaches, said these were some of the best he's ever tasted.  The fruit wasn't too sweet either and, with the cheese, crumble, and sunflower sprouts, didn't feel too much like eating a dessert fruit plate.  Awesome start to the meal!

-- Cassava's Fried Chicken (thigh meat, buttermilk marinated, chive aioli, mint cilantro coleslaw)($14) - it kinda reminds me of the karaage at Nomica, except juicier and with a lot more flavor (probably b/c Cassava uses the thigh meat).  Even after eating this and my entree, didn't have any regrets on ordering this.

-- Duck Leg Confit (heirloom beans, roasted beets, herb-spiced breadcrumb)($25) - I was hesitant about ordering this one since I normally don't go for duck, but the waitress didn't disappoint when she said I should go for it.  The duck was very tender and while savory, the beets and vegetables helped to add some lightness and counter the duck.  Highly recommend, even if you aren't too much of a duck eater.

-- Sonoma Coast King Salmon (Brentwood corn, Jimmy Nardello peppers, polenta)($27) - one of few times we found a place that could perfectly cook medium rare salmon.  The sear on the skin was also pretty amazing- nice and crunchy.  The polenta was probably less successful than it could have been, but the salmon makes up for it.

-- Hibiscus - Orange Blossom Panna Cotta (berries, figs , hibiscus syrup)($8) - great balance between the sweet syrup and the slightly sour panna cotta.  The panna cotta was a bit creamier in texture than normal, but the syrup and fruit balanced it out; n fact, the creamy texture saved the dish as a counterbalance to the sweet syrup.  My date doesn't like sweets, but he raved about this one for days after.

All in all, you get a neighborhood-feel vibe with a high quality, fresh, and just plain delicious meal that surpasses the neighborhood feel.  A must try in the Richmond area!
author: Audrey H.

description:
A very interesting brunch location that serves Japanese breakfast as an option! 

Everything we had tasted pretty good and the service was very friendly. They give you special utensils depending on wha you order, such as very pretty chopsticks and spoon for the Japanese breakfast. 

It did get very crowded very fast so definitely make a reservation or come before they open on weekends. They had many unique choices such as the lamb sausage and hash, and the curry with eggs. 

The ambiance is great with indoor seating as well as outdoor with heaters. 

Overall it is a bit pricey in my opinion but I have also seen people pay more for brunch.
author: Ellen G.

description:
We came here for breakfast the day after I saw an article somewhere on the web about the best brunches in SF, and this place was on it.

Hubby and I showed up early on a Saturday and got right in. They must hand out purse hooks (which I did not get) because every lady around me had one.

I ordered the waffle breakfast - which is much larger than it appears in photos. Hubby got the hash - which for me - had too aggressive flavors for a morning - though again - it was a HUGE portion.

The service was fine - though not great. 
Husband said the coffee was "just okay"

People seem to go nuts for their Japanese breakfast, though that is not something I am interested in. ,
author: Amy W.

description:
The food was a 3.75 for me, but the service left me a bit wanting.

I walked in after corgi con and got a table right away, considering it was almost 2pm. The shop itself was lovely and quaint. The bathroom was one of the cleaner ones I've seen in a very long time. Dried flowers on the table completed the look.

I ordered the Japanese breakfast. About 20 minutes later, I checked in on the food since it had been a while, and was informed it was still being prepared.10 minutes after that, it finally arrived. I understand a wait, but I noticed that tables seated after us had already gotten their food....

The egg in the Japanese breakfast was absolutely perfect, and the daikon broth it came in was delicious, memorable, and savory. The kale kimchi was unique, the yellow beans in sesame oil were tasty, and the white fish was perfectly buttery. The daikon broth with thin daikon slices was yum. The rice was cooked well but not overly so. It felt extremely healthy while still being tasty. 4/5, especially given the $13 price tag!

I also had a bite of the liege waffle with bacon and soft scrambled eggs. The bacon was spot on, chewy without being too thick and oily. The soft scrambled eggs had good texture, but it seems like they forgot to add salt to this. The meyer lemon flavor waffle did come through, though the texture wasn't quite what I wanted. This plate was very Instagrammable. 3.25/5

I'd be back to try things if I were in the areas. The prices were also definitely a step down from FiDi!
author: Nicole H.

description:
4.5 stars. Loved this dog friendly eatery. Long wait but food was worth it. Check in with the hostess to grab a seat. Counter seats available for singles.

Heated patio seating out front was warm and inviting. Tables are clean and well decorated- I loved how they placed setting down when you sat down- it made the brunch experience feel special.

Ordering was a breeze- their menu is small but packed full of good items. It did not take long for us to choose. We'd order both dishes again in a heartbeat.

Bbq rib hash - ribs were tender, wow. Hash was fresh and NOT heavy like other hashes I am used to. Didn't feel greasy. It was so clean and included seasonal veggies that made this so clean to eat. The sunny side egg on top added depth against thi freshness !

Waffle with Bacon and scrambled eggs- waffle was perfectly cooked, berry, ricotta and fresh strawberries made for a fresh taste but the berries were not in season so it was a bit tart. The bacon was amazing. Crispy crunchy and delicious. Eggs were perfect as well... not runny, well seasoned... perfect!!

Wait is long for the food, and if you're near the kitchen you'll see the chef cranking out the dishes to order. The kitchen is small but the amount of seating overwhelms the kitchen which means output is slow.

Note:
I wish they'd clean up the window view with some privacy glass - I don't like seeing dirty kitchen appliances and crates through the window when eating outside! It doesn't match with the dishes we ate here nor the lovely table settings outside.
author: Karen H.

description:
I've been wanting to write a Yelp review for the longest time, but I didn't know where or how to start. Anyone who knows me knows that Cassava is my #1 go to place for brunch/lunch/dinner. If there's a restaurand that's always high on my list, it's Cassava. I've tried almost everything on their menu. It changes every month, but they always have selected favorites that doesn't change. I've also had their tasting menu before. Super worth it.

My fav thing to order is definitely the baked burrata, it's my must have whenever I dine at Cassava. Their Japanese breakfast is very simple, yet it hits all the right spots on your tastebuds. I love the use of Koshihikari rice-- it was cooked to perfection and made the entire meal even better. And oh, their sangria is a must. Very generous sized glass!

Service is always amazing, and the only thing that makes me sad is the fact that there's always a wait here, and it gets really packed on most days.

I love this place, you won't regret it.
author: Elle T.

description:
-Cozy atmosphere; just as cozy as the fog outside 
-Friendly staff 
-You can easily spot this cute cafe from the street
-It's also within walking distance from the golden gate park 
-DELICIOUS FOOD 
-great smelling bathroom
author: Jess M.

description:
One of the most underrated brunches in the city! 30-minute wait for a quality brunch in SF on a Sunday? Can't complain!

My fiancée and I love Cassava. It was our first official date 3.5 years ago when I wanted to surprise her with the Japanese breakfast on a rainy December day (she is originally from Japan and authentic Japanese food was a lot harder to come by back then). We've returned several times since and have never been disappointed.

A few years older and hopefully a lot wiser, we returned last weekend with our frenchie; they have outdoor seating (and heat lamps for those frequent chilly SF days!) so bring your pup! My fiancée had the lamb sausage hash and I had the liège waffle (can't rave enough about the lemon ricotta!) with bacon and scrambled eggs. Both were delicious! I especially appreciated the savory and sweet combo in my dish, and the eggs were seasoned perfectly. We both enjoyed the bourbon vanilla honey mocha and the spiced honey latte as well. 

Service has always been quick and friendly. We don't live nearby but would gladly drive across the city to come here!
author: Olivia V.

description:
We gave Cassava another chance the other night. Again, our reservation time was not honored, so I can't leave a 5-star review, but I'm happy to upgrade it to 4-stars as they have fixed some of the other issues. We were seated 30 minutes past our reservation time, but this time they paid for the sangria my fiancé had while we were waiting. It's a nice gesture that goes a long way towards smoothing over reservation mishaps. 

Service was great, and the food was delicious. We were treated very warmly by the staff. Course timing was much better! We'll be back again in the future. I hope to one day upgrade this to a 5-star review. If they could just work out the kinks in their reservation system...
author: Traci R.

description:
I absolutely adore this place! I would give it 4.5 stars if I could. Cassava is mainly new American with a twist of Japanese flair. Both brunch and dinner options are great!

BRUNCH 

BAKED BURRATA & POACHED EGG is my absolute favorite! This was the BEST BURRATA I've ever had in my life. I loved the balance between the poached egg and the creamy fluffy burrata, with the pesto!! and small hints of other flavors. 10 stars for you burrata, you go burrata!

MEATBALLS were a bit dry, I would give it 3 stars

JAPANESE BREAKFAST was so cute! I loved all the small dishes and that fish was prepared to perfection. This is a solid choice, and would recommend trying it. 

DINNER

Get the $42 4 course tasting! Everything was pretty good, the BLACK COD with spaetzle (2nd dish) was my least favorite. It's a black cod kama. I don't mind bones in my fish, but my friend had a difficult time with the dish, just FYI. HANGER STEAK was great, perfectly medium rare, and I think the surprise of the night was HIBISCUS ORANGE BLOSSOM PANNA COTTA. It was creamy, fragrant, and refreshing. Perfect ending to a delicious meal!
author: Jessica L.

description:
Confused Menu and Poor Service

When I noticed that Cassava had recently hit Eater's list of August's top restaurants, my interest was immediately piqued. Ever since I was fortunate enough to have an incredible meal at Trestle, I've become more and more enamored with simple tasting menus that are reasonably priced. Both Trestle ($38 for 3 courses, $48 for 4) and Cassava ($42 for 4 courses) reflect a unique trend of restaurants foraying into the pre-fixe structure that's normally reserved for fine dining. 

However, my experience at Cassava was ultimately incredibly disappointing. One of the dangers of pre-fixes is that you limit the diner's ability to structure meals that are best suited for them, so in exchange you really have to structure courses in a way that not only make logical sense, but hopefully have some sort of synergy that ties them together. 

Cassava's dishes had none of that. While one of the four dishes was great (Sonoma Coast Salmon), one was acceptable (Hibiscus Orange Panna Cotta), and two were confused (Pork Ribs and Sunflower Sprouts), none of them fit together in a way that really made any sense. The menu felt more like an attempt for the restaurant to just frontload a couple interesting dishes without actually trying to understand how the dishes fit together.

The Salmon was fantastic, it had an absolutely wonderful texture and the blend of corn and chili was delightful. The rest of the meal was poor though. For the pork ribs, one scallop was well seared while the other looked practically boiled. Worse, the zucchini puree wasn't properly parboiled to remove whatever acrid flavors are left in the zucchini, so it tasted absolutely disgusting. The sunflower sprouts had an intersting texture, but throwing together some ricotta salata and some random edgy flower sprouts together does not a good salad make. Finally, while I appreciated the panna cotta I'm not entirely certain how long it had been sitting (the hostess grabbed the panna cotta straight out of a fridge when we asked for it a bit early since we had a flight to catch), and was fairly watery.

The worst experience though was when we requested the hostess to please speed up the rate of our meals if she could. We were polite and cordial. She was too when she responded that our pork ribs were being plated currently. However, when we asked if we could have our dessert sent out early too, and that we would happily accept it while we were eating our ribs, she must has misinterpreted us as asking about the pork ribs again. While I get that this misunderstanding can be slightly annoying, (ie. a customer haranguing you about something you answered) I literally witnesses our hostess roll her eyes and treat us like idiots for the remainder of the meal even when we clarified about the dessert. This is unacceptable, it is the job of the hostess to treat guests properly and not make a hostile environment because her diners asked one dumb (to her) question. 

Overall, the food was below average, but it simultaneously managed to miss my culinary expectations while being poor enough service-wise to warrant the only service complaint I've had in 35+ reviews I've written on this site.
author: Samuel W.

description:
Read mixed reviews about their Japanese breakfast on yelp and I'm sorry to say but I am on the side that was disappointed. The Japanese breakfast was pretty bland, nothing outstanding. I didn't really enjoy the soup and the fish was just ok. The price was really fair though.

On the other hand, their honey spice latte was so good though- definitely order this.

Went on a Sunday at 11:30 and only waited 10-15 mins for a table
author: Jenny J.

description:
What I loved about Cassava was that for a really classy brunch, I didn't have to wait for HOURS and HOURS in line for a table. I actually came in on Father's Day right when it opened... it was a good thing I did, because I was told that all the tables were reserved, and that we would only be able to sit at the small bar area. Luckily, though, after my fam and I ordered our food, we got moved to a larger table, because a previous party had apparently cancelled their reservation. Yay for us!

The menu itself is pretty concise, but I can tell that each dish is well thought out. My brother ordered the cornish hen, my mom got the lamb sausage hash, and I picked the leg of lamb salad. Everyone's meals looked amazing, but since I didn't really taste test anyone else's dish, I can really only speak for the salad. Overall, I had very generous portions of everything. The lamb was a little bit dry, but not so dry that I'll be complaining about it. The tartness of the kumquats was what really made this stand out, imo. Plus, for $13, I didn't think this was too bad.

Can't wait to come back here again!
author: Connie X.

description:
My friend and I were able to walk into Cassava without waiting in a line around 12:30pm on a weekday, which was nice for a small brunch place in the city. I loved the ambiance of the little shop, it was quiet although most of the tables were filled, which is a nice change from most loud brunch places.

The ordering system is a bit inconsistent, as my friend states the last time she came, they take orders at the table, but this time they asked for us to order at the counter after we get a table. Staff was courteous and friendly without being overbearing and hovering (thanks for the privacy!)

We got the Baked Burrata & Poached Egg and the Roasted Pork Sandwich to share between the two of us. I found the taste of the Baked Burrata to be very homey and the poached egg was cooked to perfection (jiggled and the yolk oozed out after being cut), which made mixing the burrata with egg very smooth and consistent. I wasn't as fond of the pork sandwich, I found the meat too dry and salty in taste.

Would come back here for the ambiance if I'm ever in the Outer Richmond area to try other menu items and possibly give the sandwiches another go!
author: Victoria W.

description:
Such a charming spot in the neighborhood! Good amount of metered parking on the street. We came late morning on the weekend and were seated at the bar immediately.
My companion and I both had their special spiced honey lattes - great presentation! Tasted so sweet and yummy, wish it came in a bigger size!
I had the sausage hash and it was delicious and I could taste the fresh ingredients. Customer service was great, our waters were continuously refilled. All in all a solid spot!
author: Wendy L.

description: Japanese breakfast sounds so good in theory but I wished it was executed better. Soup was too watery and the "kimchi" and sprouts were too bland. I did really love the muffins we ordered and the fruit tea was very refreshing. Others in my group ordered bbq rib hash and that looked amazing.
author: Helen C.

description:
Came here for brunch on a Sunday morning, the place was packed and they said we had to wait about 30 - 40 min. Fortunately our wait got cut down to less, and we ended up only waiting  about 10 min. The brunch menu is very simple here, and they only had about 10 options or so.  I would have liked to order more if I was with more people, to try out more food, but since I was only with 1 other person we just ordered 2 dishes. 

I ordered the fennel garlic sausage lamb hash bowl.  I wish the hash bowl came with more tomatoes, potatoes, and just more food overall.  The sausage was pretty salty, and the hash bowl didn't have enough ingredients to balance out all the saltiness.  The waffle dishes looked delicious, so if I come back, I will definitely be ordering the waffle dish. 

I was deciding between 3 or 4 stars, but the wait staff was all very friendly, so I went up.
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
My family from NYC was in town, and they picked this place especially for the Japanese Breakfast, which I had never had before. But after this meal, I definitely want it again!

The four highlights for me were the following:

1) The Miso soup had radish! The radish could soak up the soup broth and also bring a different texture to the soup.

2) The soft boiled egg. Maybe I've never had a soft boiled egg before, but this one was so great. I didnt expect it to be with broth, and the texture was
a bit slimy, but in an enjoyable way.

3) The fish! It was a small piece, but it was done very well.

4) Sweet potato corn bread appetizer. I'm not a huge sweet potato fan, but this was totally my jam!

I also got a cold brew on the side, and that was great! The coffee was sweet on its own, and I didn't add anything. I will also note that I snuck a bite of my aunt's Slow Braised Pork Rib Hash (only available on the weekends!!)

The only thing that was a bit upsetting was the time we waited between the appetizer and the main. The place was crowded, so I am choosing to take this as a good sign ^-^

So excited for a chance to go back :)
author: Kelly Y.

description:
I didn't want to wait an hour in line for brunch so I was pleasantly surprised to find that Cassava didn't have a long wait for two. We got the baked burrata $13, meatballs and egg $13, and the pork shoulder open face sandwich $15. 

I'm glad we ordered the baked burrata as our appetizer because it did take quite a while for our other dishes.

Both the pork shoulder open face sandwich and the meatball dishes came with a fried egg on top. I realized that I didn't really need the burrata appetizer because it had such a similar texture and taste to the fried eggs. I would order a different appetizer in the future.

I didn't love the pork shoulder. It had a nice char and carmelization but the way it was sliced was not great. It made the texture stringy at times. Other pieces were too fatty for me. 

The sauce for the meatball dish was pretty good, but I was reminded of why I don't really like meatballs. I'm not a fan of the soft meat texture but that's just me. The dish came with rice i think which was different. 

I like the idea of a fusion brunch, but the dishes we chose were just alright. 

I enjoyed watching the staff prepare the dishes. They work in a really cramped, hectic space. We sat at the awkward little bar to the left of the door. I'm slightly concerned about the cleanliness of this server/cook method because servers who bring our dishes to the table and take away used cups/plates also prepare a lot of the dishes. 

On a positive note, the host guy was super nice.
author: Thien H.

description:
Wow. This was the best thing I've ate in a while. The Japanese breakfast comes with picked vegetables, poached egg, braised fish, and miso soup. The pickled vegetables were seasoned just right, nothing too over powering. The fish was done great (I love that this was "bland" -- it really went well with everything else. Anything more seasoned would've been too overpowering.) my favorite part was the soup, plenty of daikon that's been cooking for a while that it sucked up the broth and miso, tender and sweet and umami! The rice was done well and the bean sprouts (although NOTHING like kimchi) were just right. I left feeling full/satisfied but not overly stuffed, and I felt comfortable because the food wasn't too salty/sweet/greasy!

Also the lattes come iced. The spiced honey one was so good, kinda like a dirty chai but better. I wish it was slightly less sweet though.
author: Soo L.

description:
So I already had a pretty negative impression of Cassava after having to wait 70 minutes for seats, even though we showed up early... but I guess you can't really control that when the restaurant is small and the place is popular.

Cassava is a mystery. I don't know whether I like it or hate it. I like it because the aesthetic is BEAUTIFUL. Everything from their ultra soft paper towels to their sophisticated mugs makes the enviornment very relaxing. They even have nice heaters outside so that you can eat in the warmth on a winter day (though your bums will be cold from the metal chairs... which is weird because the rest of your body is warm). They're dishes are plated BEAUTIFULLY too.

The food itself was pretty mediocre. I thought the open faced pork loin sandwich was excellent. But the meatball curry was basically really wet meatballs drenches in sauce served with rice... Nothing about it made it compelling or super flavourful. The Japanese breakfast was also underwhelming. Condiments, miso soup, rice, and a very salty chunk of fish was definitely not what I was expecting for a place that was so beautifully decorated and a dish that was so elegantly plated.

The worst part of my experience here was the hidden charges. They charged $2 for Hot WATER. I thought hot water would be free since cold water was free, and no where on the menu did they state that there was a cost to having hot water... but guess not. Also, they charge a 5% service fee that is explicitly noted as "not tip." I don't even know what this means. If you are going to mandate the service fee, just mandate the tip so we don't have to be confused about awkward tipping policies.

TLDR: come here for the insta, but there's really nothing else special about this place.
author: Monica X.

description: One of my favorite restaurants. Everything from ambiance, service, location and of course food is everything you could want at an essential neighborhood joint. You can tell they put a ton of passion into their craft. Their dinner tasting menu is such a steal. High quality and super tasty. Loved the fish course and exceptional panna cotta. Their menu changes seasonally and is sure to deliver. Cassava is a go to of mine.
author: Lindsey M.

description:
It seems like every time I make a trip out to the Richmond, there's always a new hidden gem that pops up. Having grown up in this neighborhood, there's only a few places that remain from my childhood like Americana, but I'm glad to see that places like Cassava are making this neighborhood their own. 

I came for breakfast last week with an old friend who has a knack for finding great eats. The breakfast menu is quite small and features your typical continental breakfast, a breakfast sandwich, avocado toast, and a granola bowl. However, one item stands out amongst the others, which is the traditional Japanese breakfast. Having just traveled to Japan a couple of months ago, I was intrigued by this option. In fact, I've never had a traditional Japanese breakfast while I was in Japan.

The breakfast includes a bowl of koshihikari rice, seaweed soup, pickled persimmons, bean sprouts, a soft poached egg in dashi broth and for $3 more, market fish, which happened to be cod. The meal was light, balanced, and refreshing. I loved the casual vibe, great food, and reasonable prices.
author: Bailey Z.

description:
This is a classy little neighborhood eatery, that seems to be gaining in popularity. Yay for them!

I've eaten here a handful of times over the years and have been pretty impressed. It's not too pricey, with a seasonal and creative menu. The food is beautifully plated and the service is very professional. 

There is also a small but well thought out wine list with suggested pairings as well as a pretty affordable four course tasting menu.

Yes, it's very
far out towards the beach, but it's across from the Balboa theater if you want a nice low key place for dinner before a show.

Last night husband and I had yam cornbread, fried chicken with chipotle mayo and lamb chops for dinner. We split everything. 

The yam cornbread was very good and came with honey butter. Yes, it was warm.
I'd get that again.

Next up was the chicken. It was good but fairly standard. They used chicken thighs so it was flavorful, but overall it was just ok.

Finally, we had the lamb. Well yum. It came with mashed rose potatoes and a corn puree. We were really happy with the lamb. It was so tender and perfectly seasoned. I really liked the corn puree too, but husband thought it tasted too much like creamed corn (I like creamed corn so that wasn't a problem for me.) The potatoes were good enough and looked pretty. 

I'll be back next time I want to see a movie at the Balboa and am not craving xlbs at the cash only Chinese place a few doors down.
author: El B.

description:
Yumm! So happpy we found this place.

Wanted to grab something to eat in an outdoor area before a hike with our pup on this gorgeous and sunny Saturday. Browsed through yelp and called a few places to realize that a lot of their outdoor seatings had a long wait. Was literally just about to grab a sandwich to eat in the car when we found Cassava and called them. They had a 30+ minute wait also but we were able to put our name and number down without having to be present. I really liked that they notify you by text that your table was ready and that they would hold it for 5 minutes- gave us enough time to start walking to the restaurant. 

Right upon arrival, we were led to a 5 seater table joining another couple. The table was rectangular and spacious so it gave us enough room in-between so it didn't feel like we were right next to each other. 

The menu was simple but enough to entice your taste buds. They offered 2 starters, 7 entrees, and 2 desserts as well as a back page of drinks: sangria by the pitcher, tea, coffee, house cocktails, beer, and wine (sparkling, white, rose, and red).

While still browsing through the food menu, I couldn't help but keep overhearing the guy next to us praising how great and delicious his Garlic Lamb sausage hash bowl was- he was having a mouthgasm, eyes closing, eyebrows raising, and fist clenching-his-silverware-tight kinda moment with each bite into his lamb sausage that he verbalized it three times! LOL. Sold my bf on it.

FENNEL- GARLIC LAMB SAUSAGE HASH BOWL ($17): 
made with roasted marble potatoes, fresh peas, fried egg, and chipotle aioli. One sausage wasn't enough that my bf ordered another for $7. I'm not a fan of lamb at all- the taste and smell throws me off every single time and I can smell lamb a mile away (my most disliked meat of all....) But my bf was so persistent and persuading with how delicious the sausage was that he got me to try a bite with a piece of potato. AND to my surprise, it was actually not that bad. Still got that lamb taste that I really can't tolerate, but overall was not bad. The texture was tender and soft and the taste was still gamey but bearable. We were really surprised to find purple yam mixed with the potatoes (yumm! one of my all time favs). Fresh peas were fresh indeed; bright green, firm, and sweet. The bf doesn't like soft cooked peas lets alone fresh hard ones so I scooped them over to my plate and ate it with my salad. :)

CORNISH GAME HEN & CORNBREAD ($18):
oven roasted half hen, sweet potato cornbread, market salad, and fried egg. The sweet potato cornbread was what really sold me, tbh. But it was also the one thing I didn't like as much in my entree. Texture was soft and moist, almost like a muffin, but a tad bit too sweet for my liking. Besides that, I loved everything else especially the oven roasted hen. The meat was super moist and delicious. Seasoned lightly but very appetizing and literally got me digging into the hen and wanting more after I finished it. Wished there was moree! The hen is easily one of the best poultry dishes I've had in a long time. The tangerine slices in the salad were sweet and citrusy; a nice bold taste to my salad with peas. lol

DRINKS:
- Sangria ($8): red and white wine, port, southern fruit tea. Very generous glass of sangria but it was watered down and did not have much of a wine or fruit taste. :(
- Pomegranate Margarita ($11): sabe blanco tequila sake, house-made pomegranate liqueur agave, lime, and sea salt. Decent and standard margarita but didn't have much of the pomegranate taste. Too much ice in the drink. 

Really enjoyed our meal here at Cassava that I already recommended this place to a few friends, especially our pup-owning ones! Food was great but the drinks were a total miss :\ Loved the outdoor seating- although windy, the heat lamps above our heads kept us warm and toasty. Servers were efficient and cordial. Bathroom lock was a bit weird, no matter which way I turned to lock it, I was still able to open the door which made it hard to know when it was locked!
author: Anissa D.

description:
The primary reason I look forward to weekend hikes is for the meal after ;) Après-Hike ftw! After a gorgeous hike at Land's End, we hit up Cassava and were surprised at the hipster quotient of this place. Not the kind of brunch place I was expecting in this neighborhood.

After a quick 15 minute wait, we were seated outside. I like that they have heaters outside (absolutely necessary for this part of the city #coldwinds).

They have a small, unconventional brunch menu. Since there were 4 of us, we got to try out the continental breakfast, game hen, Japanese breakfast and the lamb sausage.

I personally loved the continental breakfast. It was simple, fresh and tasty. Guiltless brunch without a crazy wait line? Bring it on!! My friends had mixed reactions to their dishes, but mostly liked it! Their coffees and juices were great too!

They were bit on the pricey side but aren't San Francisco brunch places; and uh.. fancy plating!
author: Divya S.

description: Service and food were excellent. The waffle and the burrata were phenomenal. The rib bowl was amazing and meat was very tender. All entrees were filling and this cute neighborhood brunch spot did not disappoint on anything. Great spot!
author: B P.

description:
We ordered the burrata and the Japanese breakfast. The burrata had pesto, greens, pickled onions, poached eggs, and bread on the side (I'm not sure if I've missed any ingredients). The Japanese breakfast was below average and bland. The bland miso soup had a bunch of cabbage. The "kimchi" was not kimchi but instead bean sprouts (korean style kkongnammul) and the same sauces were used for the greens. I got one small piece of trout along with some sunomono. Not much stood out to me about this dish.... so... it was disappointing. 

Overall OK experience but I'm pretty sure it won't cross my mind to come here for breakfast.
author: Monica L.

description: The food was realy great. Also loved their coffee. They let you make reservation in advance and was quite flexible when our plan changed and had to adjust to a different time. The only thing was the waiting time for food was a little bit too long.
author: Michelle W.

description:
One of the best restaurants I've been to in a long time. First time ever coming here and everything was damn near perfect. Staff was so warming and genuinely treated me like family.

Don't even get me started on the food and drinks! First off the peach cocktail, hands down one of the best I've ever had - legit tasted like peach cobbler and gave me all the warm fuzzy feelings of the holidays. 

The fried chicken starter, set the bar so high - the batter was light, flaky and crispy but packed some huge flavor.  I thought things couldn't get any better but Ive never been so wrong before. 

The salmon was perfectly cooked and practically melted in your mouth. The pork ribs were to die for. The meat literally fell off the bone. The waiter gave us a knife but no knife was needed at all.  

For dessert, chocolate pot de creme. I've never been a huge fan of chocolate but that dessert kept me coming back for more. 

I highly implore everyone to try this restaurant! Thank you for making my dining experience one of the best Cassava!
author: Austin L.

description: JAPANESE BREAKFAST IS A MUST!  A friend of mine recommended to come here for breakfast to catch up when I was in SF and it made me think of my time when I was studying abroad in Japan!  It's pretty reasonably priced for breakfast and everything that was served was excellent.  The service was very good too and I think we got lucky with not making a reservation since we were able to get in right when Cassava opened.  I definitely recommend this restaurant for breakfast if you're able to travel from downtown!
author: Alex T.

description:
Place - Easy to find. Many tables are inside and outside. Interior was so good. Sunshine from huge windows. We could see kitchen. Cup and dish were simple and cute.

Taste - We ordered Liege waffle and sausage dish on lunch menu. 

Sausage one was one big sausage with small potatos, brussel sprouts, one egg and sauce. It was good. Normally brunch from other restuarant were so salty for me, but it was well cook! Sausage was huge. It was soft and chewy. Also I liked a harmony with all ingredients. 

Waffle dish came with one waffle with fruits and ricotta, and salade, bacons and scramble eggs. Waffle was soso. It was not sweet. I felt achole(it might be taste of sugar?)But it was good to eat with fruits and recotta. Three pieces of bacons were crispy. Scramble eggs were really good. It was soft and not salty. Overall this dish was great.

Service and Price - First time they gave us wrong dish. But they made new one really fast, so We didn't need to wait a lot. Service was good. Price was little expensive like other brunch restaurants.
author: Da Won L.

description:
Came here again my last visit to sf. Really cool small spot just down a few blocks from my bf's place so we just make the walk out!

The first time we came in I got the avocado toast which was super yummy. This last time I tried out the meatball curry and it was really good!! I just wish it was a little spicer nonetheless it was very filling! As for my bf, both times he got the leige waffle! It's filled w sugar which means the waffle doesn't necessarily require any syrup as it's more than sweet enough!

The service was very pleasant both times I came in. This is easily one of our go to brunch spots whenever I visit the city!
author: Samantha L.

description: Came across this gem of a place after having hiked and wondered about aimlessly for some good three hours.  Maybe it was the exhaustion or we were just THAT hungry, the chorizo hash bowl was devoured in less than 10 minutes.  Did I properly savor the dish?  No.....  Probably should have taken the time to dissect it but the hack!  Cut through that yolk and you get that golden liquid pouring over the hash and sausage.  The juicy chorizo slides down your throat like it's on a slip n' slide, coating your mouth with that seasoned fat.  Damn it...  That's another couple hours of workout to rid of the calories...  But so worth it!
author: Ken L.

description:
Went there for breakfast. 

We had the Burrata thing which was super tasty!!! 

After that the Japanese breakfast. Overall tasty and good quality. The fish was amazing! But the egg with broth and the soup were not bad but also not that flavorful. Nice to sip but nothing I would need again. But for the price you should definitely give it a try and maybe you'll love it! 

Their teas I also found a little bit "boring" especially for 5$.

I'll for sure come back and try their other dishes which look amazing. 

Friendly staff comfy place and good service. Chances to be adjusted to 5 stars in the future!
author: Ilias S.

description:
Cute neighborhood spot.

We had a res at 10 am, and they opened exactly on time.  Service was friendly and quick, which was great because we were hungry!  It's a pretty space with plenty of light.

I had a coffee with the Japanese breakfast (miso soup, pickled beets and bean sprouts, a poached egg and a healthy portion of textured rice).  
Everything was executed well.  My soup had a lot of winter melon in it -- I'm not a huge fan, but to each their own.   It was a light breakfast, but good sized portions.  You won't go hungry.  

My friend ordered sausage and potatoes and it was HUGE.

Also, expect prices that are a little more reasonable than typical SF fare.
author: Holly P.

description:
It was more informal than I thought it would be, but that's not a bad thing, and I don't really know why I had a different impression.

For lunch and breakfast it is counter service. Not sure about dinner. 

Breakfast was quite good. My breakfast croissant sandwich was delicious. The pork shoulder had a unique (but tasty) seasoning - maybe nutmeg? The harissa aioli is delicious.  

My husband's Open Face Avocado Egg Sandwich was also good. LOTS of avocado and good quality avocado. 

Be warned - they do not have decaf coffee or espresso if that's important to you (they do apologize on the menu, but I wonder why not just get some decaf espresso and then everyone wins?)

Nice and light inside. Modern, clever decor. It's a pretty small space. Wasn't busy at 11 on a Monday - but that doesn't say anything, since I don't think anything is busy 11 on a Monday.
author: Sarah C.

description:
I came here because the place had four stars on Yelp, and the restaurant was gorgeous and aesthetically pleasing. However, the food is incredibly bland and I wish they had jars of salt or pepper on the table for us. My boyfriend and I came here extremely hungry, but we could even finish our dishes because of the lack of flavor. I ordered the Japanese Breakfast- literally no taste in the miso soup and a small portion of fish the size of a newborn's bundled up fist. My boyfriend said "this is an insult to cultural foods". My boyfriend ordered the Meatballs with Curry. This curry wasn't even curry, it was more so meatballs drowned in spaghetti sauce. It came with a side of rice and salad... with no dressing whatsoever. Literally a pile of room temperature leaves.
On the bright side, the mimosa was good, but so small for the price they are charging.
author: Vina V.

description: We came on Friday night, and we had such an amazing dinner. The menu is small, but everything we had was delicious! The staff were all incredible, and a shout out to Phil for his fantastic service. We would definitely recommend Cassava, and we hope to try their brunch soon!
author: Rachel G.

description:
We came for a late weekend brunch, but the place was still busy. My friend and I were able to be seated immediately because we were okay with sharing a table outside. Outdoor seating conveniently has heat lamps! This place has a modern feel that was noticeable even sitting outside without the decor. It might've been because of the furniture and plates, but I really enjoyed the ambiance of this place. Definitely a cute brunch date location.

The category for this place is American (new). So I was pleasantly surprised by the fusion meal options that were available. The prices were on the higher end for these items. We decided to share the Japanese Breakfast and the Korean Chorizo Hash Bowl. In hindsight, I do not recommend sharing the Japanese Breakfast. This is not the best shareable meal option because there are many components/side dishes to the plate.

Japanese Breakfast. This was a standard asian breakfast (ie multiple side dishes that accompany the rice) that I'm used to eating daily. The key difference here was the natto that I ordered as an extra. I've always wanted to try natto! I wasn't sure how to eat it and the servers were helpful in explaining. I can say that I am not particularly a fan though. It has somewhat sour taste. My friend said that they seasoned it with something because it tasted different. Be warned it is very 'slimey/sticky' and stretches like a spider web. The fish and soup that they provided was the best part of this meal. The fish was cooked and seasoned well so that it wasn't dry or salty. 

Korean Chorizo Hash Bowl (9/2017 menu). I was a little confused as to where the Korean was taking place in this meal... possibly in the chorizo? There was a lot of chorizo pieces, but unfortunately, the chorizo was really dry and didn't have enough flavor. I wouldn't have recommended this, but it looks like it's already not part of their weekend brunch menu anymore.

This is a very cute date brunch spot with great service. Menu options were unique. Taste wise.. for the price, I just expected a little more.
author: Helen H.

description:
Quaint and contemporary dining!  I was admiring the cozy layout! 

Tasting menu is well worth the bang for the buck! $42 for 4 courses and with beverage pairing, it is an additional $28.  Do opt for the pairing as it is quite swell with the delicious courses!

Service and decor of this place, was splendid.  The presentation of each dish, was appealing and the colors popped! 

Stone fruits salad was dressed fancifully.  Their striped bass was nicely cooked and homely.  I savored the roasted squab with corn purée, polenta and mulberry jus!  The squab was tender and juicy.  Compliment the succulent squab meat with the sweet polenta, then it is a wholehearted entree!  Last, but not least, panna cotta with berries and oatmeal streusel, was served.  The honey sherry whiskey pairing put a nice spazz to the whole dessert and finish to this 4 course meal!  

Cassava uses gourmet ingredients and the staff is eloquent with their words when presenting each plate with the drink. 

I was charmed at Cassava!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
I went for dinner and had a very confusing service which impacted the food as well. I think our server was new or just confused. She came and asked for drink orders when one person was clearly not present. 

For our actual dinner, we had our appetizers (fried chicken and white peach salad- both fantastic!) come out and before ate more then 5 bites, our main courses came out (salmon and pork cheeks). We had 4 large plates on a small table for two. By the time we finished the appetizers and started on the main courses, they were COLD. As we ate our main courses, our 3rd appetizer (The burrata) came out. As a result of the strange service, the main courses were awful. The crispy salmon skin was no longer crispy, it was bland, and the texture in general was off. The pork cheeks were lightly battered (I think) and lost its crispiness. The sauteed squash was begun to let water out, which diluted all of the flavor in the dish, leaving everything extremely bland. It was such a shame since the pork cheeks were so tender. IT would have been a beautiful dish.

I really wanted to like this place and put it in my rotation, but the extremely poor timing of the dishes severely impacted the taste and texture of the dishes. I will probably go one more time to see if they figure it all out, but my advice- make sure you get a good server.
author: Rose T.

description:
YUM YUM YUM YUM!

I've been to Cassava twice with both experiences being great! This time I went with my significant other since we went on a small hike around Land's End Trail. I made reservations for a Saturday since I know this place gets pretty darn busy but we ended up not making it to our reservation since we left San Jose more on the later side. We did our hike and got to Cassava around 12:30 pm and it wasn't even busy! We were seated at the outside table.

FOOD:

Liège Waffle with Scrambled Eggs, Bacon: fruits, house preserve, maple lemon ricotta, powdered sugar. Their waffle is made with pearl sugar, and is not served with syrup. This was the item I got on my first time and it was really delicious. My bf got this and he couldn't get enough of how it wasn't served with syrup yet it is still tasty.

Pork Shoulder & Fried Egg Open Face Sandwich: 12 hour braised pork shoulder, olive tapenade, arugula in verjus on Marla bakery's bread. I'm glad I went with this item because I was about to get the Cornish Game Hen & Cornbread but the nice lady (believe she was one of the owners?) recommended the braised pork since they only serve that during the weekend.

We also got a cup of Bourbon, Vanilla Honey Mocha. It was so goddamn sweet but I hella loved it! Lol.

Service was great! Very attentive and helpful with any questions I had in terms of what I'm deciding between the menus. I'll keep coming back as long as they are around!
author: Aarize D.

description: I looked on Yelp what looked good here and the liege waffle caught my eye, so I ordered the liege waffle. It comes with scrambled eggs and bacon. The waffle is made with pearl sugar and came with some berries, some ricotta, and some jam on top of the waffle. Everything on the plate was delicious and I finished it all. It is definitely worth the $15. They give you 3 long pieces of bacon and a good amount of scrambled eggs. I'm not sure if I would try anything else besides the waffle since I am kind of picky eater. My friends enjoyed their dishes, so I'm sure they're just as satisfying. I definitely recommend the waffles here.
author: Allyson L.

description:
A friend of mine took me here a couple years ago and I absolutely loved it. Last Sunday after strolling along Lands End a group of us wanted to have brunch around the area. Cassava was five minutes and I remembered how great the food was there so we decided to check it out.  As any decent brunch place is the wait was a bit long but you can't really control that. People love to linger around for ages and blabber on in conversation even after they finish their meals. Eventually we got our table outside. It was a pretty chilly day so sitting outside was not ideal but it wasn't actually that bad with the heat lamps above our table. It felt toasty and comfortable.

Our waitress was exceptionally nice to us and very attentive even though the place was busy with other patrons. She memorized all of our orders and drinks without needing to write it down. Very courtious through the entire meal and I think she deserves a lot of praise for it.

The food was pretty awesome. We all tried different things. The menu seemed to be a fusion of many different American meals and Japanese dishes, one in particular that my friend got being a full traditional (or close to being traditional) Japanese set with rice, miso, fish, pickled vegetables and even a small bowl of natto.

I chose the Cornish hen with a salad. It was tasty. The hen was juicy and the skin was absolutely crispy at first bite. The salad tasted fresh and the blood orange that was put in it gave it a good citrus flavor.

Overall a wonderful place for brunch. It's not a very big place and it always seems to be busy for weekend brunch when I pass by the place but it's worth the wait to go there. Much recommended. Especially from someone like me who does not have any sort of taste buds and food is pretty much eaten so I won't die.
author: Simon L.

description:
Trekked into the unknown land of Outer Richmond to meet for brunch at Cassava. No disappointments here at 10:30AM.

Pros:
+ Indoor and outdoor seating
+ Casual vibes
+ Friendly and attentive servers
+ Good food at reasonable prices!!
+ Outdoor heated seating (really intense heat)
+ Generous portions
+ Offers text message updates to call you when they're ready for you!!

Cons:
- Parking could be a potential issue

Recommendations:
+ Cornish Game Hen, $18; 5/5
+ Rosé; 5/5
[A big plus to the female server who was very generous with the Rosé. She also poured a little for me to try before I made the real commitment. Yes!]

My dish came with half a hen, cornbread (which I never liked), fried egg, and a peach salad. They really really nailed the hen! It was juicy with a nice crisp touch to the skin. Peach salad was dressed in a lightly tangy dressing, loved it! My friends all took a bite of my cornbread and chicken, which they agreed was done quite nicely. Overall, perfectly executed brunch experience at Cassava.

I'll come back if someone wants to try this spot or if I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Fanny W.

description:
The food was great and the service was excellent! Yuka (one of the owners) was very welcoming, and suggested drink pairings for some of the courses.

Here are the courses we had:
- pan seared Chinook Salmon with bacon, black rice, and winter squash purée 
- slow braised beef cheeks with cauliflower cream
- blueberry & bergamot panna cotta
- bread pudding
- chocolate mousse

Everything was very delicious and plated nicely. I would definitely come back again. The restaurant has a good atmosphere and feels very inviting.
author: Angela W.

description: The tasting menu will get you full and I recommend pairing it with the wine tasting. The black cod and salad are amazing. Don't try to fill your stomach with the honey butter and bread like I did. The honey butter is so good it's dangerous, lol. Jokes aside, I really enjoyed the great tasting menu and warm, casual environment.
author: Misch R.

description:
We decided to venture out to the Richmond area before visiting Golden Gate Park, so found this super cute brunch spot. The entire restaurant is so aesthetically pleasing with its simple, white and wooden décor. The touch of lavender flower vases on each table and their bottled water was a lovely add. Even the food's presentation was so picturesque. I ordered the Korean Chorizo Hash Bowl ($17) while he ordered the Liege Waffle with Scrambled Eggs and Bacon ($15). The chorizo in my hash bowl consisted of a huge piece of chorizo with all the linings included, thus making the cutting and chewing of it quite difficult. Otherwise, I enjoyed the flavors of the dish mixed with the cherry tomatoes, potatoes, corn, argula, and radishes topped with a sunnyside up egg. The pop of colors in the dish made it all the more appealing.

As for the waffle, it was definitely more on the dry side. It's NOT served with syrup, which was a downfall as the waffle is thick and full of breading that could've used some sauces. Definitely an A+ for presentation here, but food is mediocre-good and pricey. It also didn't entirely fill us up, but at least we weren't walking out of here all bloated --nice and refreshing.
author: Cindy Z.

description:
Great little brunch place in the Richmond. We sat outside on a freezing day but their heat lamps did what they needed to and kept us warm.

I was looking for something light and ordered the "Continental" breakfast which was a yogurt parfait with honey, granola, and berries with a poached egg on the side. It also was supposed to come with a croissant but they were nice and let me substitute that out with extra berries. They also allow you to substitute out the poached egg with a fried egg if you prefer your eggs less runny.

All in all, Cassava was a solid brunch place with reasonable prices, and I'm looking forward to trying out more of the menu!
author: Charles L.

description: We were in the golden gate park area and decided to try a new brunch spot. After googling "best brunch near Golden Gate Park" Cassava popped up first with 4 stars. We read the reviews and decided to give them a try. We loved everything from the service, the various menu offerings to the drinks. We started with a pitcher of the Pimms and baked Burrata appetizer to share based on the recommendation of our server. She scored on both recommendations! We both decided on the waffle and eggs for our entree and it was a hit. The fruit and greens were fresh that accompanied our flavorful entrees. Can't wait to return to our new favorite go to for brunch.
author: Ricardo C.

description:
Take a step out of the bustle of the everyday routine and settle in for a warm, cozy meal at Cassava. Set in the Outer Richmond, Cassava offers a rustic, causal environment to share a delicious meal with friends. 

Enjoyed a weekday brunch/lunch meal here with my sister. The menu contains a variety of options including traditional breakfast foods, Japanese-themed fusion meals, and even Southern-inspired fare. I ordered the roasted veggie rice bowl. The dish was perfect from the first bite. The blend of sweet, roasted vegetables was perfectly balanced with the nuttiness of the rice and walnuts. The basil pesto and other flavorings added surprise bombs of umami that set my palate on fire. All of this was mellowed out with rich avocado on top. My sister ordered the burrata with poached egg which I also tried and loved. 

The prices and portions were very reasonable and I left feeling satisfied. I would highly recommend checking out Cassava for a wonderful weekday meal!
author: Aaron C.

description:
The food itself was good. Croissant sandwich was flaky and buttery just the way I like it. The meat, egg, and cheese were pretty standard, but the arugula was an "interesting" touch. Arugula is so nutty and flavorful, but with the rest of the sandwich, it wasn't overwhelming, but still a semblance of the taste. I'm not sure if I liked it or not, I don't hate it, but I would've been fine with a different green. 

My friend ordered the continental breakfast which for $13 doesn't look that impressive. I mean I'm pretty sure I could make that save for the poached egg. But c'mon! Yogurt, fruit, granola, and honey? Easy. Toasted croissant? Easy. Poached egg? Sure, I'll give you that one. But why is this so expensive for something so simple? Additionally, the yogurt was so sour and needed a bit more honey to enjoy it. 

The place itself is nice and quaint. It's a cute cafe for hanging out, but it's a bit pricey for some simple meals imo. I'd give it 3.5 stars if I could.
author: Edmund L.

description: After a hike by lands end, we ended up coming here pretty hungry. The food wasn't the best but they have really interesting combinations. I had the game hen with cornbread - absolutely loved the cornbread. It was freshly baked, mildly sweet and still warm. The chicken could have been better - it was a little too well done for my taste. A friend had the Japanese breakfast - again a good assortment of items but nothing that stood out except for the fish which was excellent. One of us also got the lighter option of the cereal fruits and  croissant - the only vegetarian option.  A friend also had the carrot juice which she really liked! Overall, a good place to visit if you end up in the neighborhood.
author: Anand R.

description:
Setup: lunch

Owner operated small business, interesting menu options, clean and quaint space, delicious toast (of all things?!)

Though it was still brunch time, only one option was available so we had to order from the lunch menu. A number of other groups came and left due to the lack of brunch options. 

Baked burrata had good texture but not enough flavor, curried meatballs were tasty but tasted completely like tomato and no curry. Pork sandwich was pretty good but very difficult to eat (ended up using fork and knife).
author: Victoria M.

description:
I may have just found my favorite brunch spot. The beachy hideout charm is impeccable, the tables are spaced respectfully considering how tiny the space is, and the bar/wait staff are just so, so welcoming.

We got:
-Japanese breakfast: I was not excited by the presentation, but surprisingly this was my favorite item. The pickles were virtuosically good, with a daring cumin twist on top of traditional Japanese tang, and paired so well to an impeccably succulent grilled piece of rock cod. My only advice is the dashi for the egg and miso soup was watery and not umami enough.

-Sausage hash: a super hearty portion that balanced the heaviness and richness of the sausage with a lot of bright, fresh local vegetables.

-Bread pudding: I wish it was a little more custardy and less bread-y, but the fruits were so fresh and such a treat.

Overall, what made this place stand out was the atmosphere and the friendliness of the staff. Please, everyone, don't swarm this place.
author: Ken H.

description:
Holy cow! I think I just found my new favorite brunch place in Richmond District! 

Came here for Sunday brunch around 10am and there was little to no wait for a table. I was genuinely surprised and quickly got seated outside with the heat lamps turned on. Staff was friendly and very welcoming. I would say cassava doesn't have the biggest place so be prepared to wait sometimes! 

My friends and I ordered the pork shoulder open sandwich ($15) , the baked Burrata ($13), and the meatball and eggs ($13). The pork shoulder sandwich was probably my favorite dish out of everything we ordered. The bread had this garlic spread on it and the pork shoulder was absolutely delicious. Fatty and warm with a nice egg on top! I also love arugula and enjoyed every bite of this :) The baked Burrata was definitely a bit smaller than what I imagined but it also tasted great. Plenty of bread to go around the table and to dip! I didn't try the meat balls and eggs, but my friend told me it was satisfying, but nothing out of the ordinary. 

Prices here are pretty typical of other SF brunch places. Expensive for their portions, but still tasty. 

I would recommend the restaurant to invest in blankets for those sitting outside. The heat lamps help, but it does get pretty chilly sometimes. I'd be back to Cassava to try more items on their menu!
author: Kenneth L.

description:
I've been to Cassava for both brunch and dinner now and both have impressed me. Located on Balboa street near Purple Kow, the restaurant is quite small on the inside but also has outdoor seating too. I would recommend making a reservation if you plan on coming. Parking is the usual street/meter parking.

For brunch, we were able to snag a table for three before the wait began. They have yummy sandwiches and a cute trendy Japanese breakfast option that we ordered. Carrot juice was also tasty.

For dinner, we arrived around 6:30-7pm and they only had bar seating available. The rest of the tables were for reservations. The host was friendly as well as the servers. We ordered the duck confit and oven roasted chicken. Both birds were fantastic and perfectly cooked. We did not leave anything left on the bones! The portions they give you is well worth the price. The server warned us that it would take about 30 minutes to come out so I appreciate the warning.

Cassava is a great small business. I will come back as their menu seems to change every couple of months!
author: Michael T.

description:
The service was stellar. The staff memebers were welcoming. The picture says it all!

 I ordered the "Continental Breakfast" which included house made yogurt, topped with soft buttery granola, fresh fruits, and a light drizzle of honey. I'd personally would ask for a lightened topping with honey. However, everything about the dish was perfect. The CB also comes with a toasted-croissant and a soft shell boiled egg. Excellent combo for a light and easy going breakfast.

Cassava is a great brunch/breakfast spot. I'd say it's a hidden gem in the outer Richmond.
author: Jeff C.

description: Cassava is the best restaurant in the Richmond District. A wonderful husband and wife team. A very personal, caring experience. The food is great, the experience even better. And good value for the money.
author: Slip E.

description:
Great little brunch spot in Richmond. Seems to be Asian fusion cuisine. 

We were seated immediately at 10 am on Saturday, outside at the heated tables. Food comes out fairly quickly. They have a wide selection of savory/sweet brunch options as well as a good selection of brunch beverages (cocktails and beers). 

I got the Japanese breakfast with natto, the plating was very aesthetically pleasing but I felt that it could use a sweet element among the dishes. Maybe toast or something. But it was great nonetheless. 

I think this spot is very cute and worth the drive out to Richmond.
author: RachEl L.

description: I've been eyeing Cassava for some time now and finally got the chance to check it out with some friends. I rarely venture to the Richmond to eat, but if it's to catch up with my old friends, I really don't mind. I really enjoyed Cassava's new Thirsty Thursday menu. My friends and I stopped by for HH last Thursday, grabbed a seat outside underneath the heaters and basically ordered everything off their special menu. We ordered a bottle of red wine to share, three orders of Cassava's fried chicken, and three orders of the burrata plate. All the dishes were simple and delicious. Service was great, seemed like my friend was a regular there since everyone knew him, but he swears it's because his sister is a regular. Great place for dinner, and I'm sure an even better place for brunch, can't wait to check that menu out.
author: Elaine N.

description:
I would like to try for breakfast which, judging from reviews, is the best time to eat here.

We, however, were there for dinner.

Was surprised no "real" salad. A few greens under asparagus, or a few greens under smoked salmon.

The fried chicken was all batter and fatty. Probably the wrong thing to order here but I really wasn't very hungry. Others had the steak and said it was good -- but, although the menu says it has vegetables with it, the amount was so small it was more of a garnish.

On the plus side, the service was excellent.
author: Emily G.

description: This place is located in what seemed to be a wonderful neighborhood and has very polite servers. The menu did not have too many special or unique options. The food was okay.
author: Aasawari N.

description: Truly disappointed!!! So many good reviews I was so excited. The mint tea was ok I was expecting the food to be amazing not even close. The people were nice. The place across the street is ten times better. We really should've gone there. The eggs were blah. Total was $45 waist of money my breakfast was ruined. Well now I know
author: Sasha M.

description:
The pros about Cassava:

1) They take reservation for weekend brunch without the wait. (Yes, you heard me...Do it!!)
2) Pomegranate Glazed BBQ Pork Ribs "Hash" ($17) ...tasty, but a little more ribs would be nice. 
3) Indoor and outdoor seating.

The cons about Cassava:

1) From ordering our food to actually getting our food took almost an hour (but it felt like forever).
2) Liège Waffle with Scrambled Eggs, Bacon ($14)- no syrup served together. Really though, it's dry. Some syrup would be nice. Honestly, wasn't feeling this dish at all. 
3) Service was very slow and not attentive at ALL. Flagging them down each time to get water to order to finally paying for our bills. Aiyah!!!

Prior to having brunch here, we made reservation to have dinner the following week, but we cancel it. With our not so great experience for brunch, I don't know how I would feel having a 4 course tasting menu at Cassava...
author: Owie N.

description:
Another cute brunch place!  We got here right when it opened on Saturday and were seated right away (a plus!).  I ordered the Japanese breakfast and was quite happy with it.  At first, I tried each element separately, but some seemed bland while others were more punchy.  I wound up mixing everything together in my poached egg bowl chazuke-style (is this the intention or was I a weirdo?) and LOVED how well each item balanced another.  

Service was attentive, quick, and friendly.

We'll be back and will try their lattes next time!
author: Sheila C.

description: Really delicious brunches! Nice calm equiped place where we deffinitely want to come back one day to try theirs lunch.
author: Adam R.

description: Very disappointed in this place. The food was really mediocre and it is extremely over hyped. Worst part is how rude the staff was to me and my kid. Real waste of my time and money. I think the only reason they have decent reviews is because there is nothing else around like it so it feels like a novelty. If this place was in the Mission it wouldn't last very long. Do yourself a favor and skip this one. So many better options in the neighborhood!
author: Maya G.

description:
I rarely update reviews "down" but I think Cassava is solidly 4 stars. Loved their brunch offerings but dinner was just not a 5-star experience.

First of all, they require a credit card to make reservations which I found a bit odd. Not sure why any place would need to do that unless they only have a tasting menu. 

Wine selections by the glass were a bit limited and although the Rose I had was tasty, the pour was stingy for a $12 glass of wine. 

On to the food!
Starters: Burrata salad and carrot salad. Burrata was good, came with bread and some simple greens. Nothing special though and pretty simple dish. Carrot salad was delicious and loved the accompaniments.

Entrees: Limited menu. My dad got the octopus and sea bass (was supposed to come with fish collar but bass was a substitute). He wished the octopus had not been in the dish--said it was odd to mix two fish like that. Loved the bass and would pass on the octopus next time. Broth it came in was flavorful.

Beau got the Mary's chicken. It's basically a very delicious half chicken on a plate. He liked it but it was literally just chicken on a plate with little else (some wilted greens?). 

I got the salmon and it was probably the best dish on the table. Perfectly cooked with accompaniments that made sense (purée, rice). I ate every bite!

No complaints about service at all-kind and attentive. Space is also simple and modern. Nice that they have heaters above the outdoor tables in the chilly outer Richmond. Loved brunch here but can't say I'd return for dinner.
author: Semuteh F.

description:
TLDR - Cute spot, well-executed food, but sadly lacking that extra punch to warrant a return visit

I loved the place itself for brunch - chill, relaxed vibe, lots of light, indoor and outdoor seating (with overhead heat for colder days!). It's a great spot for a slower, quieter type of meal. The space is rather small so expect a little bit of a wait during peak brunch hours, or make a reservation beforehand. My group of 3 waited maybe 15 minutes for a table around 1:15PM on a Sunday. There's an open kitchen as well and since it's a small space, it smelled strongly of oil, and that grease smell stuck to my hair afterwards.

The menu is small, which is good if you are easily overwhelmed by too many choices. Reasonably priced (for SF anyway) with some Asian/Japanese inspiration. I found the food to be just okay overall and mostly lacking in flavor. Nothing wow-ed me and since the menu is short here, there's not much else on the menu that would bring me back for a second visit.

We ordered 3 dishes to share:

* DUCK LEG CONFIT SALAD ($16) - 4/5
[citrus vinaigrette, shaved grana padano, romaine, arugula, soft shell-poached egg]
First things first.. my salad was missing the egg promised on the menu. I didn't notice it until halfway through because the duck was so good, and I felt like it was too late to point it out to the waiter so I decided not to bother. But speaking of the duck, it was a decently sized portion, kind of fatty and melt-off-the-bone tender soft. Tasty, but the rest of the salad was just plain salad. Maybe it would've been better had the egg been there.

* POMEGRANATE GLAZED BARBEQUE PORK RIBS "HASH" ($17) - 3/5
[roasted farm potatoes, quinoa, soft shell-poached egg, romaine lettuce, arugula, cherry tomatoes]
Sadly disappointing. Pom glazed BBQ sounded delicious but the ribs were really underwhelming in flavor. I could barely taste any BBQ. The ribs were also a little on the dry side despite the fattiness. The quinoa, on the other hand, stood out a little more. Slightly acidic from the pickled onions.

* JAPANESE BREAKFAST ($13) - 3/5
[koshihikari rice, our miso soup, pickled vegetables, wakame with mushroom, oven roasted market fish, soft shell-poached egg in broth]
Rather plain and boring overall. The salmon was moist but not quite as soft and buttery as other salmon I've had. The portion of fish was also tiny, as was the breakfast plate portion as a whole.
author: Jessie L.

description: Almost excellent. We had the 4 course meal for $42 each. It was a $500 dinner for 7 by the time we were done but the meal was elegant and upsvale. Service was remarkable. The food was outstanding. The only negative was that we sat outside and the restaurant sits on a slightly sloped sidewalk. After 2 hrs of sitting and sliding out of my seat, my back and rear end were in so much pain. Sciatica flared up. It was bad. There just has to be more comfortable seating outside not hard slippery chairs to combat sitting on a slope for 2 hrs. On a positive note the outside  heaters are super warm on chilly SF nights!
author: Carol A.

description:
While trying to figure out where to grab lunch during what seemed to be a busy lunch hour, my friend called Cassava and they were able reserve a table for seating five minutes later. I ordered a Japanese Breakfast with the additional Natto while my friend ordered the Breakfast Sausage Hash Bowl. Overall, brunch was great. The restaurant atmosphere is hip. I tried my friend's breakfast sausage and it was tasty. 

However, while intrigued by the Japanese Breakfast, I found it rather disappointing. The flavors of the Natto and the "kimchee" were great, but the soup was bland and more a vegetable soup than miso. The rice was a mix of brown and white rice, which was fine, but overall wasn't well made. Filling but fairly overprice breakfast item in my opinion.
author: Andrew T.

description: The food was cooked perfect and presentation was nice, BUT lacked flavor. Both the salmon and lamb could use some more flavor. For the price of the food, I expected something more memorable. No desire to eat here again.
author: Kirk D.

description: Last night I dined at Cassava for my birthday. And I enjoyed every minute of it. The atmosphere was lively yet intimate; the staff was very friendly; and the food was excellent -- such unique flavors! I had the white peach salad which was refreshing and tasty with a little crunch. And for my entree, I had the pork cheeks which was incredible and savory. For dessert, I had the hibiscus-orange blossom panna cotta which was just the right amount of sweet with fresh berries and a dash of mint. The dishes were beautifully plated with such gorgeous colors. I can't wait to come back and try other items on the menu!
author: Lea G.

description:
We loved the host and we had a sweet, female, Japanese server who was awesome. The food was delicious. We ordered the baked burrata with poached egg, the waffle, the lamb sausage hash bowl, 1 glass of sparkling rose and 1 house made margarita. All dishes were fresh, delicious, prepared and presented beautifully with flavors on point. Our server filled my (very small but adorable) vintage champagne glass to the top (about 3 oz). The Rose was nice. My husband said the margarita was wonderful. 

I left off a 2 stars because our lovely server disappeared. I waived down a tall, white, male server after waiting quite a while with empty plates and glasses (we both wanted 1 more drink). I ordered another rose and then the server quickly walked away before my spouse could order his drink. Then when the server returns he pours 1/5 of the tiny glass with rose. I thought he wanted me to 'taste' it first before pouring, but then I looked up and he was gone. That .05 oz pour was my drink? For $14 a glass? I wouldn't care if  a) our first server didn't pour my first glass it to the top (which is 3oz pour if to the top), b) I looked around the place and everyone with wine had their tiny glass filled to the top and c) it was $14 glass of rose. So I paid $14 for .05 oz of wine. (This is NOT an expensive rose by any means). We tried to say something in addition to ordering my husband's drink a second time when the server came back to drop off the bill, but he immediately dropped off check and quickly disappeared without giving us a chance to order my hubs drink and address the small rose pour. 

That last server created such an awful experience to what was initially a lovely Memorial Day brunch at our first time to cassava that I doubt we will return. Between the ignoring us and the Rose rip off, it just was...., bad.
author: Brooke S.

description:
3.5 stars. I dont think it was bad, but it wasn't amazing either. 

We got there after our 8+ mile day of walking around SF; we decided to stop by here at around 5:30 or so. We decided to not go with the tasting menu, but did go with some of the dishes on the tasting menu. 

Fried chicken: pretty good flavors, the breading didn't really stay on when we were eating it. The dressing was good. 
Burrata: well if you've ever read any of my other reviews, I love burrata. This was no different. This was definitely delicious and the peaches that came along with it was a great counterpoint. 
Pork Belly: Do I need to say more? It's a bit too fatty, but not bad. 
Salmon: delicious. The peas are good. 

Protip: burrata!
author: Nina Y.

description:
What better way to start off 2017 with a great brunch! It was a bit of a struggle to find parking, even on New Year's morning, but we eventually found a spot haha. Cassava is definitely not your typical brunch place. They definitely lend inspiration from other cultures, as shown by their culturally diverse menu, which includes tastes from Japan and India as well as more "classic" brunch items. The only thing was that it was jam packed, and so the only place for the 6 of us was outside, but it was super windy and cold lol. Having the heating vents on full blast helped though, and as brunch went on, the wind settled down - or else, eating helped warm us up haha. 

- Curry with Meatballs: very nicely done. It was a bit of an odd menu dish on a brunch menu especially, not your typical eggs benny type thing haha. But everything was so balanced, and even the strong flavour of the paneer was not overpowering amidst the curry.
- Liege Waffles with Scrambled Eggs: our "safe" fallback for a brunch plate. This was quite good as well, and no complaints here.

Despite the initial windy and cold before the food came, it was quite an enjoyable brunch with good company. And it seemed to warm up as the meal went on! But maybe because we were filled with the yummy warmth of delicious food :)
author: Joanna C.

description: I came here for brunch with a friend on a Sunday. It was crowded but we managed to get a table inside within about 5 minutes. I got an iced almond milk latte which was a generous size and well made. The prices are a bit high and neither of us were starving so we each got the Continental Breakfast (plus that was the cheapest thing on the menu). It was the right amount of food and fairly healthy so no complaints there, plus everything tasted really good and it's a nice combination of flavors. However, I just didn't feel it was worth the money. I doubt I'd feel much different if I ordered any of the other dishes which cost even more. The atmosphere is nice and they do have outdoor seating for those rare warm days in SF but I don't think the food itself is really worth the money.
