I might try them for other meals to see if I feel differently though.
author: Pooja C.

description: Consistently delicious, flavorful food.  The open face pork shoulder breakfast sandwich on the weekend brunch menu is amazing.
author: Eugene O.

description:
Went for dinner...
Fried chicken appetizer was delicious but the mains we got were just so, so.
author: Rachel R.

description: I took my mom here for brunch, so I can only speak for this meal service. We started with the cornbread appetizer, which was good but one of the breads was dry and overdone. My mom had the Japanese breakfast which she said was good, and she said the salmon that came with it was delicious. I had the waffle with eggs and bacon, and they were accommodating enough to give me avocado instead of the bacon which was a big plus. The waffle was good but the scrambled eggs were some of the worst scrambled eggs I've ever had which put a real damper on the meal. Seriously, the eggs were so over cooked that they had significant brown bits throughout. Also, they poach eggs super super lightly (like almost raw), and if you don't want your egg that lightly poached, the only other option is scrambled eggs. So in a way I felt like the burnt scrambled eggs were a punishment for not being cultured enough to like barely cooked eggs? Anyway, plus sides of the meal were that they subbed the avocado for bacon for me and my mom enjoyed the salmon. It seems like they might have some consistency issues so maybe the kitchen staff was having a bad day.
author: Samantha M.

description: Came here for brunch with some friends. I love that they offer an option for a Japanese breakfast. It was tasty and light. Beautiful place to eat brunch!
author: Lindsey E.

description:
Great Neighborhood Gem

Had reservations at 6pm, was sat immediately at an outside table.  Margaritas were yum, food was delicious (I had the fried chicken as a main and burrata as an app).  Service was really friendly and attentive.  Lucky to have this gem in the hood
author: Kelli M.

description: I couldn't resist after putting off trying the Japanese breakfast for so long...I decide let's do it, Sunday mid morning around 10:30am the restaurant was packed but we only waited 10-15mins..the bar seating was pretty nice,but no hooks for your jacket (no big deal just we wanted to let ppl know )..I went with the Japanese breakfast add natto and my bf had the breakfast sausage hash bowl... for drinks I had the spiced honey latte and he had the bourbon latte,we finished the brunch with sweet pastry bread pudding and cold brew coffees...definitely hit the spot the cod in the Japanese breakfast was flaky and moist,the natto prefect salt and not to slimy lol... I'll definitely be back to try the waffles
author: jonathan h.

description: Chanced upon this restaurant while walking around Golden Gate Park. Fantastic place! Great ambiance, friendly staff. I had the Pork Ribs hash for brunch. The food looks great and tastes even better! Definitely coming back.
author: Saip S.

description:
Super cute restaurant. 

The service was great and they had self help water glass bottles and cups and utensils which I loved. I loved the idea of being able to pour myself water out of a glass bottle whenever my thirsty self wanted to. 

I got the Roasted Veggie Rice Bowl with a pouched egg. It was good but a bit disappointing, a lot of rice and not a lot of veggies. There was a big spoon full of pesto sauce which was yummy but it took over the whole dish. So half way through the bowl I was pretty much over the pesto. 

Overall it wasn't bad, I still had a good experience.
author: Houyee C.

description:
Lots of things I love about this place, but two things -- you know how sometimes on a breakfast menu, you see a really delicious fluffy waffle (empty delicious calories) and scrumptious scrambled eggs too (healthy delicious protein), as separate dishes? Well, here you can get both in one meal! Their whole menu is like that - delicious but balanced too. 

The other thing I love is that the meal that I wanted was almost vegetarian except it had bacon and I asked if I could get a substitute, and they offered avocado. Perfect! A lot of places won't do that. 

So have your waffle and eat it too!
author: J P.

description: Solid food, almost no line.  Our new favorite brunch spot.
author: Stacey C.

description:
Bookmarked as a NO-GO. Food are bought from other places and resold at much higher price. I can tell the owner is good at decorating and making "good looking"dishes but that's all they got. Let's take a step back and compare the quality vs the price and you will know what I mean. 
Wonder why they only serve main dishes at night and weekend? It's because health department doesn't work during those hours. You have been warned!!!
author: Russ C.

description:
I really like Cassava! It's a wonderful, nice, cozy place a for both brunch and lunch (I haven't tried their dinner menu just yet...)! Super friendly and accommodating staff; they really try to make you feel comfortable and welcomed. Oh, and the food is wonderful and unique! I got to try the Japanese Breakfast and the Mr. and Ms. Croque Sandwich. Both were great dishes! Light, fresh, and filling. They also serve Ritual Coffee beverages which is a plus, since I love Ritual!

One great thing about this place is that they don't have too many crazy brunch lines in the weekend like the ones you can find all over the City. Truly a hidden gem.

Last tip: make a reservation to ensure you get a table!
author: Alex L.

description: What a brilliant find! We had such a lovely experience on Solstice evening! The pear and pea shoot salad was delectable with hidden goodies thru it to satisfy the palate. The wine list was mostly imported which suited me just fine... adored the fried chicken which is one of my faves...thigh meat only! and then there was the luscious panna cotta..so unusual and delectable. The plates were all beautifully styled and arranged and colorful. The kitchen was artfully lead by chef-owner Kris Toliao and the front end was lively and attentive with Yuka in charge...can't wait to return!
author: Kay H.

description: Love this place! We come here quite often for brunch and my gf always gets the Japanese breakfast and I always love the Cornish Game Hen. Yum!
author: brenton m.

description:
Cassava is hidden in the Richmond district of San Francisco. 

And like many San Francisco restaurant, it is a little bit on the pricey side. But, if you've got some cash to spend and are craving something different, try this place out! I've been here two times now and I have luckily ordered their best dishes: BAKED BURATTA, and their JAPANESE STYLE BREAKFAST. 

The buratta is creamy and delicious with the greens and toast! The real winner here is the Japanese Style Breakfast with its miso soup, warm Japanese style rice, healthy steamed fish, (extra side of natto = fermented soy beans), kimchi, and pickled veg. DEFINITELY A BANG FOR YOUR BUCK IN TERMS OF PORTION, PRICE, and FOOD. Would go back again for this.

My friends have gotten the continental and I wouldnt recommend this since it goes for more than 11$ for a croissant, small serving of eggs, some fruit and yogurt.

Another tip is to try their GREEN JUICE! I liked it!
author: Margaret G.

description:
It's just ok .. way over hyped ... it also looked much nicer and way more charming before they did the new facade. It went from a super clean look to having poorly hand painted signage as if they had one of their friends do it for them ... weird... 
should've kept it the way it was .. just another wannabe "foodie" scene imposing itself in an SF neighborhood not normally frequented for this sort of thing ...  kinda like Humphrey Slocombe in the mission
author: Ann Oyed ..

description: I'm very picky on poultry, because it tends to be dry...but the cornish hen was AMAZING!! So tender, juicy and flavorful. Clean down to the bones good. Hands down best chicken I have ever eaten. It was like a Chinese roast duck without all the fat. Also comes with an   The sage and pumpkin cornbread was also tasty!  the bf got the curry meatballs with egg  again since he liked it last time.
author: Linda L.

description:
Decided to give Cassava a shot for breakfast. Ordered a cup of coffee and a sandwich. Got my coffee pretty fast and it was delicious however the cup was very very small, I was expecting something more than "half a cup" of coffee for my $6. Even though there was only 3 other tables(total of 8 people) in the restaurant, I had to wait for 40 minutes for a simple sandwich to arrive. I wasn't offered even water in the mean while, no one checked with me to see how I am doing... nothing. I had go get bottle of water and silverware myself. If your prices are upscale(spent $24 for small cup of coffee and a sandwich) your service should be upscale too.

Anyway, food was good(except side salad. It wasn't chopped at all, they just put it as they bought it from store) but any other breakfast place on the block has delicious, way cheaper food and better customer service. I was hoping this place to turn out good but it was disappointing.
author: Berk G.

description:
I work at a high school four blocks from Cassava. I've been waiting to try this place out forever! The exterior is so bright and inviting beside all the other dark buildings on Balboa. I made a reservation for us on Resy and the table was set up when we got there! 

We had several different servers throughout our meal, but all were extremely nice and answered all our questions regarding the menu and my colleague's food allergies. In addition, they were able to substitute the cornbread for avocado at no upcharge!! 

I ordered the cornish hen with a fried egg. The egg was delicious, however I was not a huge fan of butter/oil mixture on the cornish hen. In addition, it came with a nicely portioned side salad with a light dressing and plums. The pumpkin cornbread was decent, however it wasn't great. The piece I got was extremely dry, I'm not sure if it was old because usually I find pumpkin dishes to be extremely moist. 

The best part of my meal was the sangria. WOW! It was a large glass of red sangria with ample fruit for $8.00. I would definitely order it again and suggest you do too! 

We took a look at the weekday lunch menu and it seemed to be almost the same dishes as the brunch menu. AKA not many choices and rather disappointing. I'll probably go back to this place because of proximity to school but not because amazing menu flavors choices. For food I would give this place 3 stars, but for service, drinks, and parking I gave it 4.
author: Whitney P.

description: Food was ok. Plates are small and the line was long. I won't come back, I will try to find another places around for brunch!
author: Carolina C.

description: We've visited this restaurant several times for both brunch and dinner, and we've always had a good experience. Cute restaurant, good food/cocktails, and good service. We'll be back again soon!
author: Tina L.

description:
I've been coming to Cassava since 2014 and I didn't review this place in fear of a crazy brunch line forming and making me have to "elbows out" to get a seat on the outside sidewalk or in side. Amazing fresh flowers and plants with open windows allowing for fresh air and comfortable seating. There's nothing like a Japanese breakfast   Or a duck confit salad with your plaid hipster shirt and almond latte in outer Richmond. And if it's a sunny day get ready to wait awhile. 

The price is definitely on the higher end with the "continental breakfast" including a croissant and bowl of yogurt for $10. Don't except to save money here. 

Solid food, solid ambiance and service and beautiful space. Price is on the higher end and with Marla's up the street you got to weigh your options.
author: Linda L.

description: Tasty food, albeit they were out of several things around 1pm. Parents: this place does not have amy high chairs, which makes it difficult for us to enjoy our food. My partner had a pork dish, the potatoes were exquisite. My fave was the dessert pictured.
author: Diana B.

description: This is my new favorite brunch place! I came for "weekday brunch" and had the yogurt and granola bowl, served with fresh fruit. It was drizzled with something that I believe was orange honey - very good! The avocado toast with egg and arugula was also delicious.
author: Lauren C.

description: After seeing all the good reviews , i decided to pick this place for brunch. The menu looked interesting and we were starving so the 3 of us ordered a few different entrees so that we could try different things along with a side of waffles. It was very disappointing, nothing was seasoned, the meat was dry and the waffles were undercooked. There was not onething we ordered, that we could say that we were satisfied about maybe only the service as they were nice.
author: Nisha A.

description: Love this cute spot in outer Richmond. Atmosphere and food were delish! Really appreciate their affordable prices!
author: Helen L.

description: I've had brunch at Cassava multiple times and it's one of my favorite places for brunch in San Francisco. I've been eating here for years and they're quite consistent with food quality. I love their meatball dish and their Japanese breakfast option the best. I usually stick to those two dishes. The Japanese breakfast is a good option for a brunch that isn't heavy. It feels relatively healthy and it's a nice change from usual brunch fare found in San Francisco. When I'm tired of pancakes, waffles, and eggs benedict, I go to Cassava for their Japanese breakfast.
author: Kathleen H.

description:
It's been a while since I enjoyed a visit to a restaurant so thoroughly. I'm saying 'visit' and not just 'meal' because the whole experiment at Cassava was a fantastic one: great company (well, that one's on me), friendly and attentive service, delicious food and nice ambience. 

My friend had recommended this place to me when I asked her for a recommendation in the Outer Richmond. My criteria were: good food, alcohol and affordable. It took her only a minute to text me back and recommend Cassava. And knowing that I can trust her taste, I didn't hesitate a minute and right away called to make a reservation for four that very same evening. 

Two of us four were early and so we sat outside drinking sangria: I like that they make sangria out of the wines that they don't finish at a given night. Go recycling! When all of us were present, we moved inside and started perusing the menu. Everything sounded delicious and we ended up ordering a few starters and mains to share. Honestly, I can't quite remember what we ate, but I recall that everything was very good. (You can tell I'm not a food critic ;-) 

Like I said in the beginning, what really stood out about our visit at Cassava was that it was such a wholesome experience where all parts were in sync. I'll definitely be back.
author: Uli B.

description:
We come to Cassava regularly since we moved to the neighborhood 3 years ago. It's a charm in Richmond District. We took our friends and family there, and we recommend it to all our guests. We never get disappointed. 
They have good service every time we went. Sometimes it would be slow for the food to get on the table during the weekends, but you can actually see the chef cooking in their kitchen. For us, it worths the waiting. We always enjoy the fresh flowers everywhere in their modern and beautiful restaurant. 

Our top picks will be:
*Breakfast croissant sandwich
*Roasted veggie bowl
*Japanese breakfast
*Slow-cooked short ribs with potatoes (The white and purple potatoes are the best!) 
*Curry meat ball
*Smoked trout 
*Veggie sandwich 
*Honey spiced latte 
*coffee!!
author: Yuan Z.

description:
Cassava, a cute little brunch spot in the Outer Richmond district, is decorated with petite floral table arrangements and baby blue and yellow painted walls with servers in striped aprons that add a welcoming, homey touch. They offer dinner as well, but I feel they're more popular for brunch/lunch.

Unless I've been eating too much junk food lately, my #1 rule when dining out is never order a salad as a main. As a side, sure, but never a main. However, Cassava's duck leg confit salad was simply delicious. The main reason for my ordering of this salad? The duck leg, and yes it was worth it.

Beautifully plated with bright green arugula and romaine lettuce, crisp radishes, pickled red onions of magenta hue, shaved grana padano, and crunchy fried quinoa, the salad was light, refreshing, and flavorful. Topped with a custardy soft shell poached egg and a tender and moist smokey duck leg, the flavors paired well together making a healthy weekend brunch meal.

I had the spiced honey latte alongside my salad, which was warming, mildly sweet, and delicious.

The brunch menu has a limited selection, relatively speaking compared to a typical brunch restaurant. Service was friendly, and they generously sat down my incomplete party (me being the tardy one). Also Cassava accepts reservations! Not many popular brunch eateries do that in SF.
author: Priscilla W.

description: Good taste compare with other restaurant around it. Feels homy, the chef take care the food so well. I love the sencha tea, light but delicious. Highly recommend fried egg sandwich, big enough for a man as well.
author: Faye L.

description: Top of the line sangrias by the pitcher, very unique spices on the pork shoulder, curry and paneer meatballs, in a clean exquisite setting near the ocean..... the best brunch I've had since living in San Francisco
author: Meagan M.

description:
Brunch review. 

Smoked trout (creme fraiche, harrisa, toast) - 3/5
Pomegranate pork ribs hash (potato, quinoa, egg, veg) - 5/5 - Very satisfying.
Waffle (eggs, bacon, berries, lemon ricotta) - 3/5
Black sesame pot de creme - 5/5

Overall, the rib hash and black sesame pot de creme is "as good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description: My fiancée and I love having breakfast here! Any place that serves Ritual Coffee is probably going to be a win. She likes the avocado toast and the mocha and I like the traditional Japanese breakfast. Surrounding area is usually beautiful for a nice walk and the service here is really friendly!
author: Johnathan H.

description:
Cute brunch spot + relaxed ambiance, except not your typical restaurant service style. My party was confused with the order process. 

I ordered polenta, which is greens, poached egg, and lots of cheese in a bowl, with some toast to dip. My toast was solid rock hard but it's just toast so oh well. 

Recommend the veggie bowl & polenta plate for clean eating. I guess they don't add hella extra flavors, which is good. Bbq ribs slid off the bone (yum), and salad is just alright.
author: Gloria L.

description: I'm giving this a 4 Star only because they need better ventilation. When it's cold and the doors are closed you walk out smelling like the kitchen. Other than that Cassava has been our go to eatery
author: Rachelle L.

description: The Cassava team hosted a beautiful, delicious, and fun brunch wedding reception for my husband and me last fall (I don't usually post, but I was just thinking about how great they were and thought I ought to share it with the yelp world).  Our planning was last minute and budget was tight, but co-owner/barista/does it all Yuka was amazing to work with in the planning stages and the she and team were all great on the day of.  Guests were really complementary of the food, especially the fried chicken (we're both vegetarians so didn't try it). This place has the perfect amount of whimsy, while still delivering a great, original meal and dining experience.
author: Andrea H.

description: Here is so clean and neat place. People are kind and I can feel all of the workers are caring the restaurant keep clean. Food was great and quantity was also enough! I like the big window on a wall, so the nature light source feels warm.
author: Changmin L.

description: Love this little place. The decor and ambiance is the familiar SF farm-to-table variety (unfinished wood tables, water served in bottles, very restrained, rustic, and "twee"). Food is reasonably priced for this sort of thing and very tasty. The meatball curry with perfectly cooked brown rice and poached egg is a great lunch that fills you full of warm nutrition and righteousness. The pork shoulder sandwich with tapenade, avocado, and fried egg is crazy good. Place is relaxed and bright with good people watching on this authentic, middle-class stretch of the Balboa corridor.
author: Aaron A.

description: Charming, cozy and delicious. The waiter started off our night with his kind, gentle manner. The salad was light, refreshing with the most unusual flavors of summer and was so good. It had a unique mixed greens and juicy peaches with some kind of crunch that was incredible. My husband had the halibut and I had the short ribs. Both equally flavorful and super tasty. The dessert was a chocolate cake with butterscotch and topped with fruit and fresh whip cream. Everything was top notch with flavor and presentation.
author: renee v.

description:
Aw, I really wanted to love Cassava. The lunch I had there didn't really do it for  me.

Came here on a weekday *very excited* to try this place out. Parking was surprisingly easy, interior was very cute/clean, service was fine.

I started out by having the Southern Fruit Tea, which was good but just....tea mixed with a bunch of types of juice. Very sweet, and not absurdly good enough that I'd outwardly recommend it. My entrée was the Randwich (turkey, avocado, poached egg, pesto, tomato, white cheddar sandwich). I could taste that everything was super fresh and high-quality, but yet again I just didn't LOVE it.

The low point of the meal was the bread pudding. It came out really dry and more like a muffin than anything else, I was really disappointed. 

As much as I was excited to try Cassava, it's not for me. In the future if I'm in the area, I may come back for dinner because I *really* want to give this place a chance,  but otherwise I was unimpressed.
author: Desiree S.

description:
3 stars for food, 5 stars for service, 5 stars for ambiance.

In all honesty, I was a little disappointed by my meal here.  Maybe my expectations were too high.  Maybe I should come back for dinner and see how it compares.  I came for brunch on a weekend, and the food was pretty forgettable, nothing special.  However, the service was so lovely and gracious, and the place was so charming, that it made up for it, enough for me to want to come back for dinner and give this place a second shot.
author: Emma A.

description: The food is wonderful and different!  As a southern girl, I am particular about my fried chicken; however, I love the special tempura touch to their breading.  The staff is always SO SWEET!  They were really kind to my dog and always accommodating when we need to change seating.  Yuka is an absolute doll!  There might be a wait, but it is worth it.  (Honestly, I would not suggest going anywhere near Ocean Beach if you are on a time crunch.)  Take your time and check this little gem of San Francisco's Richmond District out!
author: Christabelle P.

description: Was in the city from out of town and met up with a friend for a New Year's Day brunch. This little culinary nook is a gem of a restaurant. The food was phenomenal. I had the ribs hash and it was fall off the bone delicious. I'm not from the area but I have every intention of going back when I make it back up to NorCal.
author: Jose Patrick T.

description: I've been here twice now, food is great, drinks are great. I've yet to have a problem making a reservation here and did i mention the service is great as well. Small place but very pretty/blogger friendly. I loved sitting outside, especially since they have heat lamps.. but it gets busy and usually no seating outside so inside isn't a bad idea  p.s order the sangria yummm
author: Amena H.

description:
YUM! YUM! YUM! My Daughter suggested we have lunch here today and it was a wonderfully tasty selection.  My Daughter insisted we get the Veggie rice bowl and was she ever right on that one.  Here is what we had for lunch and it was amazing.  Not over salted as many restaurants tend to do. The flavors of the ingredients were allowed to ring through on their own.  I will definitely be back.

Baked  Burrata  and  and  Poached  Egg           Di  Stefano  burrata,  kuri  squash,  gigante  beans,  collard  greens,  pickled  red  onion,  toast 

Roasted  Veggie  Rice  Bowl                Delicata  squash,  zucchini,  collard  greens,  mushroom,  tomato,  onion,  cauliflower,     avocado,  broccoli,  basil  walnut  pesto                           add  soft  shell-­‐‑poached  egg  +  2   

Roasted  Pork  Shoulder  Sandwich               avocado,  fried  egg,  olive  tapenade,  market  greens,  tomatoes  on  deli  white  bread
author: Catania G.

description: Fresh and delicious food! The roasted veggie bowl was fantastic. Friendly and thoughtful service!
author: Liz W.

description: The wait list was 40min, but we got service with in 20min. The food and drinks were delicious and the stuff was very friendly
author: Anna Paula R.

description:
This place is so darn cute & tiny - like A cup tiny (sadly also in food portion) which made this review so very hard.

I was torn between a 3-4 star and opt for the 3 stars due to my recent visit. Overall so much potential, just not quite there yet.

Unique menu, somewhat fusion (little Japanese twist) - fresh, tasty, and healthy overall. 

Food Talk:

(1) Duck Confit Leg - came on a bed of salad, which was tasty and refreshing overall. Duck was tender and great the first time I had it, the 2nd time was sadly bland. The salad is consistently good - a unique house mix with fruit, cheese, & fried quinoa (great for texture!) & topped off with a poached egg.
 
(2) BBQ pork rib hash - was also tasty but very similar to the duck confit in dressings and all. The only difference was the pork and added potatoes. Although the BBQ pork itself was amazing, much better than the duck I'd say.

(3) Meatballs in curry (with rice) - this was such a disappointing dish. I've had great Japanese curry and maybe expected a little too much. But everything from the meatballs to the curry, lacked that "bang" flavor of taste overall. 

Drinks:

I'd say the drinks always end up being the highlight of this place - 

(1) Southern Fruit Tea - is something amazing! Perfectly and lightly sweetened, so refreshing!

(2) Honey Spiced Latte - frothy, warm, honey sweetened heaven! 

Given I have only come here for weekend brunch - I would def. come again if around the area, but prob wouldn't go out of the way for it.
author: Saleen L.

description:
The pork breakfast sandwich, is filling and quite delicious. 

The avocado was not ripe in my other friends dish and that was unacceptable. 

They are generous with the champagne in their mimosa's though.  

This small and idyllic spot deserves those patrons who have money.

Cassava doesn't seem to know it's identity, perhaps it can focus on one style of food.
author: Timothy P.

description: Came here for dinner and didn't stay because we were disappointed in the limited dinner menu, but most importantly, because they didn't have any high chairs for my toddler. Parents be warned, not a kid-friendly place. We had a great experience at Eat Americana instead.
author: Alexandra W.

description:
Thought the choices were a bit sparse for brunch...but the food delivered was very good. I was pleasantly surprised with the Japanese breakfast. It was very clean on the palate for breakfast. The soup was great for warming me up on a nippy San Francisco morning and the sides of various pickled vegetables, natto, and seaweed/lotus chips was really good with the Japanese rice (very glad it was not just regular white rice). We also went with a more traditional Croissant sandwich. It was a bit oily, but still very good.

I ordered a spice honey latte to go with my meal. It was definitely sweeter than how I typically take my caffeine, but I still thoroughly enjoyed it. Dad and I also shared a panna cotta (cause why not). Again, on the sweet side, wish it was delivered with fruits that were a little more tart rather than sugared strawberries. But the texture was just right as far as panna cotta goes.

They really should check who is allowed into the restaurant though. We had a vagabond wander in openly asking sitting patrons and the employees for free food and drinks. He also called out patrons like myself for "giving him paranoid looks". It was a bit of an uncomfortable situation, and to be honest, I wish the restaurant would have done more to escort him out sooner instead of letting him loiter in the common area touching the shared bottles of water, the glasses, possibly even the utensils. Just my two cents.
author: Elaine Y.

description: So yummy! Came in for breakfast today and the food came out really quick and was delicious. The Japanese breakfast was on point, and the smoked trout that came with it was great quality.
author: Hannah W.

description:
My worst nightmare is having to show up to brunch at least an hour early so I can grab a number and wait another 2 hours, so I'm inclined to give Cassava 5 stars alone for allowing reservations for weekend brunch.

Menu is on the smaller sides, and the brunch menu offered 7 options. If you are dining with indecisive people, this place is a blessing. Between the 4 of us, we ordered the Japanese breakfast ($13), Cornish game hen ($18), and pork shoulder sandwich ($15) x2. While the food was delicious, the portions were on the smaller side for the price. I understand that this is SF, but we've eaten brunch in SF plenty of times and this was probably the most expensive meal for the amount of food served. On the other hand, this most definitely isn't your typical diner breakfast food, so while on the more expensive side, I do appreciate the flavor and presentation of the dishes.

Parking is not too terrible - there's a school a block north from the restaurant, and there's usually ample street parking by there on the weekends. While Balboa St does have street parking, I'd suggest trying for the neighborhood street parking since Balboa always seems to be full. 

All in all, we would come back, but if patience and time isn't a factor, this wouldn't be my first option for brunch.
author: Emily Z.

description:
Great place! Delicious food and small prices. Itsy bitsy menu, everything made from scratch. The chiken and carrot soup was sooo good! The bread with honey butter is a must. 
We liked less the foie gras torchon though.
The waitress kind of tried to send us away because we were with kids - not nice. Parents like to have good food too sometimes.
author: Yana K.

description:
Food was definitely 5 stars! And loved that they took reservations for 2 of us just 30 mins before. This was a Monday but a holiday so they were serving brunch. Only downside is that it's a little pricey but worth it for once in a while.

Burrata appetizer was amazing and totally worth it (comes with bread and not too much squash).

Fried egg and avocado sandwich was also delicious (with and without the meat).
author: Pallavi K.

description:
*** In Short ***

Brunch. Cute. Tasty. Takes reservations. Need I really say more? Okay, fine: if they have it, be sure to try the Merguez lamb sausage.

*** In Depth ***

My friend, who absolutely loves Cassava, has been telling me she wants to take me here since, oh, my birthday last year? So, after more than a year, I decided to just go myself, with a different friend. Oops.

Anyway, I ordered their:

* Merguez Lamb Sausage - This was just divine. Flavorful? Yup. Rich? Oh, definitely. Greasy? Very much so. Delicious? Hells yeah. 

* Braised Short Rib "Hash" - Not so much a hash as it was a quinoa and potato bowl topped with a poached egg and fall off the bone tender rib deliciousness.

Cute little brunch spot, with a simple, but fantastic color scheme, and a combination of indoor and outdoor seating. Oh, and my favorite part? They take reservations. For brunch. WIN!

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - We were seated on the border of their in/outdoor seating, so I didn't pay too much attention to the interior seating arrangement. If memory serves me, I remember the place being a little on the smaller side, with the border seating actually being the best option. That said, my end of the table was on a slight decline backwards, which made for slightly awkward seating. 

Bathroom - Didn't try.
author: Johnny W.

description: Neighborhood favorite. Wonderful experience food and service every single time. We miss being able to walk over!
author: Emily S.

description:
Surprisingly tasty brunch spot in the Outer, I mean Outer reaches of SF. Perfect for your post-Lands End hike. 

We sat outside with our dog and toddler, and it was a little chilly but they do have industrial sized space heaters above the outdoor tables. 

Delicious Belgian Liege Waffle (oh man I could drown in that lemon ricotta) and spot on Japanese Breakfast. SO GOOD. Also very unique Burrata appetizer with veggies and perfect Toast. 

Delicious. Awesome. Will come again. 

Only piece of feedback - please get high chairs! Even just one would be great for whoever got to use it.
author: Aman H.

description:
Setting: weekday Brunch 10:30am

Menu: limited 

Ambiance: cute yet classic 

When I go to brunch, food wise, I really only have 2 criteria: I want to eat food that I can't necessarily make... OR I want to eat food that is better than what I can make at home. In this particular case, neither were an option. 

I ordered an open faced avocado sandwich (ie hipster talk for avo toast with an egg on it) 3 slices of "thick bacon" (literally regular bacon strips) and my gf ordered the continental breakfast (Costco Croissant, fruit + honey parfait,  and a poached egg. 

You know it's not going to be the best place when you literally start mathematically calculating how much that meal cost to prepare (ingredients wise) and fully disappointed because the reviews do not reflect the current menu. 

This review earns an additional star because this place was the first breakfast place where i ordered a drip coffee and it was actually really good. 

Will I recommend to a friend: no 

Will I be back: no
author: Jacob O.

description:
Pretty decent, but not sure I'd return again. I had this place bookmarked for awhile, so the SO and I decided to make the trek over for a Saturday brunch. We arrived around noon or so and had  20 minute wait which isn't so bad. They're very good about actually taking your phone number and then just texting you when they have the table ready so you can walk around to kill time!

It's a pretty small place, but has a chill hipster vibe with nice decor. The one qualm I did have with the space is that it's an open kitchen so it's literally right next to all the seats and as a result, the place smelled very kitcheny... so oil smells etc which is not so great. 

They have a pretty simple menu but everything on there is good. We got the smoked salmon appetizer, the SO got duck salad, and I had the traditional Japanese breakfast. Portion sizes are pretty large and filling -- the appetizer was basically the same size as the entree so you could have gotten two apps and probably been fine. Smoked salmon was good, it came with an arugula salad. The SO thought the duck was decent, and the Japanese breakfast was decent -- simple, albacore was pretty delicious, the side dishes were yummy, but it wasn't quite AMAZING. I've had better Japanese breakfasts at other places. 

Overall, it was a decent experience, but none of the food was that mindblowing. Good place for a one time brunch, but not quite outstanding enough that I'd want to come back. Service was good, price was $60 which is a little on the high side but what you get for a hipster brunch place I guess.

tldr; decent, but not exceptional cuisine. okay for brunch but I'm not dying to come back soon
author: Jasmine X.

description: Great menu especially for brunch, great staff/service, nice outdoor seating too! We shared the pork shoulder and chorizo bowls and they were both so fresh - and hot when they came out! Great little find in the outer Richmond area.
author: Tamar K.

description:
I love the food and ambiance! We had a delicious dinner and returned for amazing brunch. 

Highly recommend!
author: E. N.

description:
We came for brunch on a Sunday, and we called to make a reservation the night before so we didn't have to wait for a table when we came in at 1:30 PM since it was ready for us already.

Service:
The waitress checked on us pretty quickly (asking if we wanted any drinks, giving us water poured from an empty wine bottle) and our food was served to us pretty quickly.  She also checked on us to see if we needed anything.

Food:
+ Hibiscus glazed pork ribs hash ($17) - It comes with 2 pork ribs , cherry tomatoes, a poached egg, arugula, roasted potatoes, slivers of lemon?, and quinoa.  The ribs were, indeed, fall-off-the-bone tender and it had a kind of BBQ-ish flavor to it, which was pretty tasty.  Unfortunately, the poached egg wasn't runny when I poked it, which is how I like it, but mixing it together with the rest made it taste pretty good.
+ Liege Waffle with Eggs and Bacon ($14) - My friends ordered this and it was a waffle with some fruit, ricotta cheese, scrambled eggs with 2-3 slices of bacon on top of lettuce.  They seemed to enjoy it, and were able to request for the bacon to be extra crispy.

Overall: 3.75/5 stars rounded to be 4 stars

Would I come back? Probably, if I'm in the area, so that I could try the "Mr & Mrs Croque" Sandwich or the Meatballs in Curry with Rice Fried Egg, that I've seen in other reviews.
author: Gilda W.

description:
Ate here recently, overpriced and we were rudely treated by the hostess.

She gave us the worst seat in the house, even when there were other tables, and when we asked nicely for a change, got a flat "no."

Picked up a menu they had lying around and she snatched it out of my hands like I was a child.

Other than the hostess, the wait staff was fine.
author: A S.

description:
It is a great place for breakfast. You order your food at the counter and then find a seat where they will bring your order to you. I had an amazing continental breakfast here. It included yogurt with fruits and granola, a croissant, and a poached egg. The yogurt was very smooth. The blueberries, cherry, and banana were very fresh. The granola and sweet honey were great complements to the yogurt and fruit. The croissant was great: crisp and fluffy. The poached egg was cooked perfectly. As much as I enjoyed the food, I hated the latte I ordered. It was an abomination. I took two sips and put it on the table next to me. It was very disappointing since the pictures on Yelp looked great. I can only assume that the barista has not been trained up to speed yet, which happens and I could understand. In addition, I only drink specialty coffee. As a result, I will hate coffee if it is not great.

If you are visiting San Francisco and looking for recommendations, feel free to message me through Yelp and I can share my itinerary, which includes my Yelp reviews. The information for an electronic copy can also be found in the link via my Yelp profile.
author: Patrick W.

description:
A brunch spot in SF that takes reservations? Score!

I tried Cassava on a Sunday morning before Outsidelands... Parking situation was kind of hectic and we were late for our reservation. Luckily they were nice enough to hold our table for up to 30 minutes past our reservation time. We were so grateful!

This place is super cute inside! It gives off an intimate vibe with its simple, dainty decor and wooden tables. Service was fast and attentive.

We started off with a pitcher of tasty sangria which was an absolute steal! We each had about 3 full glasses between the 4 of us and only paid $6 each! The waitress initially filled each of our glasses upon bringing out the pitcher and ran out, so she returned with a completely full one and we got to keep it! ;)

Now when it comes to the food, this is where I was a bit disappointed. I ordered the Liege waffle, which I found to be just decent. The waffle was pretty good but did not wow me. The eggs and bacon were just average. My friend ordered their burrata, and it didn't turn out the way she had expected it to. I'm not quite sure what burrata is supposed to taste like, but I tried a bite of hers and thought it was just alright. Two of us ordered the curry meatballs, and the curry was pretty tasty! Unfortunately, however, the meatballs were pretty lackluster and bland. 

3 stars for the food, 5 for the service. I'd come back to try the honey spiced latte and the bourbon latte.
author: Cheryl N.

description: This place is adorable. Cute setup inside and they also have outdoor seating. They are dog friendly I love coming here when I have my dog with me.  The japanese breakfast is super legit. It's very authentic.  It comes with a perfectly soft poached egg. I usually don't like poached eggs but this one is amazing. The fish was excellent and you can even order a side of natto with it. Yum!  We also ordered the liege waffle. It came stacked with fruit and whipped cream super soft waffle not too sweet. I've been here a few times and will continue to come back whenever I want a traditional japanese breakfast. They are also kid friendly.
author: Krystal R.

description:
CASSAVA a place to get half the breakfast for twice the price, and they might be able to accommodate your request for a drink without ICE!    

Went for brunch with my mom, ordered the waffle, bacon scrambled eggs dish. Got undercooked bacon, guesstimate of about 1 and 1/3 of an egg, and half a waffle,  I notice it was a popular dish, and all potions were different.  Where is the consistency!  As stated bacon undercooked, (my dog did enjoy it).  The waffle, tiny,  was overdone with no where near enough toppings!  Like seriously 4 small cube of peach, a quarter of a strawberry, a half a teaspoon of berry preserves and mascarpone or other loose type cheese. Very dry!  And the 1 and 1/3 egg I had was literally drenched in oil, if fact all I tasted was the oil!   My mom asked for no ice in her drink and our servers response, I quote "um, I think we can accommodate that request".    My mom had the Japanese breakfast all she said was ok, pretty bland.  
I did notice servers in the kitchen area cooking and playing, perhaps that's the cause of the lack of consistent portions!
Needless to say if you want to spend too much on "meh" breakfast go ahead and head to cassava!
author: Nathan K.

description:
Brunch is amazing. The curry meatballs are so good I hardly ever try anything else. But today I sampled the cornish game hen with lemon verbena cornbread, and it was like chicken and waffles only better. I have to say this is one of the more unique brunches in SF with not your typical American breakfast fare. But plenty of egg dishes too if that's your thing.

Do read the info on the website about hours, reservation policy, etc. And do read the caveats on the menu to avoid surprises (their take on waffles specifically does not come with maple syrup, for example). Lots of useful information there, so don't say you didn't know!

I will have to go back again for the dinner tasting menu sometime soon. It's been too long. Fancy enough for a special occasion, but for the quality it's a much better value than some of those "other" tasting menu places. Or order a la carte if you just don't feel like cooking. Even if you don't live in outer Richmond, it's worth a trip! Close to several bike routes and Ocean Beach.
author: Sven E.

description: Great food in a small neighborhood spot. Run by a really sweet couple. Great service, great food, great place for breakfast. It's not on the menu but ask for the Rose honey tea...spectacular
author: Ursula Y.

description: Pretty nice place. My sandwich for lunch was great. It was chilly outside so heating was timely.
author: Liliia P.

description: This place was a nice surprise. The service and ambience was excellent. Dinner was spectacular, specifically the cornish game hen and the hangar steak. I would go back and recommend to others!
author: Anna C.

description:
In my travels, I often find places outside of California that offer dishes that celebrate local and seasonal ingredients, and I often wondered why a place that practically invented the concept of localvore and seasonal ingredients has lost its ways. It's like Alice Water revolution has come and gone and everywhere else has grab hold of the torch and ran to the finish line, leaving Californians behind. Northern Californian cuisine has been rest on its laurels for too long.

Cassava, is a rare exception. Its seasonality of ingredients is the keystone to a well planned and executed meal, its originality makes the place a stand out from all other places I've been to that serve New American food in the last few years in the city. 

There are also a few secrets that few knew. 

1. It offers Japanese breakfast, one of the few, if not the only place that offers such delectable outside of Japan or New York. Go on week days. But that's not all. 

2. It is dog friendly. I repeat, dog friendly. How many Richmond restaurants offer such an experience? Not many. 

3. It's known as a brunch place but really, the dinner is where it shines. Main dishes are incredibly well prepared with a lot of unusual yet local vegetables. Uni appetizer is a Americanized version of chawamushi, but it is a lot denser and more approachable (for Americans). No it does not use Hokkaido uni it uses Californian uni which goes back to its localvore concept. The Japanese influence in its cooking is unmistakable. But like most Japanese French masters, the restaurant's chef, which as I read, hails from Luce, one of my favorite brunch places, has acquired western techniques and ingredients. Thus, the Japanese influence is a hint, a light touch, a barely noticeable something something, but it enhanced the experience in ways you wish that you could see in more restaurants. Okay who am I kidding? Just about any Michelin restaurants you go to these days have Japanese cuisine influence in their dishes. this one may not come with a star (yet), it has mastered the technique. It's a real and rare bargain for this city.

Menu changes with the season. Its 4 course tasting menu is far approachable than most Michelin star restaurants in the bay area. The quality of food is also comparable with any number of Michelin star restaurant in and outside of the bay area. 

Go at 5 PM after a day at the GGP. Grab an outdoor patio seating with the heat lamp on so the sun is still shining and the fog has not come through the O.B. My favorite mains are the fish of the day / month / season and pork loins. Bring your fur baby.

In my opinion, it's only a matter of time before someone decides a place like this should be given at least one Michelin star, then you'd be fighting with everyone else to get a table reserved.
author: Victoria E.

description: Really, really good. I had the traditional Japanese breakfast and it was a great experience. My partner had the waffle and we both think it was one of the best we have ever had. I highly recommend the honey latte - still thinking about it days later! Service is wonderful!
author: Tiffany S.

description:
Holy moly -- Food that combines enticingly flavour, texture and umami with great attention to presentation and a fruit and/or grain flavour base to enhance the package... now lather. rinse, repeat four times and you have a stellar four-course tasting menu (highly recommended by me, by no means pushed on the diner).  

The staff is attentive and makes a point of ensuring your enjoyment (not the usual, "how's your food, hun?" gum-smacked query).  Beverage recommendations (pairing with the tasting sequence or stand-alone) is on-point.

The pork cheeks, when available, are a tasticular orgasmic item.  24 hour braising, another day in the sous-vide machine... yowza!  Check the online menu frequently...  things change... we've been twice now and it's now part of our dining regulars rotation.

It's clear the owners cultivate and take care of their regulars (notably, NOT to the detriment of newbies).  This is a neighborhood gem that deserves your attention.
author: Bruce B.

description:
I have been here several times already and am never disappointed with the friendly service and the food. I've tried the pork shoulder, the liege waffles, and the rillettes. All had the perfect balance of flavor and are worth it. I can't wait to come again! 

Sangria and their fresh squeezed juices are great too :)
author: Raquel L.

description:
Possibly one of the best brunches I've had in San Francisco! I love their Asian-inspired dishes. From meatball curry to a Japanese breakfast, they had various one-of-a-kind options.

Will definitely be back...best part, there didn't seem to be any long lines either. Keep this a secret gem!
author: Katherine L.

description: What a peaceful neighborhood this spot is in. I ubered in from downtown SF for the delish Japanese Breakfast I saw on their Instagram. It was everything I hoped for! The cheerful man that took our order 4/19/17 suggested the Pear Carrot drink which was delicious!! The service was excellent, the ambiance was very laid back and the food delicious!!
author: Cecilia D.

description:
A true gem not just in San Francisco, but one of my favorite restaurants in all of America! Have had brunch here twice and dinner twice - all 4 meals have been absolutely top flight quality. The Japanese breakfast is a lovely and creative brunch option, and the Liege waffle is made so well that you don't even miss the syrup! And the coffee is always great! For dinner, I always go with the 4 course tasting menu - I want to taste as much of their delicious food as I can and at the price it is a very fair deal!

The menu has consistently great options across the board. While the quality food speaks for itself, what stands out to me the most is that Kris & Yuka simply get it. They know what they are as a restaurant and excel at it. On top of that, its two wonderful people who truly value each and every person that walks through their door. I'm a New York native now living in North Carolina and when I travel to San Francisco I ALWAYS make it a point to eat here. Yuka always greets me by name and with a smile, as Kris diligently works in the kitchen and yet still makes it a point to say hello and welcome me back. Sure there's plenty of restaurants with great food but they are also ones where you're simply a number, just another faceless paying patron. At Cassava, you matter. They make you feel like family. 

The space inside is very well done, with cleverly thought out usages of space and some outside dining tables as well. The menu is never overdone or over complicated and it's diversified enough to cater to just about anyone. The service always amiable and attentive. Whether it's dinner, or brunch or even a pop in for lunch - Cassava has it all. Do yourself a favor and come enjoy a terrific meal and a great experience and rest assured you'll be valued by the entire Cassava team.
author: Doug R.

description:
Disappointing. 
I came visit from LA to try this place, had a very high expectation in mind.
Apparently they don't know how to cook eggs properly: too sweet and too chunky. And the Japanese style breakfast was also a big bummer...
author: Sarah H.

description:
Came here for dinner.

Food and Service are both great here although I think the timing between dishes can use a little more work.  Felt like we waited over 30 minutes between our appetizers and entree - and the restaurant wasn't even 100% full at that point.  

I also wish their portions are bigger.  The tomato and pear salad was tasty but I think there were only about 5-6 pieces in there. By the time you get your palate going to taste the flavors, the dish is all gone.  The Hanger steak was cooked to perfection and I have nothing bad to say about this dish!   

Did not get dessert because there was nothing that interested us.
author: Jannie Q.

description: Fresh clean flavors. Had brunch and dinner here and all things were a hit. Loved every bite. Servers not so sugary but not necessarily bad. Ambiance is a chill neighborhood vibe. Overall it's worth the haul.
author: Tatum T.

description:
First time we came here the rib hash was amazing.

Second time that was no longer on the menu and other dishes were extremely disappointing.

Korean Chorizo Hash Bowl ($17) - Sausage was so dry it was falling apart, no fat or flavoring basically mush. Other hash ingredients were fresh, but also without salt or flavor.

Japanese Breakfast ($13) - Menu described with miso cod, but came with salmon (not mentioned by the staff at all) that tasted not fresh and fishy.

A 19% gratuity was also added automatically for our party of 3. I consider that high considering they only refilled our water and switched our utensils one time. The prices should reflect great food and service, but we got neither.
author: Brendan C.

description: Cassava is a neighborhood gem! Their Japanese breakfast is wonderful, and their sandwiches and salads are delicious! The owners and employees are impeccable - friendly and warm. I miss it because I don't work down the street anymore! But I have come in for a weekend brunch! Always a treat.
author: Ravi C.

description:
What a HUGE disappointment.

Ordered: Japanese Breakfast
                 Smoked trout w toast
                Desert Japanese yam creme brulee

All I'm going to say is:
-They made us wait 10 minutes for a table even when we had reservations AND there were 2 empty tables!  We saw 3 girls walk in and got a table. B*@#!
-Pricey for TINY portions
-Shell in my poached egg from Japanese breakfast tray
-Miso soup in Japanese breakfast had brussel sprouts? WTF?!  If it was good, than that'll be acceptable.
-The pickled bean srouts and cucumber was Butt salty
-Okay tasting food, NOTHING special
-Smoked trout w toast nothing special.  
-Only upside was the creme brulee
-Service was SUBPAR.  The girl was barely there, but was quick with our bill.  

NEVER EVERY again.. MUY MUY MALO
author: Katrina N.

description:
Cassava is obviously a labor of love of the husband and wife team who own and run the place.  What that meant to me was a heartfelt welcome on my arrival for a recent dinner. Service is a team effort and good; and given the very generous portion sizes the pricing is fair.  With a tweak here and there the mostly very good food could be stellar.  

Carrot-lemon verbena soup came with a dijon creme fraiche and rye croutons.  The dijon creme fraiche was superlative but the nicely thick soup barely tasted of carrot.  But the creme fraiche elevated what would have been a disappointment into an interesting plate of food.

A salad of Di Stefano burrata with sunflower sprouts, fuji apple, apple cinnamon butter and two immense slices of try toast was wonderful.  The ample serving of burrata was rich and 
creamy, the fuji apple lent some astringency to the salad, and the cinnamon butter was spectacular, something to be bottled for take-out.

A main of pork belly and  polenta came with smashed english peas, and bok choy.  The pork belly may have been a bit under seasoned for most people, but not for me as I am salt restricted.  The polenta, copious portion of smashed peas, and utterly fresh bok choy made this a complete plate of food.

Cassava is worth the slog (for me) to the outer richmond.
author: David D.

description: Our polenta was completely burnt and bland af.  The half game hen portion was not large enough.  Very cramped.  Our service was sparce, but the water guy was on it at least.
author: Smiley S.

description:
We came here for the Japanese breakfast it was something that I've always wanted to try. Everything was exactly as I hoped. Rice, salmon, soup, pickle veggies. 

Would love to come back
author: Tony T.

description:
It's so very good!  The food was delicious, and the service was excellent! In fact, we ordered our coffees before we even sat down!  

It was our first visit.  We have passed by Cassava many times, but it always looked so crowded, so we always thought, "next time."  But yesterday, we were able to get reservations, so we rushed over there!

Cassava is a super-cute small restaurant!  It is decorated in hues of light blues and yellows, and it looks amazing! I got the "Mr  &  Mrs  Croque"  Sandwich.  Yum.  It was huge, and I could not finish it.  My hubs got the Pomegranate Glazed  Barbeque  Pork  Ribs "Hash."  Now, his breakfast looked GOOD.  I stuck my fork into his dish for a big scoop.  YUM.  

We sat next to regulars who noticed that I was checking out their waffles.  It looked so good that I almost took a photo of their brunch. LOL.  But, they were really nice, and they said the waffle here is the best in the City.  That Cassava made the Liège Waffle special.  

Too bad I could not order 2 breakfast dishes! I can't wait until I go back.  I already loved my brunch, and now I find out that the Liège Waffle is even "better?"  I am definitely returning, and I will be ordering the Liège Waffle.  I can't wait until next time!
author: Charissa N.

description:
Wanted to try something new last night for SF Restaurant Week and found this self described "California cuisine" place and wanted to try it out.  We snatched their last Saturday night reservation on Open Table! When we walked in 30 min early,  we immediately felt a great vibe: we were welcomed warmly by the host and the Co owner/beverage manager who accommodated a request to sit earlier. They smiled and didn't make us feel like a nuisance for asking. We both had the 4 course tasting menu, including a few extras to complete our meal. They worked as a team, providing wonderful and colorful plates that would satisfy any palate.

Pros:  excellent salmon dish...that black rice with the squash puree was amaze balls! EXCELLENT table service by all that approached our table. The beverage manager Co owner was extremely warm and friendly...so down to earth; everyone who served knew the dish they were bringing out. The plating was phenomenal and just put together well... aesthetically pleasing to the eye because the moment you see the dish in front of you,  you have to stop yourself from going animalistic by using hands and teeth to feed your stomach (had a white jacket on, I needed to take it easy and use the knife and fork). Ceramic plates are the way to go. They make an EXCELLENT cappuccino and even asked what kind of milk I'd like to take it with (whaaaaat? First time a restaurant has ever asked me! Ritual Coffee too!) Have I said EXCELLENT too many times? !? Well,  just handle it. 

Con: Maybe it isn't such a con but the apple crumble was a tad too sweet for my taste. The apple slices themselves were sweet enough coupled with the singular baby scoop of ice cream/whipped cream (couldn't tell because it was so hot), so I felt the chocolate crumbles on top pushed it over the edge for me.  If you end up choosing this dessert,  make sure to tell them ahead of time because it will take 15 min to make ( says so in the menu). 

The place only seats 40 max but I did enjoy the intimate seating. Make a reservation! Cassava has given me more reason to drive the 40 miles north into Outer Richmond. I'll be back for brunch and bringing friends!
author: Liz Z.

description:
Charming joint, great service, but food and coffee were only ok. Nothing exceptional to trek back out here for it. 
We ordered:
-Cappuccino - decent but a lil too much milk
-Bourbon vanilla latte - again..too much milk and doesn't taste like coffee. More like milk, vanilla and splashed of bourbon
-Liege waffles with scramble eggs and bacon - portion is small for $14. Waffle was good but plate came with 1 small piece
-Cassava's continental breakfast - the yoghurt was a bit runny, barely any granolas and croissant was dry.
author: Hanah P.

description: I absolutely love this place; casual and approachable, but definitely high-end culinary treat that you simply must eat at when hungry in this area. The owners are extremely warm and friendly, the service is unmatched. Still, the real reason for writing this review is one dish that I am most impressed with -- the black cod entree is quite simply the best fish I have ever eaten, hands down. It puts offerings from Michelin rated restaurants to shame, and is my go-to over anything else (and I am a pretty die-hard steak lover; not to dissuade you from their excellent hangar steak). Don't miss it.
author: Daryll H.

description: Came here for brunch with a friend. Only thought the place was okay because it's quite expensive for small portions. Most menu items didn't interest or excite me. Service wasn't the best--had to remind the server a few times for things like silverware or water.
author: Alison M.

description: Amazing. The absolute best Cornish Game Hen I've ever had in my life. Great atmosphere, cute as a button. Yummy drinks and wine. What more could you want?
author: Lucas R.

description:
It's been a few hours since I've left this spot and I'm still thinking about it. I had probably one of the best brunch meals in recent memory. The service was amazing and the food was absolutely delicious. I will say that it's on the pricy side- about 20 bucks a person- but so worth it.

The waffles were made to perfection and were crisp. The fruits that came with them were fresh and as tasty as you could ever imagine. I never felt like I needed syrup for the waffles- fruits did the trick alone. Do not even get me starred on the bacon- it was probably the best I've ever tasted.

The ambiance is also awesome here. The place itself was casual, yet the experience is not- the menu has great variety and the people who work here love their jobs. The casual feeling turns to one that makes you feel like you're at a fancier place, because the people here really take care of you to make sure you're enjoying you time.

Overall, I can see this become a monthly spot for me. The balance of great food, nice people and the location makes this the perfect place to go out for breakfast or dinner (which I'm hearing rave reviews about as well). Check Cassava out!
author: Alex B.

description:
Service trumps the quality of the food in my opinion. With poor service comes a poor dining experience and in return poor food. At cassava, the service was unfortunately below average for me. We ordered a Mr. And Mrs. Croque (along with other items I will not be mentioning here) and were fooled by the pics on yelp. We anticipated it to come on a crossaint sandwich, but instead it came on two grilled slices of white bread. My mother is extremely picky with her food and specifically came here for the crossaint sandwich so we asked if we could get a crossaint in the side. The lady behind the counter was quick to answer that there was an extra charge for the crossaint. We answered with a "no problem." What is a couple extra dollars if it makes your overall experience a better one? When the crossaint came we asked if there was any way they could transfer the contents of the original sandwich to the crossaint and the lady said that it would take about 10 minutes. We already waited about 25 minutes for our food and our tummies didn't want to permit us another 10 minutes so we picked up the knife and went at it ourselves. The lady then went onto comment why we didn't want to try the original slices of white bread with the sandwich because it tasted really good. She said this in a rude, condescending manner as if we didn't know how we liked our sandwich to be. If we didn't know how we liked our sandwich to be, we wouldn't have ordered a crossaint on the side to begin with. This was a small problem that could've easily been fixed by spending a couple extra dollars, but because the lady had to throw in her rude comments after her inability to help us, this review had to be written.
18% gratuity is included in the bill. Were they deserving of this 18%? Probably not. I just hope it goes more to the cook, hostess, and waiter that all played a team effort in this restaurant. There are better places in the city that will serve brunch, so go do yourself a favor and skip this spot. You'll have more pleasant experiences and food elsewhere.
author: Amy T.

description:
We had a reservations for this place, thank god because otherwise the wait was around 30 minutes to an hour for a typical weekend brunch. 

All in all, not impressed. The place is on the pricey side for brunch. I got the potato hash. First of all, this wasn't a hash since the potato was basically baked potatoes in chunks. Then the pork was extremely dry. Everything on the plate was under seasoned. My girlfriend got the waffle plate. The waffle was really thick and super bready/doughy. Not sure how to describe it but we weren't fans.

We probably won't be coming back since there are sooo many other good brunch places in the area. Nothing about this place stood out, and we definitely felt that it wasn't worth the cost.
author: Jinyan C.

description:
Have been here several times for brunch and have consistently had good food and service. Lots of natural light, very cheerfully decorated, and even heat lamps for the outside tables for chillier days!

Highly recommend the Japanese breakfast, Meatballs and Curry, or Korean chorizo hash. Although some of the dishes sounded like they should be very heavy (i.e. chorizo, meatballs, pork shoulder, etc.), the seasoning was actually very restrained and the proteins are lean without being dry. The menu is an eclectic mix of classic brunch and some Asian inspired dishes which keeps things interesting. Also very good coffee and brunch libations. 

The service here is also on point and extremely friendly. Although the wait wasn't bad at all for noon on a Saturday, had no idea that you could make reservations online and will do so in the future.
author: Tina G.

description: My fiancé and I live in the outer sunset and we LOVE having Cassava close by! It is our go to spot for a nice evening out near our neighborhood, always delicious, seasonal, fresh food and tasty wine. We often come here for brunch as well, there are tables outside perfect for sunny days on the weekend. Dinner tonight was delicious, I highly recommend eating here and supporting a small, local restaurant. Its like having a mini Nopa nearby.
author: Emily B.

description:
Came here during the week to try out the Japanese breakfast (served until 11:30am weekdays). I don't know what it's like on the weekend but on a rainy Friday it was very mellow and quiet with just a few other tables occupied by a few locals, a couple of tourists, and a grandma/mother/baby family. 

The Japanese breakfast came with koshihikari rice, a few dishes of pickled vegetables, a sous-vide egg suspended in dashi broth, miso soup with seasonal root vegetables, and slices of pickled radishes. Natto available by request - which I did but would caution against it unless you're an adventurous eater. It was all very nice and I enjoyed having a Japanese breakfast in SF but wish there were more small dishes and less rice. Though the rice was good it's pretty much the mainstay of the breakfast dish. Something like fried/tinned fish would have been nice - something other than the $3 smoked trout chunks. Or some legumes to round out the protein. 

It's just filling enough and if you're feeling fancy you can splurge on some pastries.
author: Jean K.

description: This place was just mediocre. Friendly service but disappointing food. The menu looked amazing, everything looked delicious and I had a hard time deciding what to order. That's where the love affair ended. Our table ordered the baked burrata with summer corn served with toast to start. It looked amazing but was bland. Normally I would have scooped up every last bit of burrata, but I was so underwhelmed that I left the last couple spoonfuls behind. I ordered the Korean chorizo hash bowl which was also super bland. My friends ordered the Japanese breakfast and the Cornish game hen & cornbread. Unfortunately the waitress misheard our order and we got 2 orders of the bland Korean chorizo. Cute place and I like that they take reservations, but the food doesn't warrant a return visit.
author: shatier x.

description: Moved two blocks away 2yrs. ago. but just started to use yelp to check in here a couple of times. Hands down CASSAVA is my favourite fine dining experience on Balboa (Outer Richmond District), from a beautiful breakfast, lovely lunches to die for dinners. All local and organic whenever possible! I can taste the delicious difference. Service is great here but the food is even better! Worth the drive from where ever you are. Please $UPPORT YOUR LOCAL SF BU$INE$$E$!
author: Joe G.

description:
This place is very cute and sort of classy, so it's definitely a nice date place. Imagine going to a little French bistro, and you'll get the vibe of this place.

They serve water in recycled wine bottles and mason jars, they actually have linen napkins, a small pot of plants to decor the table, and their menu has a French touch to it. Extremely charming.

It is a nice option to have a special brunch. But be ready to sit on the outdoor tables, since the place is quite small and popular.

So far, I have tried the liege waffles (an amazing dish, very fulfilling, and really yummy) and the "mr. & ms croque", which I think it's a new interpretation of the croque monsieur and croque madame you can eat in France. Both were delicious.

People say the meatballs are amazing. Since they were out of it when I was there, I will definitely have to come back to try it.
author: Andréia S.

description:
Came here for lunch after a walk at Land's End. My friends and I ordered the liege waffle with maple ricotta ($14) and the japanese breakfast ($13).

The liege waffle was so good. It was caked with the kind of crispy sweet texture on the outside and chewy/cake-y on the inside. SO GOOD with the maple sauce and ricotta. I also tried some of the bacon - it was thick sliced and CRISPY!! Props for a perfectly prepared bacon.

The japanese breakfast is an assorted platter of small dishes - some seared albacore, miso soup, seaweed, flavoured bean sprouts, poached egg, and natto. The natto is available by request since it's a very unique flavour and usually only an acquired taste. I personally did not like the natto...too strong of a smell for me. The other items were all pretty good and refreshing for a light lunch. I wanted to note that all of the items (excluding the seared albacore) would probably be offered for free at hotels in Japan. They're all very basic and traditional breakfast items. However, obviously Cassava is in SF so the prices reflect that.
author: Theresa L.

description: great spot with amazing food and even better customer service , had the croissant breakfast sandwich and couldn't be any more pleased. Will definitely be back, love the versatility of the menu
author: Jeff M.

description:
Yet another place that's been in my Bookmarks for forever. Made reservations the night before for 12:15 p.m. on Sunday, which is perfect lunchtime (aka you get to sleep in a little). 

It took a while before someone came to take our order, but it was also a packed house/super busy. It seemed like they were slow to get to everyone, so *shrug* But other than that, great and friendly service!

Price-wise, I think it's pretty reasonable for brunch...if you just order entrees. Our tab came out to be $50 for 3 items O= Drinks are a bit pricey; I think one of the juices (might be their signature one) is $4. 

NOTE: Come early to find parking!! 

Baked Burrata with Summer Corn - SO GOOD. I love burrata and I love corn, so when I saw this I HAD to order it. I didn't care much for the poached egg that came with it, but everything else was delicious! The burrata, corn, basil pesto and arugula were just perfection. The dish also comes with bread. What more can you ask for?! The only thing is that there's quite a bit of oil at the bottom of the bowl =/ 
Japanese Breakfast - The smoked trout was so yummy! A tinyyyyy bit dry, but such a nice smokiness to it. I loved the pickled bean sprouts -- it was also a bit spicy (I think it was chili oil), and so good. The poached egg was good, but very simple and plain in flavor. The miso soup was very interesting; kale, daikon slices, corn and mushroom. It's not as salty as the miso soup you typically get at Japanese restaurants, which was nice.
Liege Waffles with Scrambled Eggs, Bacon - The bf got this and enjoyed it. I think he didn't enjoy it as much because he's not used to waffles without syrup.
Side of potatoes - The bf asked the server if they had anything off-menu for potatoes, and he said he could get something for us. We got a nice plateful of fried/roasted rainbow potatoes. They were amazing crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. I hate home fries because they're always just kinda soggy/mushy, but the potatoes were so good!

Hope to come by and try their dinner menu soon!
author: Doris K.

description:
We came here for SF restaurant week. The $2 difference in price was a little laughable. 

Service was definitely great, and felt high end, although the restaurant has a more casual feel.

Food
salad- artistically displayed, but really like two pieces of carrots, some beets and oranges.
salmon- cooked nicely, average.but the crispy rice was really good.
short rib?- very very tender, pretty yummy, 
panna cotta- favorite part of the night! yum

also ordered a glass of wine, and the pour is not generous. 

overall we were full, food was solid. I want to come back for brunch which is what I hear they are better known for. A lot of new american restaurants just do salmon and short rib dishes so  often (maybe because its easy?) so I am not too impressed.But I suppose it is a decent price for 40-42$ prefixe!
author: Christine M.

description:
This place is always packed no matter what time of day you stop by (they serve meals throughout the day, from breakfast - dinner). There's a good reason for it. I've been here a couple of times for brunch and was never disappointed. Stellar service, cute ambiance and top quality food. I'm not a foodie but can tell when the chef cooks with his heart. The exquisite details and the fresh ingredients that go into each dish are well thought out and nicely presented. 

Today I ordered the Duck Leg Confit Salad and the Mister ordered Pomegranate Glazed Barbeque Pork Ribs. Duck leg was juicy and tender sitting on a bed of mixed greens, cheese and nuts. The ribs were bursting with flavor with a good balance of the potatoes and quinoa. And then their soft poached eggs, cooked to perfection, was a great addition to both dishes. 

It's on the pricier side, but food and service make up for it. I am happy to have this gem in our neighborhood. Worth every star!
author: Em T.

description:
I came here on a Sunday afternoon & to our surprise, there was a 40 minute wait for the indoor tables, but none for the outdoor - which we didn't mind since it wasn't too cold & they have heaters over each table!

I opened up the menu & immediately drawn to ordering the Japanese breakfast. I have no idea what it was - but I knew I wanted to try it vs the rest of their American options.

It comes with rice, salmon, fermented beans, seaweed, some sort of pickled vegetable, miso soup, & nato (poached egg & soy sauce) - upon request. 

I've had nato before so I was pretty familiar with the taste already - but it's really hard to explain - definitely not for everyone but if you've never had it, you should definitely try! You mix in the fermented beans with the egg and eat with some rice. I really enjoyed it - pretty filling too since its mainly rice.

Will definitely be back to try the rest of their brunch options!
author: Carrie L.

description:
Cassava is such a cute, lovely brunch spot!

I love going to Cassava when I want to have a nice weekend brunch, but do not want to face the ridiculous mobs of people at every brunch spot in the city. I've been here a few times already, and not once have I had to wait long (or at all) for a table. The ambiance here is so cute - very "hipster," but not annoyingly so. I can't believe I'm saying this, but it's so "Instagram-able"! The service is so friendly, too. With just the service and ambiance alone, you can't help but feel happy when you're in Cassava.

I find the food to be delicious, fresh, and unique. The first time I went, I had the liege waffle, which came with scrambled eggs and bacon. It was so hearty and satisfying. Most recently, I had the pork "hash" that blew my mind. I definitely didn't expect my hash to come out the way it did (eggs/ribs/quinoa), but the moment I tasted it, I had no complaints whatsoever. The pork was so tender and the combination of flavors was something I didn't expect - so delicious!

If I had one critique, it might be that the service is a little slower than other places, but it's not something I minded. With beautiful ambiance, good company, and delicious lattes (try the spiced honey!), the wait for your food doesn't end up feeling very long at all.

Overall, Cassava is a wonderful place to go for weekend brunch with friends, especially on a beautiful San Francisco day. I highly recommend it and I can't wait to go back!
author: Alyssa T.

description: I enjoyed this place and perhaps because I found the service excellence and I had good company to enjoy my meal. I ordered the Japanese breakfast which seemed interesting and unique to me I thought I would try it. My friend ordered the same thing and she had recommended it. We sat outside and there were heaters which definitely made it a little more enjoyable since it was chilly. Service was prompt and friendly. The Japanese breakfast consists of a couple little items combined on one plate. One includes their version of a miso soup that's kind of nontraditional (well, I've never been to Japan so perhaps this is real miso), a piece of cooked fish over some pickles, a side of rice, a poached egg and I think vinegar, and what appeared to be kimchi beans sprouts. People might have some qualms about eating fish for breakfast, but I don't mind and I thought the fish was cooked well but I didn't necessarily like it with the pickles, although I liked them separately. I didn't really care for the miso soup or their version of it  and I wished it was more savory and flavorful. But mixing the eggs, rice, and fish was excellent. They also have a really interesting menagerie of items on their menu that would be worth trying and going back for. Went on a Sunday morning around 1130 and it wasn't too crowded  but I hear it can get really crazy in the wait very long.  Parking wasn't too bad because it's in the outer Richmond, but definitely keep in mind you might have to park three or four blocks away.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Outstanding food and superior service. It's not cheap, but you probably shouldn't expect anything cheap in this part of SF. Fun vibe too. But you need to get there early. The place fills up fast.
author: Anil S.

description:
Craving something light and delicious? this is your place! 

AMBIANCE
Super cute shabby chic style neighborhood restaurant. From the outside, it looks small but once you step inside, it's a lot bigger than it looks. They offer two types of seatings: table & bar.
