I prefer to sit at the bar. It's small but the set up is spaciously done so you feel pretty comfortable and roomy. Love their wood tables mixed with metal chairs. It feels as if you're at your friends house getting ready to have brunch. 

FOOD
I ordered their liége waffle with scrambled eggs, bacon and it was DELICIOUS! Waffle was crispy outside, chewy inside. It also had the perfect amount of sweetness in the batter that paired well with the mixed fruit. Bacon had the right amount of thickness and scrambled egg was soft and creamy! My friend ordered their japanese breakfast and meatballs in curry with rice + fried egg. Japanese breakfast was plated beautifully. It was light, clean and fresh. Meatballs in curry sauce topped with fried egg was killer good! Curry was not too salty and the meatballs were juicy and tender. Adding rice to the sauce gave it a nice balance. 

OVERALL
Service was great. Very tentative but not over bearing! There could be a bit of a wait so be patient.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
We had an extremely positive experience at Cassava. We booked a private event here for a Christmas work party. Prior to the event, communication with the owners, Yuka and Chris, was smooth and seamless. Chris worked with us to accommodate dietary needs (gluten and dairy) and food preferences. 

On the night of the party, the causal daytime cafe feel was dressed up into a restaurant with refined ambience. The food, as always, was excellent. Highlights include the beef cheeks, herring, apple cobbler, bread pudding, cocktails, and wine pairing. The service was on point, attentive but not intrusive. Everyone was very professional yet warm and gracious. 

I highly recommend this restaurant for private events. The personal attention and the quality of the food made this event very memorable for us and our guests.
author: Kar Y.

description:
I've been wanting to come here for a while but they are always so busy (a great sign).
The liege waffles are amazing.  Especially the berry sauce they put on top.  Omg so good.  Mochas are awesome too!  Good, warm service.
author: Chelsea D.

description:
What a cute spot!  Has an almost cottage-y feel, with the light blue walls and small vases with flowers on the table.  We went here for breakfast before hitting up the Sutro Baths (which I highly recommend if you haven't gone before).  

I had their vegetarian quiche of the the day; 'twas lovely.  It didn't taste too egg-y, and the crust to filling ratio was right.  I'll say this about the dessert I got here too, it melts in your mouth.

I also tried the spiced honey latte--nice cup and does the job.  The server forgot about it, but she quickly went back to make it and apologized for the wait when I reminded her about it.  

To finish off my meal, I had to try the Madagascar vanilla panna cotta.  Again, dissolves right in your mouth.  It was lightly sweet and creamy, served with fresh fruit.  The presentation made it almost too pretty to eat.

Portions aren't the biggest, but for me it was just the right size for a satisfying start to my morning trek in the city.  Overall I like how simple the inside looks, yet you get a solid and tasty meal for a great price in SF.  I must go back to try the Japanese breakfast and the liege waffle with maple ricotta--sounds yum!
author: Emmeline C.

description: Yum! Great brunch and dinner. Very fresh and interesting food. They have a good wine and cider list too.
author: Roz B.

description:
Cassava is well off the beaten track if you're already from the West Bay and your bubble of consciousness is limited severely to the neighborhoods east of Twin Peaks. Nevertheless, it's worth a visit. You'll be welcomed with exceptionally warm service, and the quality of what you'll get, given the prices, won't disappoint either.

Unlike Western breakfasts full of eggs, meats, and other stuff that's guaranteed to bust your arteries, Cassava's Japanese Breakfast just feels so... good for you. All the items and ingredients are authentic, whether the rice, miso soup, picked vegetables, house-cured ocean trout gravlax, or a soft poached egg served in broth. Quite a nourishing breakfast overall. I can't wait to try more of their offerings when I'm in the area again.
author: Vincent L.

description: Delicious food, was actually surprised by how simple and fresh it was and how great it tasted. The burrata is an absolute must during brunch.
author: A K.

description:
Hipster brunch exists in Outer Richmond! Complete with wooden tables, latte art, and mason jars. Who knew? 

We shared their spiced honey latte before ordering and it was insanely good. Best latte I've ever had. I opted for the leige waffle with a poached egg (instead of scrambled) and bacon. The leige waffle was topped with fresh berries and some type of cream. I either forgot or didn't know what it was, but it was delicious. The waffle was made perfectly - not too sweet, not too soft. I love dishes with sweet and savory portions because I have a huge sweet tooth. The poached egg was served on a bed of arugula - almost perfect, but the whites of the egg were too runny. The bacon also came on top of greens - good, but far from mind-blowing. My bf ordered the pork rib hash and loved it. I would not mind coming back for brunch again someday.
author: Stephanie G.

description:
Been here a good handful of times.  Love their latte and mocha.  Sooo saaad they dont do to go coffee :(

- Smoked Chinook Salmon Belly: mustard greens, crème fraiche, toast...this was a total thumbs up for me. 

- Pomegranate Glazed Barbeque Pork Ribs "Hash": toasted farm potatoes, quinoa, soft shell-poached egg, mustard greens, arugula, cherry tomatoes...the meat was totally fall off the bone!

- Liège Waffle with Scrambled Eggs, Bacon: berries, house preserve, maple lemon ricotta, powdered sugar (waffle is made with pearl sugar, no syrup served together)...i havent met a waffle i didnt like :D but my friend said the sweetness was a bit odd but must be cuz of the sugar they use.

Wanna try dinner fo sho!
author: she q.

description:
Cassava is tops! They have a beautiful space, delicious food, knowledgeable wine service, and excellent service.  We had the tasting menu with drink pairing and were pleased with each course. 
This neighborhood gem is worth a trip to the Richmond!
author: Jen F.

description:
This place has excellent cuisine. The menu is a bit small and they try reasonably hard to sell you wine at 50% off on Wednesdays. The service is reasonably good, and they take care of you pretty well. They go for a high-end stuck-up vibe which doesn't really match the open-kitchen cheap-chair ambience. I say this because they have to make it clear that they are providing an exception for you when their menu says that the entire table must order the 4 course meal, or none. On the good side of the high-end service, is that they do clean the table after courses, and help you pour water when needed.

For food, we got the 4 course meal + a main course of chicken. I found the portions a bit smaller for the 4 course meal. The chicken was a full entree and was cooked well - not dry meat in the middle and good flavour for the (not-crispy) skin. The bacon it came with was only ok, but the veggies were good. The appetizer for the 4 course meal was asparagus and well made. My only concern here was that some parts of the asparagus were too hard (and probably should not have been served). The arctic char and the lamb cheek were both good, small portions but an excellent combination of ingredients. Finally the dessert was excellent - it was a panna cotta with berries. I think the flavour here was perfect since it was not too sweet but not tasteless either. 

I'd give the restaurant a strong 4 stars (4.5) but the snobbish feel just makes it miss the 5 star mark. Note that they also add an automatic 18% gratuity...although I feel it was deserved, I'm not a fan of forced gratuities.
author: Alfonso C.

description: I've never been disappointed. Been for brunch, lunch, and dinner. Impressive sake menu! Has outdoor seating with heat lamps and you can bring your dog.
author: Anna K.

description:
Drink: they call it the hot one, $10, and it's their interpretation of a bloody mary.  No kick at all.  It was a lagunitas beer and tomato juice. Didn't taste anything else in there.  The menu says they make it with la tapatia sauce...maybe they forgot to put it in.  Also shared several pitchers of sangria.  It was not bad, but also not great.

Food:  had the bbq rib hash.  3 tiny ribs.  Dry and bland.  By definition, a hash is supposed to have potatoes.   This thing had 5 small pieces of potato.  It was mostly quinoa and uncooked spinach.  Accurately, they need to call it a bbq rib salad.  Very disappointing. $17

Service.  Not knocking our waiter because he was very nice and attentive.  However, a minute after we ordered our food and drinks, the angry owner woman rushed over to tell us they have a $25 per seat minimum in the most condescending tone.  We were a party of 9, with 2 babies and 7 adults.  We ordered 9 entrees because we were going to share some dishes.  We also ordered lots of drinks.  I have no idea why she felt like she needed to treat us as if we weren't ordering enough for her to turn a profit on our table.   F#ck lady, we ordered 9 entrees for 7 people. Was that not enough?  Anyway, back to the story.  We question her policy, noting that this $25 per seat minimum is not indicated anywhere on the menu, on their website, on yelp, nor on opentable.  Her response was, "I assume you would know that", and walked away.  Well, we all know what assuming makes you, don't we.  At the end of our short meal, because we couldn't wait to leave this place after being treated like sh!t, she came over again and said we were $1 short of the minimum charge.  Could we have just added $1 to the bill and call it a day?  Nope, you have to order something.   Fine.  Dessert.  Happy?  With tax, automatic 19% gratuity, SF mandate, our tab came out to $300.  Did we meet our minimum?  Bye.  You suck.  Never coming back.
author: Peter M.

description: The service is great here.  The coffee and food is pretty good too.  Parking was easy on Saturday around 1p (surprisingly).  I'd make reservations just to be safe.  We had the Japanese breakfast and the Croque Madam and both were good.  I really loved the honey spice latte and pumpkin panna cotta.  I would definitely come back.
author: Chris L.

description:
Being Asian (...no, it's not a myth, it's true), I've had more than a passing curiosity to visit Cassava ever since it opened a couple of years ago. However, as a SoMa-ite, it was on the edge of the world as far as I was concerned. The outer Outer Richmond since you can feel sea spray over there. Or at least I thought it was sea spray. Funny thing is that I've been to the bakery that previously inhabited that space, Le Bread, and judging from my long-forgotten Yelp review from back then, it was not a happy experience. But alas, just two words were able to bring Cassava and me together.

No, not "Japanese breakfast" - the words were "dead jellyfish". Thousands of them washed ashore at Ocean Beach. Had to see their glistening royal blue carcasses for the inevitable photo opportunity. So since I was in the vicinity, I thought I'd give Cassava a try. It looks like they've expanded the space since the Le Bread days into a light, airy cafe with white subway tiles, heather blue walls, artistically drawn chalkboards and patio seating (photo: http://bit.ly/1uUH5b1). All of it was quite inviting though I had to wait about five minutes for a table for one. Once seated, the service was cordial with staff dressed nattily in pinstripe aprons.

I have to admit the weekend brunch menu was full of temptations, half with an Asian twist and the other half more new jack American (photo: http://bit.ly/VEhi7A). I was seriously eyeing the $17 72-hr Braised Short Ribs "Hash" Bowl with Poached Egg, but the hostess Yuka went down on her knee and broke the news to me that they were out of it. I managed to avoid a heavy sigh and ordered the $12 Meatball + Curry & Fried Egg, an Indian-derived treat that takes as its base the tomato cream curry sauce found in butter chicken dishes, adds several meatballs made of tofu and beef, and then places a fried egg sunny side up on top.

It came with a scoop of rice with paneer cheese and a bit of lettuce lightly doused in some dressing (photo: http://bit.ly/1pZlr0O). Mild subcontinental peasant fare is how I would describe it, and it was delicious in the morning. Yuka came back and lured me with their $5 Madagascar Vanilla Panna Cotta, which they describe accurately as a "super creamy Italian Milk flan" surrounded by macerated berries and orange chunks (photo: http://bit.ly/VElR1B). Speckled with real vanilla bean, it was ridiculously good. The two Asian girls at the next table were gawking at me and obviously exhibited more willpower than I did in not ordering it. But what the hell? I was somewhere near Timbuktu, right?

FOOD - 4 stars...clean, creative executions on Asian-accented dishes
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...an open, inviting space 
SERVICE - 4 stars...quite attentive and special props to Yuka
TOTAL - 4 stars...perhaps the Outer Richmond doesn't require a passport and shots
author: Ed U.

description:
Do not hesitate to visit this Balboa neighborhood gem.  You can get homemade waffle with tasty bacon or the marinated Japanese brunch with poached egg, marinated salmon and kim chee pickles. Coffee was great and polished it off with a Reutberger Lager. Prices are more than reasonable and the service was low key and on time.
The GF appreciated the spiffy, clean restrooms too.
author: Todd R.

description: I had their Japanese breakfast set.  It was really good!  We sat outside on a good day.  They also have a really interesting menu selection.
author: Serina K.

description: This is such a wonderful spot and has great Japanese breakfast. I came here ALL THE WAY from the western addition. Love you cassava!
author: gabriella m.

description:
My parents and I came here early on a Friday night and the place was totally empty but we chose to sit outside which was really nice. It happened to be happy hour so my dad got a $3 sangria which he enjoyed. He said he couldn't taste the alcohol and drank it really fast (mom had to drive him home lol). I had their hibiscus spritzer with rose water which I loved! It kind of tasted like cinnamon.  We all shared the Porchetta, 
Scallops with farro (risotto), and
Glazed pork spare ribs. I enjoyed the Porchetta but my mom said it was too dry.  The spare ribs were so tender they fell right off the bone! And the scallops were delicious! It also came with a farro risotto with Brussels sprouts, mushrooms, and butternut squash. 

For dessert we had the Madagascar Vanilla panna cotta, Bread pudding, and a Spiced honey latte. Everything was amazing! The panna cotta was so flavorful and came with fresh fruits and an apricot jam. The bread pudding also came with fruits, whipped cre, and apricot jam. The honey spiced latte was my favorite, I would definitely come back just for the latte. 

Overall we really enjoyed our meal and will be back in the future!
author: Linz C.

description:
My friend and I were looking some where to have Sunday brunch after our walk on Ocean Beach and we came across Cassava on Balboa Street.

The food and presentation was amazing , customer service was excellent. We got to chat to one of the owner's Yuka, super friendly!!!
author: mark l.

description:
Finally had a chance to visit cassava after having it booked mark for quite some time.
After reviewing their menu I didn't know what to order (I wanted something heartier than the Japanese breakfast) and settled on the croissant breakfast sando. While I enjoyed my over toasted sandwich I could still taste the day old ness of the croissant ;(  
My friend opted for the meatballs in curry which she really enjoyed. While my 60 hour cold brew sounded super interesting on the menu it was just ice coffee that could of used an extra shot of espresso. 

Service is super friendly. I'd return to try out other items on their menu someday...
author: Liz N.

description:
Came here with my brother for a Saturday brunch, after seeing an ad during the previews the night before at the Balboa Theater. (The ad worked on us!) We were seated at the "bar", so luckily didn't have to wait at all.

The interior and decor is very hip and cutesy, with rustic/farmy elements. The main kitchen is kind of open so sitting at the bar, you can see them cooking on the stove and plating dishes...which was nice. (I always enjoy open kitchens) 

Food was certainly good, but nothing amazing. Definitely on the pricier side, $12-20 a plate. 

I ordered the "Continental Breakfast": yogurt w/ granola and fresh berries, honey, and a side of soft poached egg and croissant. It was very light and fresh, which I enjoyed! I asked for a rustic roll substitution, but they forgot and still gave me the croissant. :(

My brother ordered the "liege waffle w/ scrambled eggs, bacon". The waffle had a strange texture, as if it wasn't cooked through...but I don't think that was the issue. I think it was just the batter. Not bad, but just interesting... The scrambled eggs were delishhh and super fluffy! He also got a fresh squeezed juice, which was good but very overpriced!!! It came in pretty small glass :/

Overall, very cute restaurant with very fresh ingredients. On the pricier/fancier side, but if that's what you're looking for..definitely worth a try!!
author: Melinda W.

description:
Does not live up to the hype at all. The food took way too long for being one of the first tables in there. Many other tables got their food before we did. I'm talking about a breakfast sandwich, nothing could make it possibly take that long. It was drenched in pesto which mixed together with the egg made it a sloppy mess. No one ever checked back in on us for me to express my unhappiness. Also the waffle that was ordered was a half of a waffle. How trendy? I mean order it if you're not that hungry. 
I literally had to flagged the server down so I could pay and leave. Only to go get a bagel.
author: Ari F.

description:
* came here once for brunch - service good, food great
* was enough to convince me to support their go fund me campaign
* owners hosted a thank you party for go fund me supporters, awesome!
author: Cassandra T.

description: Delicious brunch food unlike any other brunch we've had before. I had the baked burrata and my fiance had the hen and cornbread. The ingredients were super fresh, thoughtfully put together and well balanced. We thought this was a nice change from more typical brunches with huge servings of standard breakfast foods that are thrown together. Additionally, echoing other reviews that the staff was really nice. We will definitely be back.
author: Amanda C.

description: Went for a Monday brunch. Reason for 3 stars: very limited menu. I think there was only 6 options. I wanted bunch and was hoping to see the waffle that everyone raves about but I guess it's a weekend thing since it was not on the menu. I got the open face egg avocado sandwich which was good, the sauce made the meal. Definitely recommend some ham or bacon on the side otherwise you may not be full. Place is cute, I sat outside. It's order and pay first then seat yourself.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Went for dinner on Saturday, January 28th 2017.  Found Cassava through the Restaurant Week event. It took us almost 2 hours to get there from Livermore (heavy traffic on the 580 & going across the bay bridge), couldn't find parking (eventually found a spot a couple blocks away), and we seriously needed to pee by the time we got there! (I know - TMI.)  After taking care of necessities, we needed wine, and needed it fast! The staff was friendly and professional (a good balance is critical to me), we were seated right away and, working with the waiter, we found a nice glass of Pierce Ranch Tempranillo to unwind with while we reviewed the menu.

We did the pre fix menu.  Here's what we had:
Burrata Salad  - not part of the pre fix but we just had to try it - delicious! This comes with toast so you can scoop up the gooey burrata and the apple chutney. All the flavors meld nicely - you could make a meal of this salad.  Good thing we shared it because we had a lot more food coming.

Nantes carrot "salad" - best damn carrot I've ever had - seriously!  You look at the plate and there's this whole carrot lying there amid an artful array of beets, purees, and micro-greens.  You're thinking to yourself, uh, this is just a carrot on a plate. lol I'll probably never have a carrot like that again. It had the most interesting, and yummy, infusion of spices and perfectly tender crisp.  Mmmm.  Oh, and the beets were good too.  :-) Alain Passard would be proud!!

Chinook Salmon - beautiful piece of fish cooked perfectly. Crispy blackened skin was so good and the flesh melted in your mouth it was so tender.  This little beauty comes on a bed of black rice with bacon tidbits - a totally scrumptious, hearty divine mesh of goodness.  

Beek Cheeks - hmmm, was getting full by the time this arrived so this entre was not the star of the night for me.  It reminded me of slow cooker pot roast. (I love a good pot roast so not saying this dish was sub par - just wasn't in the mood for it.) The accompanying roasted cauliflower was excellent though (they do something with vegetables here that defies reasoning).  If you're a person who doesn't like fish, this entre is totally in your wheelhouse. 

Panna Cotta - I loved this dessert.  I love panna cotta in general and this didn't disappoint.  The flavors imparted to the custard were subtle and wonderful on the palate.  Very refreshing end to the meal with the mint infusion and fresh berries.  As part of the pre fix, this came with a glass of cream sherry. They went very well together but I think a nice mint tea would have been sublime for me.

Tip: Since we had a glass of wine before dinner, one with each entrée, and the sherry with the dessert, we walked down to the look at the ocean at the end of the street and then back up to the La Promenade Café (closes at 10PM) for lattes before we got on the road back to Livermore.  This is a charming neighborhood area and things are very quiet here in the evening hours.
.
author: Nancy A.

description:
Be sure to try the Japanese breakfast. 5 courses of goodness. 

The vegetable/ fruit juice is prepared fresh daily. Delicious.

They serve Ritual coffee- but do not offer decaf.

They offer soft boiled eggs prepared sous vide at one temperature setting. Slightly firm, slightly soft. 

Try the short rib hash w quinoa. You won't be disappointed.
author: Jamie M.

description: What a delicious japanese breakfast! It was so cute in tiny dishes and just what i needed for a sunday brunch. I will be back for the continental breakfast.
author: kim w.

description: Just had a perfect brunch at Cassava.  The food was exquisite. Super amazing ingredients prepared w flawless execution.  Service was excellent.  Beverages were also quite exceptional.  Sf brunch with no wait?  This is an overlooked gem.  Get there now before everyone finds out!
author: Dan D.

description:
Food tries hard and falls short. Way to expensive for what they are putting out. We ordered the waffle (which is actually only half of a waffle) and their fancy egg sandwich. Completely disappointed with every aspect of the meal. The sandwich was drown in pesto and oil which made it literally fall to pieces. The only reason this business lasts is because people here don't care or have standards. 

Thanks again SF.
author: Anthony O.

description: Went there for brunch. Honey latte was delicious but a bit on the sweet side. Decor was super cute and the service was very nice. The only regret was both items I wanted to have were sold out, so I ended up getting a salad. The salad had persimmons in it and was very fresh and delicious; I requested no arugula in the salad but my salad still had a fair amount of arugula in it :( Short ribs were very flavorful but portion is small. Might come back if I happen to be around.
author: Emily H.

description:
I've been here for brunch twice and I think 2.5-3 stars is appropriate. It's pricey, food is ok, very few choices, service is pretty good, the decor/ambiance is definitely the best part.  

It's a really pretty restaurant, but I'm not interested in paying for pretty. I would rather have better food and more menu choices.  We won't be going back.
author: Sarah S.

description: OMG . This Neighborhood Cafe and Bakery is Simply Scrumptious.  Be Ready to Wait for Seating on Wknds. , But You Won't be Disappointed.  Some Really Downhome Comfort Bakes Here . Good Java Too. Limited Seating
author: Gerry L.

description:
[BACKGROUND]

With a place named Cassava, I half-expected boba :P  (FYI cassava is the plant that boba pearls are made from... thus justifying my postulate that boba is legitimately a food staple). 

We came here for a weekend brunch and made a reservation just in case, but it would have been a minimal wait, unlike the places with a mob of laissez-faire hipsters with nothing better than to do than to spend an hour waiting for brunch.  Parking is also reasonable (unimpossible meter street parking).  Service is not super speedy, so expect to pay for about an hour of parking, even if you made a reservation.

[FOODIE MEETS HIPSTER]

Anyways, Cassava turned out to be quite lovely, with unique cuisine and a modern ambiance.  It's kinda-sorta-not really fusion, bordering geographically the American and Asian areas of the Richmond and serving the curious Japanese breakfast.

I love how the menu has none of that over-priced boring eggs/bacon/toast, but is solely (soully? :P) restricted to the experimental foodie goodies.  I believe it changes, probably according to seasonal local availability blah blah blah.  On the downside, it is fairly limited--half a page of appetizers, half a page of entrees, a back side of dranks.  However, only having ~5 entree options is a blessing for indecisive people.  

As for the hipster elements, you would've guessed, water served in mason jars.  The tables are pretty, with the rustic wood and real flowers.  There's a nice outdoor seating area as well, for the rare days of good weather in the Outer Richmond.  The check is brought to you in a whimsical wooden clip, along with a recipe that I think is ours to keep.  Servers are in colorful suits with ties (props to them for dressing up the ladies so fashionably in such a risque outfit).  I was surprised when the server taking my plate exclaimed "You finished!!!", but the owner of the restaurant read my Yelp review and kindly messaged me to clarify that they were happy I finished the food, not that I was being a fatty P:

[NOMS, TAKE 1]

I originally intended to get the MEATBALLS WITH FRIED EGG, self-proclaimed on the menu to be a favorite.  The actual menu didn't mention the fried egg though, so I changed my mind as 1) there is no such thing as brunch without eggs 2) without the fried egg it would have just looked like tikka masala i.e. PG-13 food porn.

[NOMS, TAKE 2]

I splurged for the 72 HR BRAISED SHORT RIBS "HASH" with roasted potatoes, quinoa, poached quail egg, romaine lettuce, shaved fennel, kumquats ($17).  Quotes on a menu item usually signify a big risk (for example, never get "pizza").  As expected, it was not what I expected at all, but thankfully, in a good way.  Instead of a greasy fried dehydrated mess of beef and hash browns, it was... a salad.  There was arugula instead of plain old romaine lettuce, and orange instead of kumquats (or maybe I just can't tell the difference).  

I don't know whether there is some culinary rule about how long hash has to be cooked for; Griddle Fresh boasts of a similar 72h hash.  Economically, I guess you are getting more bang for your buck if you are eating something it took them 72h to make.  I don't know whether my palate can detect how long it's been cooked for, but I can attest to the fact that it was melt-in-your-mouth tender.  

Some people may dislike the fact that there isn't really a sauce for the "salad"/"hash", but I found all the ingredients to complement the nutty arugula extremely well: the fatty beef, grainy quinoa, and hearty roasted potatoes.  Admittedly, I am not the hugest fan of quail eggs because I never know how to eat them--pop the small egg into your mouth and pop the soft-boiled-ness whole, or break it like a Benedict and mix it into the salad a la bibimbap?  Overall though, the hash was delicious, satisfying, and relatively healthy.  

[NOMS, TAKE 3]

My friend got the JAPANESE BREAKFAST of Koshihikari rice, ichiban dashi miso soup, sous vide "onsen tamago" poached egg, Meyer lemon "kosho" natto, daikon wakame salad, market pickles, salt Pepper Crusted Albacore Tataki ($13).  The small portions of everything and monk-like simplicity appeared Japanese indeed.  We were pretty happy with everything except the fermented beans seemed a bit funky to us.  It's a rather healthy option, until you get hungry afterwards and grab Purple Kow down the street.
author: Edna C.

description: I think this is a hidden gem out in the Richmond district. It was a fantastic dinner. The employees make it feel like you are at their home. They are extremely helpful, hospitable, and welcoming. I would definitely come back here. They also do a brunch, but I haven't been here for it.
author: Makenzi B.

description:
This is a cute little place in the outer Richmond. Good food but pricy and limited options on the weekend.

I came here on Saturday with a friend visiting SF and ordered the Japanese breakfast ($13) while he got the Liege waffle ($14). I instantly regretted not getting the liege waffle because it looked delicious in comparison. The Japanese breakfast was nothing special. It was kind of bland and small in portion. I didn't feel like I was in Japan.

Probably won't be making a trip out here again unless I am in the area.
author: Christina G.

description:
Worthwhile visit if you're living in this area. Always popular on weekends for brunch. I haven't yet tried their weekday menu nor their dinner menu. 

Notable dishes: Liege Waffle, Duck Leg Confit Salad, and Hibiscus Glazed Pork Ribs "Hash" Bowl. I was so taken by the meat, it tastes so fresh and the duck leg and pork ribs fell right off the bone and were bursting the flavor. I've also had the Japanese Breakfast, which came with many items and is the cheapest, but it didn't stand out in comparison to the other plates that I listed. Most of the meals are incredibly healthy and have a home-made feel.
author: Kathy Z.

description: Went there for diner on Wed night. Great food, great service, super cute atmosphere (that wallpaper and chalk drawing!!) 1/2 price bottle of wine that day. Too bad its not closer to my home :(
author: Margaux M.

description:
Nice waiters.

Cute spot.

Must be slim pickings for brunch in the Rich, because this joint is not IT. If you venture out to the Rich for brunch, you shall be punished. Prepare for it. 

I had the waffle. Dry, I asked for syrup. Needed more berries. Eggs were boring. Don't do it.

Also ordered the lentil soup with blue cheese and flowers. Interesting, but lacked so much flavah:(

Won't be back. Do yourself a favor and treat yourself to brunch in the Mission or Castro.
author: Gabriela W.

description:
such a cute restaurant and i really wanted to love it.
service and ambiance are great. and appetizers got me excited. but the main (squid and pork belly) fell short.
i might try it again later but not any time soon.
author: Julie L.

description: This is probably my favorite restaurant in the city. Everything I've ever had here is delicious and just makes my soul feel good and nourished.  My favorite thing is the Japanese Breakfast.  They also have delicious desserts.  The service is fast and courteous.  I've been here many times for brunch and dinner and it never disappoints.
author: Reese G.

description:
This place was a ripoff. It is small, looks like a former deli or dry cleaners was there before. 

I had a 4"X4" piece of Salmon for $26. I was there before my date and asked for a glass of house Cabernet. The waiter said, "they usually don't pour glasses of wine, just bottles but would give one to me". Not seeing the prices we had 4 glasses of wine for $64 on the bill, $16 each for house Cab.

The food was good but they are charging double what they should be. This is a small neighborhood place and we were sitting on metal bar stools at a bar for dinner. 

You can go to the Cliff House or Beach Chalet close by for ocean views, better ambiance and less expensive. I was on a first date so did not complain, just never, never go back.
author: Mark S.

description:
Cassava was pretty disappointing, the food looks better than it tastes.  Service and hospitality is quite good however.

I tried the meatballs in curry and both parts of the dish were a fail, the curry was almost flavorless and the meatballs were dry. For my main, I had the Croque sandwich with black forest ham, herbed turkey, fried egg, avocado vermont white cheddar, basil walnut pesto, arugula.  It was pretty good but far from epic, and not constructed well (sandwich fell apart quickly).

Wouldn't return here, but the folks are so nice that I wish them well.
author: Saminda W.

description:
NEIGHBORHOOD CAFE
(4 stars)

WEEKEND BRUNCH!! Love the deck of cards for table numbers.

-FOOD, delicious
-PRICES, depends
-SERVICE, order up front
-AMBIANCE, cute

It's in the outskirts of SF, closer to Ocean Beach. Love the atmosphere, it's welcoming. The are and quotes and books are a nice touch. I come here after my jogging-sessions for yummy beverages and breakfast. 

HEFER STATS. 

LATTE ($3.50) - nicely roasted espresso. Didn't get a chance to catch what kind of beans. They have a cute set up for the coffee area, serve yourself!

LIEGE WAFFLE ($12) - liege waffle with sugar crystal, scramble eggs, house made preserve, and thick cut bacon. First off, it's a liege waffle to perfection!! Secondly, the house made preserve was like crack... I got addicted, so good!! Lastly, the scramble eggs were a little watery to my liking so if have to subtract a star. 

HIBISCUS SPIRTS ($3.50) - imagine an Italian soda without whip cream, that's what it was like with a sweet taste of hibiscus. 

Will I be back? Saturdays :)

until the next review....
author: Jane A.

description: I'm surprised that I had written a review years ago. Now that I have a child - I cannot  tell people enough to NOT go there if you have a child. My toddler wasn't screaming or yelling but Yuka made me feel so embarrassed and guilty for being there. Please note she was the only one who was super rude. Not the other servers and not the other customers. We're generally very conscious that others shouldn't have a bad experience because of us and my kid was pretty well behaved. So as an owner or host, you would likely be upset if other customers were being disturbed. He was interjecting while she spoke and any 2 year old would do that. She actually rebuked him. Not going back there and as my genre of women have children. If you are a mom or a parent with a kid, you don't need places like these to make you feel unwelcome. Food was great as usual but the overall experience was not good.
author: Sugar P.

description:
After numerous lunches, several breakfasts, and random coffee & pastry stops, and even random drive-by macaroons, my wife, daughter, and I finally joined Cassava for dinner, and what a treat it was.

The first thing you should know is that the restaurant is quite small, and you should probably make reservations as the seating capacity is limited.  What you should take away from the size is that the restaurant is making small, delicious batches of its menu items, and is not churning out monster quantities of food meant to feed massive crowds.  Instead, you get really fresh tasting and flavorful plates assembled in detail by the chef and his team.

We tried their pork ribs appetizer, grilled brussell sprouts, seared albacore over lentils, and ribeye w/ potatoes, and each plate was chocked full of flavor and simply wonderful.  The ribs dropped off the bone, the albacore was unique and tender, and the ribeye was executed to perfection. We weren't able to stay for dessert, but will come back sometime for that for sure.  

Cassava is a brilliant star of a restaurant in an emerging neighborhood business district.  I'm thrilled to be your neighbor and will be back regularly for your delicious concoctions for any and all mealtime cravings!
author: Andy S.

description:
This is for the dinner review. 
The flavors were not balanced well for all dishes....All main course were too salty as well. When we asked why they are so salty, the lady just said " sorry about that" without eye contact and left without any explanation...for all above, we feel this place is overcharged wayyyy to much for what it can offer. we paid over $350 for 5 folks. :(
author: Jessie C.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here for brunch. 

We ordered: 
Spiced honey latte 
Croque sandwich
Pork rib hash

The latte was really unique in flavor and I would definitely order it again. Very tasty!

The croque sandwich was delish as well. All of the ingredients in the sandwich made a great combo.

The pork rib hash was my favorite. It had purple and yellow potatoes, quinoa, arugula, tomatoes, orange, pickled onions, and fall off the bone pork ribs. The ribs were really tender and great in flavor. The only thing that I thought was weird was the orange slices. Personally, I think this dish could do without it.

Service: The server we had was super friendly and definitely welcoming.

All-in-all a solid brunch place.
author: Denise K.

description:
You have to come here for their quiche! The day I went, the quiche was squash. I don't even really prefer squash most of the time, but the quiche was so good, I didn't care! Moist and fluffy on the inside and flaky on the outside. I would go back right now and grab another if they were open! LOL!

I also got macarons, a blueberry danish and a morning bun. All were good, but not blow my mind good like the quiche. The macarons were a little more dense and chewy than I prefer. The blueberry danish was as well. And after having the morning bun from B Patisserie, nothing can compare.

I would like to go back and try some of their brunch dishes one day. And of course grab another quiche!
author: Elena N.

description:
Beautiful brunch in a part of the Richmond that lacks this sort of sophistication. We stopped here for a bite after a long bike ride through Golden Gate Park. Would happily come back for their prix fixe dinner menu. 

Recommend: the duck confit salad or the meatball curry if you're really starvin'.
author: Paul C.

description:
This is in reply to the comment the owner left on my last review--

One, HOW CAN THE BAR SEATS BE RESERVED? I came in WITHOUT a reservation and your staff at the door told me all your tables were reserved at the moment but i was more than welcome to have a seat at the bar because it was for OPEN SEATING. You told me this yourself too before because i never make reservations when i come there.

Two, WE WERE NOT DONE WITH OUR FOOD, i remember telling my friend we should go but then she was still drinking her juice and i didnt want to seem like i was in a rush to get out of there. It's just not right to feel that way at a restaurant, you know? 

And three, YOUR STAFF TOOK LIKE 3 PICTURES OF US IN TOTAL, one of them offered to take the picture...we didnt even ask her, but she was nice enough to offer! Actually, Your staff were so professional and accomodating! Too bad i can't say the same for you, what a shame...

To wrap this up, Judging from your comment you seem to remember who i am, you shouldve known how i was as a customer, i was never rude or disturbing when i come in. I remember you being so nice to me too! With that said, this review is purely based on my recent experience, i never had this kind of experience before with your restaurant. 

If your duty is to serve as many people in the community as you can like you said, then that goes to show that youre after QUANTITY (sales) and not QUALITY (service).

Sorry but this is a well deserved, honest review.
author: Raine A.

description:
Service is good. Kinda pricy for ordering at the front and getting your own water. I have had several times I have been here and my sandwich wasn't constructed In a manner conducive to eating.. It is always AMAZING THO. 
Blt+t = amazing.
Ranwich = amazing.

The best local sandwich place I would say in the outer Richmond.
Get a mimosa, get a blt+t. Enjoy yourself.
author: Nathan B.

description: I like this place, but it's a bit pricey for regular lunch. It's located close to my house I come here often, I would give 4,5 stars. Stuff is always friendly:)
author: Denny D.

description:
We came to Cassava for dinner tonight with two friends.  The owners makes you feel right at home.  There's an extremely comfortable vibe coming from Yuka that is extremely rare to find in a person.

We ordered:

Starters

Hot Links - made with cherry tomatoes, onions, mushrooms with a side of Kewpie mayo.  Nothing unique.

Roasted Bone Marrow - came with four pieces of brioche.  As I don't eat beef, I'm not sure if the dish was good.  Hubby and friends seemed to enjoy it.  It had a buttery fatty taste as I was told.

Entrees:

A & A both ordered the meatballs in curry & fried egg dish, which came with a side of rice.  The dish was beautifully plated.  Unfortunately, they said the dish lacked curry flavor and the meatballs were bland.  The rice was hard as it probably didn't have enough water.  They said it almost tasted a day old.

I ordered the porchetta, which is pork belly rolled with basil and walnut pesto.  The pork belly was very tender and melted in your mouth.  I couldn't taste the basil and walnut pesto.  There was also a side of butternut squash purée, which gave the dish more color.  

My friend ordered the autumn polenta cake, which came with brussel sprouts, butternut squash, kale, and heirloom cherry tomatoes.  I thought her dish was beautifully plated from the vibrant colors of the vegetables and polenta.  The polenta was yummy and I tasted a bit of truffle.  It was probably my favorite dish of the night.

Dessert:

Sweet Pastry Bread Pudding - a mixture if croissants and pastries from the morning.  I'm normally not a fan of bread pudding, but this was yummy. It had a strong citrus flavor and wasn't too soggy.

Madagascar Vanilla Panna Cotta -  it was plated beautifully, but too sweet for my liking.

Although some of the dishes were hit or miss, I do think they offer excellent service.  You can't always please everyone's taste buds, right?  I plan to return and try their tasting menu.

Thanks again Yuka for your hospitality! =)
author: Candice H.

description:
I've always had Cassava bookmarked but it was another one of those places where I'd have to dedicate a Saturday morning to get over there because it's a little bit out of my way coming from the peninsula.  So on one random Saturday morning, that's exactly what I did!

I came in to try their brunch menu and tried to go early enough to make sure that I would get a seat.  But even getting there at around 10:30am the place was packed!  Luckily, there was one seat left in there for me right after I ordered my food.

**Note:  this visit was before they had expanded and the food items that I ordered may or may not be on their current menu because it is seasonal.

So there were two things that I ordered.  The first item was their Quiche because it made 7x7's 100 Things to Try Before You Die list.  And the other item was their Shrimp and Avocado Sliders which was really the main reason that made me bookmark Cassava in the first place. 

Quiche -- http://bit.ly/XLlhvw
Yeah.  This sucker was good and I've had a nice fair share of quiche at other places.  The egg filling writh the veggies (looked like mushrooms and zucchini) was nice and fluffy while the crust had a lite crunch to it.  It totally deserves to be on the 7x7 list.

Shrimp & Avocado Sliders --  http://bit.ly/X3d6ME
If the quiche was good, these were EPIC!  Huge pieces of shrimp and a nice amount of avocado in these brioche buns.  I definitely took my time with these because every bite was full of awesomeness!

Spiced Honey Latte --  http://bit.ly/15bkI1v
This drink sounded so interesting and since it was on top of their drink menu, I had to try it.  I don't necessarily remember what was in it, but I really enjoyed this too!  Had a very light sweetness to it while having some kick to it.  Almost like chai in a way.

That was a nice trifecta of good stuff that I ordered and it's too bad that I couldn't try everything that day because I was stuffed after my meal.  I would definitely come back and dedicate another Saturday morning for another brunch session and also to try their dinner pre-fixe menus because they sound really good!

Since that last visit, I'm really glad to see that they've expanded the cafe and I'm really looking forward to my next meal over there!
author: Rodney H.

description:
Cute and cozy! Cassava is tucked away from bustle that normally crowds the Richmond and Inner Sunset neighborhoods but it is a really great find. The atmosphere is really laid back and I love the decor inside, especially the fun urban themed damask wallpaper! We came here for lunch after trying to go to Outerlands and finding it would be an hour wait. On a Monday. I was really glad coming here to find that there were plenty of tables open. You might think that because there isn't a huge line of people waiting outside, that Cassava must not be that great, but I think it might speak more to how out of the way the location is because the food was great! Boyfriend and I had the honey spiced latte with whole milk, the randwich, and the meatballs in curry with rice. 

The tomato curry tasted as you would probably expect it to. It wasn't anything spectacular but I think it tasted like a fun and interesting take on spaghetti and meatballs. The randwich was incredibly tasty though. The side salad was citrusy and light, and the soft boiled egg inside the sandwich took it from tasty to incredible... yummm. I'm a total sucker for runny egg yolks though! And of course, as many have said before, the honey spiced latte was delicious! I'm not even much of a coffee lover/drinker. (: 

I wish Cassava was a little easier to get to because I want to try more things here, but I think if it was, it would be just as annoyingly crazy busy as all the other popular brunch places. I definitely want to come back again to try out their breakfast menu!
author: Stephany L.

description:
Brunch is my favorite meal of the day, and Cassava does it fantastically.

My small and only gripe is that a waitress mispronounced one of the menu items. "Croque" (a French word) in "Mr. and Mrs. Croque" is pronounced like the word "crock", not "croak". 

Now on to all the good!

I recommend going here with a group of 4 or less, just for the convenience of getting seated. However, I went with a group of 5, and we were seated almost immediately.

I actually said "wow" after my first sip of the Bourbon Vanilla Honey Mocha. It's a very well made drink, almost like drinking a cup of melted chocolate. (Don't go for this if you're looking for alcohol in your drink, though. Bourbon vanilla is a species of vanilla.)

I ordered the Liege Waffle, [with] Maple Ricotta with Eggs, which also comes with bacon and a salad. The waffle is sweet and moist ad beautifully-decorated with fresh berries. The scrambled eggs were very fluffy but a bit salty. I've slowly become a fan of bacon, and the bacon strips were thick cuts that I enjoyed.

I can't wait to come back to get the curry meatballs and chocolate mousse!
author: Victoria C.

description:
My friend and I came here and love this little joint. Cute place with small tasteful flowers. great value for the food. and the food is made with love without the extra grease, extra richness, and super portion that usually accompany a lavish brunch somewhere.

brunch with asian tastebuds concocting the menu. many brunch items are created with western and eastern influence, but always with thought and care, with an innovative twist, speaking to restaurant goers with a straight-forward directness and a willingness and desire to impress and delight.

I ordered the Japanese breakfast with 
-- Koshihikari rice, ichiban dashi miso soup, sous vide
-- "onsen tamago" poached egg, Meyer lemon kosho 
-- natto, daikon wakame salad, simmered hijiki and 
-- konnyaku noodles
-- Salt Pepper Crusted Albacore Tataki

fantastic mix of delicate items. I even really enjoyed the natto (I really liked eating it with the rice). this is fast becoming my favorite default place to come back to in SF.
author: Rebecca C.

description: Delicious unique foods! A neighborhood favorite. Love to come here for the brunch on the weekends. Haven't came during the week yet, but I'm sure it's great! The eggs are always cooked so well, and the food is so fresh.
author: Zeke M.

description: Had the japanese breakfast on Wednesday morning since I'm currently working close by.  The set breakfast looks pretty and is presented well in Japanese fashion.  But take one bite and a sip of the miso soup and anyone that knows what Japanese food should really taste like will tell you that it lacks taste.  Everything was kind of bland.  The egg was however poached to perfection, it melted in my mouth.  The Japanese breakfast was supposed to be $10 but they asked if I wanted to add sliced trout which I added.  I think it was 3 slices for a total of $14.  For $14 and what I got, I thought it was expensive and lacking.
author: Paul T.

description: Ordered the chicken and trout - both were amazing! Limited menu but a good variety of options to choose from: fish, chicken, pork, vegetarian... Small and cozy ambiance.
author: Nitzan S.

description:
This restaurant, by far, is my go-to neighborhood quality eatery for fresh, local ingredients prepared with love and sprinkled generously with outstandingly warm customer service!  Yes, that was purposely a mouthful that will lead into my review.

It was "Saturday Date Night" with my gal.  We got premium seating outside, on a gorgeous late fall evening.  We had to get to a fundraiser after dinner, so we opted for just a salad and our entrees.

We started with a shared salad of mustard greens, pomegranate seeds, and Asian pears.  It was the perfect starter to get our taste buds tantalized!  I was well balanced over baby kale with a sweet molasses vinegar/beetroot yogurt dressing.  Yum!

My gal opted for the pan-seared salmon and it was perfectly cooked (and she's a fantastic cook in her own right)!  Accompanied by black rice, bacon, mustard greens, and a winter squash puree, I just had to have a taste for myself--and yes, it 's flavors were spot on.

I, on the other hand, chose the oven roasted Mary's chicken.  Folks, this is half a chicken, so there's plenty to share of the juiciest, most flavorful roasted chicken ever!  To quote my lady: "it's the most delicious roast chicken I have ever eaten!". Combine that with kale, honey nut squash, Nepalese barley, and broccoli sprouts, and the meal was complete and ever so filling.  

The perfect accompaniment to our meals were the glasses of Coppola Pinot Noir--WOW!  All it took was one slurp from my glass to tempt my gal, and she was all over it!

I wanted to try the lemon panna cotta, but we were both quite full.  We opted for two cappuccinos to go.

From adjusting the heaters outside to answering all of our questions on the menu, the staff made this meal memorable.

Next time, we'll definitely save plenty of room for the four course tasting menu.

Thank you, Chef Kris Toliao and General Manager Extraordinare, Yuka Ioroi!  You all made Stephanie's first dining experience at Cassava a memorable one!

Fully fueled and caffeinated, we danced for over 3 hours at the fundraiser for the Asian Women's Shelter.  Happy Couple!  :-)

Thank you,

--Alex
author: Alex S.

description:
Incredible. 
What a memorable experience!
Warm and welcoming service.
Delicious dinner. 
For a Friday night, it wasn't noisy.
It was a perfect meal highlighting local, in-season ingredients.

We had the chicken rillette, tomato and pear salad, trout, and the steak. All we're perfectly balanced, cooked, and beautifully plated. Table currency was on point and the servers treated us as if we were regulars!

We'll be back and soon!!!
author: Lily Z.

description:
This place gives great aesthetic. So perfect for a little breakfast/brunch. 

You order at the register first, and then sit wherever you'd like. All the items on the menu sounded pretty good. It was pretty pricey, and I was also hoping for more variety. IE: waffles, scrambled eggs, bacon... More breakfast-y type things.

I ended up getting the "Randwich!" I forgot what exactly was in it. From what I remember, it had pesto, turkey, tomato, an egg, avocado, lettuce, and a side of salad. Yum. The toast was perfect and served on wheat bread, which was no problem to me. My total was about $13.95.

Their service was whatever. At least from my experience. 

The wait took somewhat awhile. Maybe about 10-15 minutes? 

I'll definitely return some other day. Hopefully I'll come during the weekend brunch!
author: Mikaela T.

description: Overpriced for the quality of food unfortunately. The service was fine but the food was almost $30 per entree for very bland (although decently cooked and high quality meat) food. There were only three bottles of red wine on the menu so I ended up bringing a bottle and paying the corkage fee because I was so disappointed by the options. Nice thing is it is very easy to get a reservation. We went on Friday at 7:30pm and half the restaurant was empty.
author: Amy Y.

description: One of my favorite dining places in the Outer Richmond.  They have both indoor and outdoor seating, and just the right touches of food from breakfast, brunch/lunch, and dinner.  It's an open kitchen, and the environs are ideal.  Fresh and clean.  Dessert menu is heavenly! It's worth coming out to this neighborhood and then head over to the beach or Land's End afterwards.
author: Tina C.

description:
Seriously?! The food was one of the best I had in a long time!! (And I go to great places in the city)
I know this place is getting very popular( no wonder) and the quality and the attention going into food is amazing. 
Great quality ingredients, well executed with no pretenses---SO enjoyable!  I'm blown away...
Made another reservation next week. Yay!
author: Megumi S.

description: I just had lunch there with some friends and the food is up to par what San Francisco is all about. The salad was fresh and healthy, ribs fell of the nine tender with tons of flavor, pork belly to die for and the most amazing warm smoked trout I've had in a long while. Hats of to the chef and I will be back when I'm in San Fran! Must try.
author: Edward J.

description: I've been here a few times in the past, but now they are charging a mandatory 18% gratuity? Service was not friendly. Food was just ok not great. I live in the neighborhood, I won't be back for a long time.
author: Wesley W.

description:
After finding out they had expanded and there were more seating areas, I came here for brunch.  It was fairly crowded inside, but we found a table outside, probably cause it was a bit chilly out.
I ordered the Waffle Plate.  The waffle was nice but a bit dry.  It does come with jam, but it was too sour.  A fatty piece of bacon along with eggs that were soft and creamy.
Overall a nice place but a bit overpriced.
author: Karen L.

description:
Local outer richmond spot for breakfast, lunch, and brunch.
Always busy but consistently delivers good food so it's worth the wait.
Spiced Honey latte is a great and yummy start.
Japanese breakfast is wonderful if you are feeling the craving for tuna, miso, pickled vegetables, and rice.
Liege waffle with bacon and maple ricotta is sweet and delectable. A more Traditional breakfast.
Service is friendly w/ owners walking by to check in; a nice touch that seems forgotten in this fast pace world.
If you are wanting a comfy spot for food, come here.
author: David H.

description: If I was just rating the food, it would be four stars. However, the service was poor. We received water immediately but then waited 15 minutes to order. Previously being a server, I tend to cut people in the service industry some slack but the place wasn't full and the staff didn't seem to be busy. When we finally were greeted, the server appeared to be annoyed. At the end of the meal (no one checked on us the entire time), I had to get up and ask for the bill. Likely will not return.
author: Maria R.

description: Restaurant is cute, service is nice, and food here "looks" great but taste is a bit hit and miss. As an appetizer, I ordered the asparagus/garlic soup which was fantastic with great flavors that kept it light and satisfying. For the main course, we tried the pork belly and the fish collar/octopus, both of which ended up a bit tasteless and rubbery. Overall a good experience but nothing to write home about.
author: Sherman L.

description: The sautéed shrimp and avocado sliders were amazing!!
author: Brent O.

description:
Just ok for me.  I had to visit with all the Yelp reviews so maybe that hype has my expectations too high.

Japanese breakfast- ok.  Really. Smoked fish was perfect but that's about it. 

Rib hash- again, just ok. Yes ribs were tasty but it wasn't anything notable. 

I will say customer service is top notch!
author: Will I A m.

description:
Since I am a creative consultant these days and work from home 76.2% of the time, Cassava has become one of my lunch go-to's in the up and coming Balboa St. district that now has Marla Bakery, Noise Records and a new, improved Balboa movie theatre!

My two faves are the Chris' Meal Salad (I add turkey) and the tuna melt that also comes with a side salad.

The fruit tea is also delish. I really should find out what fruit is actually in there.

In fact, I'm off to get lunch there now since I'm hankerin' for a tuna melt.

I get back to you on the fruit tea ingredients!
author: Dennis S.

description:
Frankly, not as impressed as I had hoped. The food was over the top frou frou with poorly balanced flavors. The roasted parsnips were tasty albeit sticky but the accompanying beets absolutely flavorless. A couple of grains of salt on the beets would have made a big difference. However, no salt or pepper on the table. In fact, request for ground pepper initially unheeded. Only after second or third request did a small dish of ground pepper (no grinder) materialize. 

The salmon was nicely cooked but bland, and the portion of sauce that came with it was too meager to make sense of what it was. Not that it mattered because the salmon was overpowered by the taste and oilness of pancetta in the accompanying bed of black rice anyway. 

The $3 plate of artisan bread with honey butter came with a serving about the size of a silver dollar. When we exhausted it and asked for a little more, the waiter brought us a glob of regular butter. As neither of us were honey butter fans, that didn't matter, but seemed tacky and cheap nevertheless not to provide a more generous serving of the advertised honey butter.

We had to ask several times for another fork as well

Glad to have checked the place out, and that it is sprucing up the neighborhood, but in no hurry to go back.
author: Buthi D.

description: Lovely place that we stopped by for brunch before our Land's end trail walk. Had the beef hash and the meatball/paneer curry. Beef hash was a tad odd being on a salad and tons of roasted potatoes (some were undercooked). Luckily, I was skipping the rice from the curry and the hubs combined the two and enjoyed his meal. The meatball curry is not a very typical Indian curry. It tasted milder, with more of a tomato base and I could eat it directly without having to pile on tons of rice. Made for a hearty brunch on a breezy Sunday morning. Lovely decor (funny, albeit beautiful, wall paper of fire hydrant, rats, pigeons and parking meters) and nice service. Won't necessarily trek out here specifically but if in the neighborhood, a good place to stop by.
author: Stephanie L.

description: We were impressed! Food was yummy, service was excellent, portions were large. Nice and intimate setting. Great date spot!
author: ere r.

description:
Very trendy, good atmosphere, decent food, but ultimately overpriced.
Bottom line: a fine place for brunch, but not worth the price.
author: Jeff C.

description: Love this local gem! We are lucky enough to live nearby, and our whole family enjoys delicious breakfast and brunch items as often as possible. Sometimes disappointing to wait when it gets crowded, but it never gets crazy like other brunch places in the city. My husband and I have also enjoyed date night dinners at Cassava as well... inventive, delicious, never heavy.
author: Lee Anne W.

description:
Hipster, charming, and inviting environment with a cafe-like atmosphere. The space is quaint, but brightly lit with indoor and outdoor seating. The weekend brunch menu limited compared to other brunch places, but there a few unique options to try. The staff was very friendly and helpful.

We made a reservation for weekend brunch, but still had a wait ~30 minutes before being seated since our table was no available yet.

I ordered the Meatballs in Curry with Rice + Fried Egg and Spiced Honey Latte. The meatball dish tasted like an average meatball dish with tomato sauce and rice. I could not tell that it was Japanese Curry given that it lacked the "curry" favor I was expecting. The Spiced Honey Latte was warm, sweet, and delicious; similar to a Starbucks sugar-filled latte.

Would want to come back to try their dinner menu.
author: Angel G.

description:
The first time my friends and I tried going here for a Saturday brunch, we weren't able to go.  Turns out you have to have a reservation especially with our big group.  So we were able to reserve for our next Saturday brunch.  Place is pretty small but it's great that they are the few that takes reservations for brunch.  
I got the curry meatballs and I liked it.  My friends got different dishes that I thought were unique.  It's not your typical brunch menu.  I was bummed out though that they didn't have decaf coffee.
author: Claire J.

description:
I've been selfish for far too long. This place is close to my heart and home and I haven't written them a review for many years, but they deserve it. Most people come for brunch or lunch, but what most people fail to realize is that their dinner is even more scrumptious than the daytime meals. Most small restaurants can't boast having a drink menu that can stand up to the food pairings, but sometimes I'll just come for that sweet honey-spiced latte that only they concoct. They change their menu all the time because they use fresh, in-season, and local ingredients. You can't go wrong with any dish you order here. Try their dinner before it gets packed and there's a line out the door!

And to the people complaining about the service they're getting, maybe you're just assholes who have no idea what it's like to work in the grueling service industry, because I have been coming here since they opened, and not once have I ever felt rushed or slighted or forgotten by their staff. The owners are incredibly generous, warm, and hard-working, and I've seen them bend over backwards trying to please their often uppity and whiny customers. Trust me, I work in the industry and hearing the way some of you entitled brats talk about stuff you know nothing about is simultaneously hilarious and infuriating.
author: Heather U.

description:
Tasty food and coffee. Great, relaxing ambiance. Service with a smile 

Order to go or order to eat in.

If you eat in, order and pay, then pick your seat. Grab your own utensils, cups and karaffe.

I would definitely return!
author: Missy W.

description:
Cassava is fantastic!  A friend of mine wanted to go to Marla and how great was going to be except he made no reservation.  Marla is packed even when it is not packed.  Luckily Cassava is right there--a cup of coffee and a not too long of wait we were able to sit down and eat.

I had a great experience.  Food and service were outstanding.  San Francisco and I have said many times before is an okay service town--hard to get good or north of impossible for great service.  I had a Liége waffle with scrambled eggs, bacon sans the eggs--they were so gracious and offered avocado--I never turn down the opportunity for avocado.  The Liége was not dense-light and thoughtful amount of berries and maple lemon Ricotta, two handsome wands of bacon.  We ordered a pitcher of red Sangria and loved there was a flower in it.  

The quality, concern and delivery of the food is done so well not just for the Richmond district but any district.  I look at the negative reviews and I cannot believe I ate the same place.  Cassava was a great experience and true concern and care for quality, presentation of food and great and gracious service.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
Nice to have another fabulous restaurant in the Outer Richmond.
Yuka and her husband rock.
The food is fresh and delicious.
The decor is cute.
Espresso is wonderful.
Cassava has character.
author: Angela K.

description: Great service but the food was so bland   I found this place on open table and it had great ratings. I took my parents there when they came to visit and sadly we were overall underwhelmed.
author: Avery A.

description: good ambiance, owned by the chef and his wife. super friendly and hard working! the food is beyond expectations and definitely worth the money and wait
author: Nick H.

description:
Whenever we come to the city I always like to try some place different.  We always look on Yelp and so glad we did.  We had lunch here last Saturday sitting outside with our dog.  The service was great and we did not feel hurried at all despite the people waiting outside near us.  I had the Liege waffles and when it first came out I was thinking what small portions.   It was fine since the waffle was very filling.  My only compliant was the side of greens.  It had no flavor and was just shredded ice berg lettuce and some arugula. 
The eggs were a little running but hubby said that the Japanese style of making eggs.
Hubby had the curry meatballs and rice and loved it.  Towards the end I saw the coffee selections and was excited to see some different choices so we took one to go and it was delicious!!!! I think its made with Ritual Roasters coffee.
author: Nancy G.

description:
This is a hidden gem and must-visit restaurant in the Richmond District! They helped me host a big group of 15 for a birthday dinner. When we got their, they greeted us by name, and had a table immaculately set up for us. We did the 4 course tasting menu--my favorite was the Mt. Lassen Trout, which was perfectly crisp on top a bed of rice and kale. Side note: I usually avoid kale at all costs, but they made me a kale-liever :)

Customer service was incredible, as was the lemon verbana panna cotta.
author: Benjamin A.

description:
Had the most perfect Valentine's Day dinner here with my honey and another couple who live in the neighborhood. All were wowed by the gracious service and the quality of the food the tiny kitchen turns out. The owner even remembered the kind of wine I like from another visit. 

Although it was a  5  course fixed price , a few of the dishes like the chowder and the delicious, subtly flavored Arctic Char are on the regular winter dinner menu. Warm, intimate, it reminds me of the perfect family run European bistro.  A place for both everyday and special occasions.
author: Joan P.

description:
I have been waiting to come back to Cassava when my family come and visit me. 
 
Our experience were as good as the first time when I found this place.  Staff are very friendly 
The ocean trout is out of this world, super yummy 
Our entrées were delicious we had the Mr&Mrs Croquet; Duck con fit salad which by the way is sooooo tender; and scrambled eggs with waffles and ricotta n honey is amazingly delicious. 

Only one minor note was, when I asked a staff about the names of the micro greens on our Ocean Trout plate,he picked through our salad with his fingers even though I told him that we were still working on our plate,  by then we had lost our appetite didn't want to finish the salad.  which made us feel really awkward
author: P C.

description:
They open for brunch at 10am on Saturdays and Sundays, we got there about 5 mins before and we were still served, which is nice of them. There were already a couple of people ahead of us that were served as well.

Japanese breakfast $10- the marinated persimmons that was stated on the menu were non existent - there were fermented beans instead. The rice that came with this dish was hard. Which is weird because it should be a fresh batch of rice since they just opened. The miso soup that came with this dish was yummy and I like that there were lots of mushrooms in it. 

Meatballs in curry + fried egg $12- beef and tofu meatballs in a "butter chicken" curry sauce/tomato cream, tasted more like a tomato cream than it resembles butter chicken. The rice we got with this dish was better & the meatballs were good.

Btw, they don't carry peanut butter cornflake cookies anymore that everyone is raving about! I really wanted to try it :(
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Cassava is one of my favorite restaurants in the SF Bay Area. I come every few months for brunch even though I live in the South Bay.

I recommend Cassava based on consistently excellent execution and a delightful menu. The dishes balance freshness and richness (e.g., duck leg salad). The Japanese breakfast is a true gem beyond the "contemporary" items on the menu.

The space is bright and cozy and all the staff I've interacted with are very friendly. They also have Where's Waldo books for the table to play with while waiting!
author: Amy S.

description: I've been here a few times for lunch and I'm a fan. Their sandwiches are amazing. Tried brunch here today though and wasn't wild about the brunch menu. Very small menu, not much to choose from. Buuuut I did get the meatball / curry / rice / fried egg thing, and it was amazing. PHIL, our server, has an awesome personality. Five stars for Phil. P
author: Chelsie D.

description:
UPDATE:
I've been a Yelp member since 2009 and had never written a review before today, but felt compelled to do so after my very disappointing experience last night. 

On the flip side I felt compelled again to write a follow up since Yuka contacted me in response to my review both in writing and via a call.

She proactively called me to share her heart felt apologies for our experience and to offer an unsolicited full refund. I have a lot of respect for a biz owner who wants to go above and beyond to make a bad situation better.  Thanks, Yuka.
------------------
Terrible. Had on my list to try and finally did, wish I hadn't. With so many wonderful choices in SF don't waste your time with this place. 

Service - uneven at best. We arrived on time for our reservation and our table wasn't quite ready. No big deal, we didn't wait very long to be seated (maybe 10 mins.), but that was the last time we didn't wait long. Once seated we waited 35 mins for someone to take our dinner order and no one came; I eventually I got up to find someone to help us. While apologetic, which we appreciated, you would have thought that this type of situation would have highlighted our table, but it happened time and time again throughout the meal. Odd things like my husband and I both wanted wine with dinner so I ordered a bottle, but our waitress misunderstood and brought both of us a by the glass pour. Our server made good by eventually bringing us the bottle but by the time she did so we were mostly done with our meal.

And the food...our apps were fine. Salad and burrata were both fresh, but nothing spectacular, but the chicken rillettes was bland and forgettable. And our entrees...we were a 4-top, 2 people chose the steak (which contained "silver skin" throughout) it was tough and mostly inedible (note, one of our dinner companions mentioned his dissatisfaction to one of the waiters who picked up his mostly uneaten plate and he just sort of shrugged and smiled as if to say oh well); I had the squab which was overcooked and dry (and my sides were cold and odd tasting) and a fish dish which was ok. 

We all had high hopes going in, but left sorely disappointed and somewhat embarrassed as I had chosen our destination. My advice, don't waste your time or money on this restaurant there are many, many better choices in SF.
author: jennifer s.

description:
Cute lil cafe in the Outer Richmond.  You'd think that with a name like "Cassava" and an owner that's Filipino that they would serve cassava, but they don't. :( So don't get too excited if that's what you're looking for.

The other half of the couple who owns this restaurant is Japanese, so there are a lot of Japanese inspirations in the menu.  They're known for their Japanese breakfast, which is unique, fresh and worth trying.  This is one of the hottest sellers on their menu.  You get a great variety of items to taste on the tray, which one of their staff will need to explain how to enjoy.  It's worth noting that the ingredients used for their Japanese breakfast, in particular, are incredibly fresh.  You probably will not taste anything like their ichiban dashi miso soup anywhere else!  We also ordered their Short Rib Hash Bowl, which was also good.  Good portion with quite a variety of fresh ingredients.

The cafe is quite small, seats probably under 20, so expect to wait for a table.

Brunch was good, but not GREAT...maybe it had to do with what we ordered or what I was expecting.

If it's all about supporting local small businesses, I'm all for going back.
author: Audrey C.

description:
Came here for my birthday back in December and also a week ago with some friends.  I will say that my absolute favorite thing is the Japanese breakfast and that's about it.  The second time I came here I had the meatballs and just thought they were meh.  

The place itself is very small but really cute.  One of the few places with outdoor seating in SF, so makes it great to bring the dogs with us to brunch.
author: Krystal L.

description:
Can't believe we haven't been to this neighborhood gem before now! We will for sure make up for lost time because the brunch at Cassava was top-notch.

We went on a Sunday morning, sans reservations (for shame!), but they had a few tables available. Service from the hostess was nice, waiter was a little more reserved but it didn't bother us. 

We ordered a spiced honey latte (PLEASE do yourself a favor and try this), a mocha, and two leige waffles&scrambled eggs plates. The lattes were delicious and the waffle plates were scrumptious. Our waffles were topped with a dollop of ricotta and a dollop of (apple?pumpkin?) butter with a sprinkling of fruit. I'm not a huge sweet-waffle person but I really really enjoyed the lemony flavor of the waffle with the sweet toppings. It wasn't too sweet. The bacon was thick and crisp, and the scrambled eggs were slow-cooked and very rich.

Highly recommend coming to Cassava for brunch if you live in or are visiting this part of the city.
author: Liz G.

description:
About two weeks ago, my friend and I stopped here after a beautiful stroll through Land's End. 

First, the service was exceptional. Our server, who may also be the store manager, was so accommodating and friendly. After taking our drink order, she saw that I was waiting for the restroom for a while, and offered to let me use the staff restroom. Wow!

The drinks and food were delicious. I had a honey latte which was flavorful without being too sweet, and my friend had a really refreshing juice. The Japanese breakfast set we ordered was elegant comfort food. The presentation was lovely, and each dish was simple and tasty. It went perfectly with the heavier favors of the Hibiscus Glazed Pork Ribs "Hash" Bowl.

The desserts were fantastic! My friend and I couldn't decide between the cherry panna cotta and the almond pot de crème. Here's the kicker. After admitting our indecision to our server (an A+ first world dilemma, I'm aware), we finally decided on the pot de crème. When she came to drop it off at our table, she brought us both the panna cotta and pot de crème, so we wouldn't miss out! 

Loved everything about Cassava! You guys rock!
author: J H.

description:
Cassava, similar to its likely competitor, Marla Bakery down the block, makes you forget you are in the Richmond district of SF. If you grew up as a native around these parts of the city like I have, you'll know that New American eateries were unheard of. It wasn't until recent years that this Russian and Chinese populated area gave us something other than old and boring to be excited about.

Parking can be a pain if you go on certain times of the day.  Makes you wonder if it's worth eating up 2 gallons of gas before you even get to eat what's on the menu.  Well, if you happen to be stuck in that most unfavorable scenario, just let me clear your frustration and road rage now by telling you it is soooooooo worth it. If you happen to catch me leaving there, I'll gladly give up my space for a bribe that will conveniently cover the cost of gas I used up to find my space... and then some.  Haha... Cruel.  Hey pay it forward... that's a great idea if you ask me.

When the parking ordeal is over, walking into Cassava is a breath of fresh air and maybe even a breath of pollen as your road rage and anger is subdued by the clean quaint setting that resembles something like that of a summer cottage brunch with white plates atop wood grain tables smiling with a touch of fresh lovely seasonal flowers.

This cottage charm gives way to a small unique menu of Japanese/American fare that highlights fresh tasty ingredients. Although not made in house, they offer delightful pastries from the famous Semifreddi's bakery. On a cold windy autumn's day, a cup of their house made hot cocoa, Bourbon mocha, or mint honey rose tea reminds us how nice it is to be indoors sipping from a hot steamy mug with an elegant date. 

As we waited for our orders of Tuna Melt and the Randwich, we enjoyed some laughs and selfies over steamy hot sips and a sweet light fluffy morning bun.  A great start to such a relaxing early afternoon before each of us had to head to work. Our eyes glistened with utter delight as our sandwiches made it to our table. The ever lovely Gigi M. has a habit of pressing her hands against her cheeks while her eyes light up as her jaw drops when she sees or tastes something that excites her... You know it's nothing short of amazing when she makes that face. Within seconds, she snaps away, easily capturing the most IG perfect square to enlighten her friends of her proud new find.  I knew how she must've felt... Everything was indeed picture perfect.
