I quickly found myself mesmerized by the luscious green of the pesto and the waterfall of a bright sunny yellow yolk flowing from my 'Randwich'; A seductive combination of roasted turkey, avocado, tomato, spinach, pesto, and poached egg in between warm toasted foccacia bread.  It was one of those moments where you reluctantly take a bite into a sandwich because it was that much of an eye candy. I mean, could you imagine the fight I had within myself?  If I eat it all, I won't be able to see it again!  To eat or not to eat? That is the question Prince Hamlet would have asked if faced with a Randwich. To eat... The unequivocal answer when it comes to this kind of Hunger Games. Like the "house", Morning famine always wins. The Randwich... Yums.

The tuna melt didn't disappoint either. A crispy bite of grill pressed white bread enticingly introduced us to a warm gooey creamy layer of good ole American cheese, fresh cool tomato, and a light creamy tuna brightened with lemon and little sweet crunchy crystals of shallots. A childhood favorite that never seems to get old no matter how many times or how many ways you've had it very much like watching a sunset or playtime in bed with your lover. *Wink*

We rested our bellies as she enjoyed the earthy roast of their Bourbon Mocha while I, the fragrant Rose tea enliven with mint sweetened with honey. Warm and cozy indoors, we each tapered off our breakfast/lunch date with a few pages of good read we had brought with us.

The bottom of our cups didn't fail to remind us that it was 20 minutes before work on another manic Monday. We unwillingly left the comfort of our afternoon sanctuary and back into the brisk autumn SF air. I would have loved to take a bribe from someone in dire need of parking, but it seems Mondays are a good day to be here... no mental torture finding parking, save a couple gallons of gas to pay meter instead, no wasted money on bribe, and a wonderful breakfast/brunch.

Note: Although the hostess at the register comes off as standoffish, the overall experience was, is, and will be a fond first here at Cassava. There will surely be many more. Friendlier vibes and house made pastries would definitely put them up at a 5 for me. I was slightly on the fence between 4 and 5.  As my emotional high settled, a 4 seemed much more fitting. Enjoy!

Edit: Host maybe owner reached out for genuine feedback! Love Cassava even more that they care. See compliment from Cassava B. n my response. Looking forward to giving 5 next time!
author: Colin M.

description: I finally tried the Japanese breakfast and it was just what I needed. I ran my usual jogging route, and needed something light before I headed home. The cured trout that is marinated in salted beet sauce was amazing. It was cut like sashimi, and the texture is like sashimi too. It's not grilled or cooked in anyway, so be aware of this. The daikon miso soup had good umami, and light in taste. There's a softboiled egg with chicken stock?, and that was a unique flavor. Not my favorite, but nice way to get additional protein. I paired my meal with a refreshing southern fruit tea (think iced tea with more fruit juice at a 20/80 ratio). I asked for a cappuccino to go, and that was the perfect way to end my meal. Now I plan to keep coming back until I try everything on the menu. Meal was about $25 after tax and tip.
author: Thomas L.

description: My favorite restaurant in San Francisco! Great food and better service. Would give it more stars if I could.
author: Matt M.

description:
Cute, quiet, good food. Super hipster.

------------------------------------

Came here with my girl friends for Saturday Brunch.

The service was amazing, the people who work there are the cutest and the nicest.

We ordered some drinks, the Japanese meals, the Hibiscus salad with Glazed Short Ribs, and the Black Forest Ham Sandwich. Everything was so good. No complaints in my department.
author: Eileen ..

description: Cassava is a nice little lunch spot with abundant parking nearby (during the week). I enjoyed the turkey BLT, a very small panini accompanied by a very small salad. Though the portions appeared small, they were sufficient without feeling stuffed. My co-worker had the meatball, curry and rice. Also a petite portion. My sando was pretty tasty, the bread soft and the bacon crisp, but still meaty. I'd come back for a light lunch, not a place for big eaters.
author: .Alan Y.

description:
Great alternative brunch spot to all those other crazy busy places with insane lines. So glad I decided to come here instead of waiting in a hour+ line! I remember seeing this cute little restaurant when I was in Outer Richmond a while ago but it wasn't open so I just added it to my bookmarks. Finally got around to trying it a year later! 

We came for a later brunch, around 1pm, and we were seated once our table was set up. The restaurant is pretty cozy and adorable! There are a few tables for outdoor seating as well, which is a better option for larger groups. 

Their brunch menu was simple which is nice. Sometimes it takes us forever to decide what to order if there are too many options. I started with a spiced honey latte, which is right up my alley. I love anything chai/spicy and honey flavored. It was the perfect balance between spicy and sweet. They use real honey so it was overly sweet but it definitely had that nice after taste to it. 

I went with the smoked trout hash which was basically a quinoa salad with roasted potatoes topped with smoked fish, grape tomatoes, some citrus fruits, and a soft poached egg. It was definitely a very light and refreshing meal compared to my usual heavy brunch orders. I felt full and didn't feel horrible about myself afterwards! 

Definitely recommend this to anyone looking for a change of pace in the brunch selections. They have some unique selections on the menu that you don't really see on typical brunch menus.
author: Maryann S.

description:
Such a cute, little hipster bakery cafe! Loved the decor and ambiance. 

Just for their drinks:

Iced Bourbon Vanilla Mocha- pretty good. Sweet, full of flavor, with the right amount of coffee. 

Iced Green Tea Latte- my friend ordered this, but it was really bland. It just tasted like iced milk w/ a hint of matcha powder. She asked for more matcha powder & was given some, but was told it's not like Starbucks :l I'd prefer Starbucks' GTL over this one though. 

Wish we came here to try their Korean Breakfast. It looked so cute and their dishes were nicely plated. Def will come back here for breakfast.

The only thing is that it's super teensy and tight. They have a few tables and some outdoor seating.
author: Elise T.

description: Amazing breakfast! Compliments to the chef. Simple open faced egg, avocado and arugula sandwich, but done so well!! Will definitely be back for more.
author: Jesse H.

description:
Perfect outdoor brunch on a sunny day after a walk at lands end.  A super plus for me is their outdoor dining so the pup can hang out too.  

I opted for the japanese breakfast because I was looking for something on the lighter side.  I liked that there was an american influence because a full-blown japanese breakfast can be intimidating, especially for first timers!  

My fave items were the duck liver mouse - super creamy with a nice port gelee and the smoke ocean trout.  Omg I could eat a whole plate of that trout all by myself. 

Can't wait to come back for dinner & more! 

Thanks Kris and Yuka!!
author: Phoebe L.

description:
I wanted weekend brunch but didn't wake up super early to wait the hour long lines at the normal brunch places.  I remembered some friends mention Cassava and decided to look it up online - and then saw you can make reservations on a Saturday for brunch on their website and 12pm was available, I hear a WINNER!

It was an unusually sunny Saturday in the Outer Richmond and I realized there was a wait, but it was to sit outside.  The decor is modern, simple, and clean with mason jars for water and playing cards for table numbers. 

What we ate:  I ordered the Hibiscus Glazed Pork Ribs "Hash" Bowl ($17) - the ribs were soft and fell off the bone and poached egg cooked perfectly.  My husband ordered the Meatballs + Curry & Fried Egg ($12) - was awesome! very flavorful and the paneer cheese was surprisingly good in the curry sauce.  I kept eating off his dish, I think we'll have to come back to get our own Meatball dish next time :)  We also tried the Liege Waffle ($14) - waffle was crispy and soft but the other dishes stood out more.  

Overall great service and food. Will I be back? Definitely would go back and can't wait to try their dinner services!
author: Yolanda G.

description:
Much love to Kris & Yuka. Such a lovely, friendly, open and warm couple. 
I want to see their labor of love thrive!

I've been meaning to come to Cassava for some brunch on weekends but I seem to be living at the studio these days (becoming a gym rat, aiiyahh!). When my foodie gals proposed a dinner here I immediately jumped on the chance. My review is strictly for f dinner and coffee. 

Cassava just recently started doing pop up dinners. They are by reservation only, so get on it!

We were a few minutes late for our reservation (curse you Outside Landers!) but we were warmly greeted Yuka. She understood that our beloved city was in a state of chaos (Outside Lands, Giants AND 49er game) and was way cool about our girlfriend being late as well. But!!! Please try to be on time.. Very small kitchen so meals need to be timed properly. 

The inside of Cassava is very cozy and inviting. Tiffany blue walls and inspirational messages all over. In the display window sits branches with ecosphere globes! Such a cute decoration! 

Okay but on to the food.

Amuse bouche: Burrata, Maldon sea salt, basil oil and sunflower seeds.  - I actually hate Burrata but ate most of this because it was GOOD. That basil oil was very refreshing.

English pea "salad" English pea "panna cotta" , fried chickpeas , nasturtium leaves, edamame, shiso flowers. - Sweet and delicately minty from the shiso flowers.

Minestrone. Clarified tomato & fennel broth, marinated pearl onions, tomato jam, cranberry beans - Uhmmmm LOVE. Lightest minestrone I've ever had and the beans were delicious. I don't know why I kept calling them garbanzo beans when it said CRANBERRY BEANS on the menu smack dab in front of me but  I want more. I found myself craving it last night.

Kurobuta porchetta. Berkshire pork belly 2 ways. L: sous-vide. R: w/ caramelized onion jam, jalapeño, "sunny side" quail egg, stewed apples and cauliflower purée - the sous-vide pork belly was mostly fat, not enough meat but the other one was perfect! Even ratio of meat and fat.

Intermezzo: Orange Lemon Granita. Orange lemon flavored ice. Sweet, light and refreshing. Reminded me of Japanese sodas. Delicious.

Branzino en papillote. Branzino, kale, oven dried tomato, wood ear mushrooms, olives and tomato beurre blanc. I found the olives to be a tad too salty for my liking but I loved the wood ear and kale. This sat underneath the branzino and sopped up all the lovely flavors of the fish. Doesn't look like much, but it was umami

Dessert: Nutella lemon curd pot de creme. Pate sucree cinnamon cookies, rosemary apricot preserve.  LOVELY!.


After all this, I could barely keep my eyes open. Had a soy honey latte which was really good but food coma won. I got home and gave up on packing for my 8am flight the next morning and KO'ed instead.

I'll be back!
author: Susy C.

description:
Cassava is the perfection addition to the Outer Richmond. It offers coffee, breakfast, lunch, and the occasional dinner. After having a wide sample of everything, there have been some hits and misses but the one constant is Yuka. She is always friendly and personable. If you cannot decide what to order she patiently explains the choices and offers recommendations without being pushy.

At Cassava I have tried: 

Peanut Butter Cornflake Cookie
Quiche Today
Caffe Latte
Randwich!
Shrimp + Avocado Sliders
Meat Balls + Curry
Patisserie Philippe Macaron
Diamant Cookie
March "Spring is Near!" Tasting Menu

The lunch items were delicious but a little pricy. The macarons were different from what I tired before. The center had a cream-like consistency sandwich between two super light and delicate cookies. I am a fan of macarons with more of a bite but these have a great flavor.

And for dinner I really enjoyed the tasting menu, which I had before the remodel. Seven courses for $52/person was very affordable. The portions were perfect - I left satisfied but not overstuffed. I am excited to return to see how it has expanded and changed after the remodel. 

What I recommend:
-- dinner tasting menu
author: Andrew W.

description:
In a word, spectacular!  A true gem in the neighborhood. I could eat a bucket of their fresh green salad with magical dressing.  Don't miss the lamb meatballs or the panna cotta with cardamom and caramel. Mmmm.  Delicious food matched with exquisite service and a delightful interior. 
We'll make the trek from Russian hill again!
author: Ashley F.

description:
I ventured over here with a girl friend to try out their brunch on a Saturday.  I had looked at the online menu and knew right away that I wanted to get the braised short rib hash.  I'm a big fan of corned beef hash, so this dish sounded perfect.

We had a reservations, so we were seated on time.  The restaurant was busy, so we patiently waited for a server to come by and take our order.  We ended up having to flag someone down.  We ordered the crab salad to share, I got the braised short rib hash and my friend got the Japanese breakfast.

The crab salad was basically crab meat sprinkled on top of a salad with blue cheese.  I generally love blue cheese on a salad, but it was a bit overpowering and it took away from the crab flavor.  My has looked really good when I got it.  But as I dug into it, there was way too much quinoa and not enough of the short ribs.  It was quite tasty, but just lacking in the meat department.  My friend liked her Japanese breakfast, but didn't care for the natto.  I had tried natto a while back, and warned her of the interesting taste and texture it had.  She was not a fan, but did like the rest of her meal.

This first visit wasn't a hit with me, but they do have other items on their brunch and dinner menu that look tempting.  I'll have to give this place another shot one day.
author: Patra I.

description:
I ordered the seared albacore dish from this restaurant.
Both me and my wife broke out with allergic reactions.
Except we are not allergic to albacore. And actually we dont have any allergies at all.
Im sure the restaurant has some goods points but MY EXPERIENCE was horrible.
So please stop removing my reviews.
People deserve to know that i was sick all night after I dined here. I can show you the receipt from my dining here and the receipt from the benedryl I purchased 2 hours later.
Please stop removing my reviews.
author: Mike J.

description:
This is truly one of my absolute favorite places to eat in the city!  Everything about this place I love!  I love that they take care of their customers, provide quality food with creativity and attention to detail with reasonable prices.  

I still remember my very first experience here shortly after they opened- I ordered a morning bun and Yuka asked if I wanted it warmed up.  I was thinking, oooh warm would be nice, so I answered yet.  However, when she brought over the morning bun, it was not warmed.  I was actually fine with it, but then Yuka realized and was immediately so sincerely apologetic, she brought out another morning bun that is warmed for me.  WOW, that is service right there.  After that incident and having had their delicious curry meatball dish, I wanted to go back to try other foods.  Went back within the same week with a friend, and Yuka was again super nice to us.  There were no more seats inside, so she seated us outside with a special tiny folding table.  Made us feel special :)  Another time I came with my fiance on a gloomy windy day, Yuka provided us blankets to wrap ourselves with when we sat and ate outside!  

Since then, I've been back many times and had the greatest pleasure with their dinner pop up tasting menu (before they expanded), which was soooo amazzing.  I was really blown away by the food that was put out without a real kitchen at the time.  I really miss that!  Now since they expanded and have outdoor heaters, I've been here for brunch/lunch and dinner altogether many times.  Never a time being disappointed!

For brunch, my favorite for a long time is their Mr. and Mrs. Croquette sandwich and curry meatballs.  Favorite drink is their honey spiced latte, so delicious!  Their new brunch menu item duck confit with salad is probably my new favorite because the duck was cooked so moist and tender, it just fell off the bone.  Hmmmm.  Fiance always orders their fresh juice and though we've tried everything on their menu, we always end up going back.  
Favorite dinner items is their pop up dinner menu ( boo no more ) brined chicken, short ribs, and panna cotta!

Wait time is not as long as other brunch places in the city and you can make reservations in advance.  If you drop in, they do text you when a table is ready for you. Every friend that I've recommended this place to has good things to say.
author: Iris H.

description: This place is always busy but they seat you and serve you really quick. I ordered the curry meatballs with rice. It was the best rice I ever had and the meatballs with tofu and curry was so good. The lavender panna cota was light and refreshing. So worth it. I finished the meal with a bourbon vanilla mocha had so much flavor. I could have a cup of that every morning
author: Jeremiah S.

description: Brunch was delicious. Four stars because the high volume seemed too busy for the staff at times, and I didn't like their water. I would go again but maybe not on a Sunday afternoon. They offer outdoor and indoor seating. I was able to text and make my reservations. You will need a reservation due the the high volumes they may experience at certain times. Their waffles are honestly the best I've ever had! You don't need syrup but add some and it tastes like heaven in your mouth!
author: Dee F.

description:
Holy Smoked Fish of Amazing Good Food. If you're ever in SF, do yourself a favor and do not be a tourist and head over here. This is the best breakfast yummy place I have ever eaten in my life. As a self proclaimed Food Lover extraordinare, I have never fallen in love with food so fast as I did here. See my review right below!

I had the japanese breakfast and it is by far the best breakfast ever. I honestly dont remember the items I ate because my mouth was having palette orgasm. Thats how good it was. The smoked fish (add ob) was the most tastiest smoked fish ever. It didnt leave that pungent fish oil taste in your mouth and was cured to perfection. The side seaweed soup was amazeballs. Like seaweed soup, you would think eh but this one was WHAAAAT THE F AM I EATING LET ME SWIM IN THIS SOUP!!! I dont even know the other three side dishes but they were equally amazing balls as wells. This is how happy I am folks. I cant even describe what I ate because my mouth has beeb traumatized by the simple yet holy sh!t amazing food. YUM YUM YUMMMNNMMMMMM
author: Danica S.

description: Delicious brunch spot! Can't wait to go back and try dinner menu. Highly recommend the liege waffle, Japanese breakfast and meatball curry!
author: Helen Y.

description:
Cassava is a fresh-faced establishment for good eating and calmly sweet aesthetic design.

It's well-appreciated as a breakfast and brunch spot, boasting a small and well-executed menu with something for everyone.

I have tried two different dishes: the Japanese Breakfast and the Maple Liege Waffle Plate.

Unfortunately, the Japanese Breakfast is not to my taste. It was not a bad meal, it just wasn't the meal for me. I would say the only negative thing I could truly say about the meal is that there may be too much rice served with it for a breakfast. I think a smaller portion of rice is a better balance.  The parts of the Japanese Breakfast that I definitely did enjoy were the poached egg, the miso soup (full of good bits and bites), and the additional seared albacore. My least favorite part was the Meyer lemon "kosho" natto. I have no doubt it's very much an acquired taste and texture. The friend who recommended this place to me loves the Japanese Breakfast. It seems to be a popular item, so obviously it's well-enjoyed. Just not by me.

The Maple Liege Waffle Plate, on the other hand, might have been one of the best breakfasts I had during my little vacation. Everything presented on this plate was perfect. The perfectly textured scrambled egg with a little bit of runny egg in it resulting in some of the most tender and tasty scrambled egg I've put in my mouth. The not sweet but not too savory waffle. The thick and crisp and chewy bacon.  The combination of ricotta and rhubarb compote and the fruit. Even the little addition of salad was welcome. It was just a balanced breakfast of flavor, texture, presentation, and deliciousness.

With either orange juice or a green tea, I felt pretty satisfied. I love the look of the place and the look of my more traditional area breakfast choice, and I love the way they execute and present their meals. Definitely an enjoyable breakfast spot in the Outer Richmond.
author: Cate T.

description:
Even though I'm giving this place a 3-star for now, I'm willing to try it again, only because I knew going in I was ordering a japanese dish not from an actual japanese restaurant. I think this restaurant's concept is world cuisines, their menu is pretty interesting. 

I ordered their japanese breakfast and wish I had ordered their hash. The breakfast itself hit the spot, but flavors and texture were a bit off. Here's what I got in it:

Poached egg - pretty good, though not special at all and I had egg shells in mine, oops
Rice sprinkled w/ light sea salt - nicely done, wish they put a bit of crunch on top to up the texture
Tuna - very good, totally satisfied
pickled cucumber/sprouts - nicely done
Seaweed/kelp of some sort - nicely done, though nothing special 
Natto - from reading a few reviews, I knew this is a dish that's not everyone's cup of tea, but I just had to try. I know this comes with a lot of nutrients so I ate most of mine, but I'd never order it again. I'm fine with the texture, but the bitterness was something I couldn't appreciate at all
Miso soup - was this supposed to be miso? not sure, but not great

Again, willing to try Cassava again for something they are actually good at. I've heard good things about other menu items, like the meatball.
author: Jackie C.

description: I really liked the ambiance and food here. The service was very attentive despite what a small restaurant it was and you can also see the kitchen which is really neat! The restaurant serves its water in cute little mason jars and the ingredients seemed very fresh. I got a pesto sandwich that I thought was really good. My friend had the waffle and thought the waffle was only ok but the pork was very good. Regardless, I think it is a brunch place worth trying!
author: Jocelyn K.

description:
Cute place, but sadly I was not a fan of the very limited breakfast/brunch menu, or the Japanese Breakfast I ordered. 

The Japanese Breakfast was a cute assortment of little dishes, very elegantly presented. It's probably an acquired taste, but besides the miso soup and cucumbers, the rest of the dishes had very unique tastes and textures, and my taste buds just did not agree with them.
author: An Y.

description:
This place is always great!!! The owner is a very cheerful lady and great to chat with! If you have questions just ask and they will help you choose a great meal. Pet friendly, kid friendly and fun! They have a promo for brunch on Saturday were if you wear a cat, you get a free drink. 

Will post photos soon but the porchetta is the best and their spiced honey latte is yummy! Go and try them at least once! I bet you can't only go once ;)
author: Miguel D.

description:
I began my Sunday morning working in the outer Richmond district. Before my work, I landed at one of the newest bakery and newest business in the city, only opened in the beginning of March of 2012.

Early morning can sometimes be a drag, man. As I checked-in to the newest bakery with my phone, I also saw a check-in deal for a free small brownie bites on the screen. As soon as I saw the deal, the smiling Joe Cool (me) showed the deal from my phone to the cute lady behind the counter. "Man, don't you love technology and Yelp?"

Then she gave the bag of brownie bites to start my breakfast. My free treat: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/muX0aRES6vsp5DEuJaW_uw?select=uMbdBeMO6Rl9vnPwaZ1LiQ

After my free treat, I ordered Blueberry Cream Cheese Danish and a needed small cup of coffee. The $3.25 Danish was fresh in the early morning and my "strong" cup of Joe was made with Ritual Roasters coffee-a local coffee company. My second straight reviewed business that offer the Ritual Roasters Coffee Company (Cinderella Bakery is the other business). My breakfast: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/muX0aRES6vsp5DEuJaW_uw?select=TgDvOnhWiCFqQ-sRT6KH4g

As I was enjoying my morning treat, I was observing the Meyers Lemon Preserve located underneath the pastry counter. The same cute lady said the homemade preserve is used in their salads and sandwiches, which used SemiFreddi's bread for their sandwiches. I might try the sandwich with the exclusive preserve next time. 

One of the newest bakery and businesses along Asian-friendly Balboa Street is a hit. Joe Cool will be back!
author: Matt G.

description: 2 stars for service because they are super nice. Maybe I didn't order the right things but the food that I got was not very good to say the least. The fish and rice dish was so salty that it was bitter (fish) so did t eat that. The egg sandwich was meh - too much and also salty.
author: Lena T.

description:
What's so special about this place that it has 4 stars? I like cute neighborhood places but there were few things on the menu that appealed to me. What I did order was nothing special. The kind of nothing special that makes me want to go to Jack in the Box after and get a sourdough jack.

I also noticed that after the mediocre meal I had, they didn't even bother to credit me for making a reso through Opentable. 0 points even though my date and I showed up on time (just before they opened, our reso was at 10am), ate, and paid.

I won't be going back.
author: Yelper F.

description:
I had bookmarked this place for almost a year. Close by neighborhood cafe with cute pictures on Yelp. Very rare in outer Richmond. Before they expanded I would drive by and notice their 3 tables full. Today however thought it was my lucky day. Looked half empty, and yay-parking right in front. No time to sit and eat but let's just run in grab a menu and drink to check it out. 

Like other yelpers commented on the configuration seemed feng shui wrong-ordering /seating /two different condiment tables. One which stood right by the door. 

Anyway do not despair.... Let's order!  The small menu board behind the cashier in tiny writing included food options and inspirational quotes like being nice and kind. 

Ordered Hibiscus Rosewater Spritzer -$3.50 sounds fancy and refreshing.... Light on ice please. I almost always ask for this as 
1- ice dilutes my drinks 2- we live in freakin outer Richmond !  It's cold out here 

As I wait for my drink I flip through their cafe book. Oh cool I thought. Maybe it's a recipe book. Nope it was filled with pictures of the staff and close up of pantry items... Strange. What's that about?  Why would I want a book with your face making coffee. 

Asian lady hands drink to me (I think others may have called her dragon lady. ) As I head out I noticed my drink looks half empty ?  I turn around she thinks I'm looking for lid. I say "um don't you guys fill it up? " This is a 16 oz cup folks for $3.50 mind you. Let me ask you fair minded yelpers-as a person with common customer service sense would you reply:

A) oh I can fill it up for you with a smile 
B) make up some BS like the recipe calls for the portion with less ice 
C) offer to give money back with attitude 

Answer: B &C. 

I could not believe it. Cassava. Why are you so cheap ? What recipe do you have for this glorious special drink that you can't just proportionately fill up drink in place of ice. I mean aesthetically it's just wrong. It's like ordering a burger and some one takes a bite and hands it to you. I was so shocked at her answer and the offer to give me my $ if I wasn't happy. Yes I wasn't happy. Use your common sense. Is this how you should treat a new customer. Won't be back and would not recommend. So pretentious from the photo book to their overpriced drink menu. Wanna be hipster place. I really wanted to like and come back and try the food. But with the service it's clear new customers aren't important.
author: Sam S.

description:
I'm impressed that a restaurant finally ventured into Japanese breakfast! I only wish there were more options for Japanese-style. The set they have is a pretty good start though. We came here around 11am on Saturday and were just able to snag a seat at the bar before they filled up.

:: Spiced honey latte - signature. must try, at least once! I can't really describe it...a bit sweet, a bit spiced, but not too much of either. Unlike any other latte I've tried.
:: Hibiscus Glazed Pork Ribs "Hash" Bowl - tasted as good as it sounds.
:: Japanese breakfast set (natto optional) - great spread of small dishes such as seared albacore, miso soup, pickles, and of course a soft poached egg. By the way, natto is a fermented soybean that is a bit of an acquired taste. Everything was on point!

Some of their other brunch dishes looked amazing as well, and I'd love to come back to try them! If only it weren't so far out by the beach, I'd be here much more often for sure.
author: Audrey L.

description:
I LOVE ALL THINGS CUTE...

CUTE couple.

CUTE bakery.

CUTE delectable treats.

This is Cassava Bakery + Café.

With its grand opening today, I passed by Cassava this morning on my way to work to grab some treats for my co-workers. I would be lying if my primary reason wasn't to get the FTR which someone beat me to it already. SHUCKS. 

Owned by the cute couple, Kris (former Sous Chef at one Michelin starred Luce http://www.yelp.com/biz/luce-san-francisco#hrid:i3TQ5u3zindDGaBdfZAitQ) and Yuka is this cute bakery + café resembling a contemporary yet rustic country nook. 

Sharing is caring so in an effort to make my co-workers as "fluffy" as I am, I bought chocolate chips cookies, chocolate croissants, and morning buns. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/muX0aRES6vsp5DEuJaW_uw?select=btBlBF4-YnQXFiQWtywWEg And, ummm...as the Queen of Clumsiness, I decided to reward myself for surviving the weekend unscathed with the mushroom quiche. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/muX0aRES6vsp5DEuJaW_uw?select=1aJrJF2sPR8pF9SCdC7MOw The mushroom quiche was AMAZING!!! The crust was rich and flaky, the egg mushroom concoction was as fluffy as can be and made even more mouthwatering with the topping of oooeeey goeeeey cheese. 

How did my coworkers like the "fluffy" inducing treats? 

"You're sabotaging my diet!" *grabs chocolate croissant*
"What are you trying to do to my waist line?!?!?" *snatches the last morning bun*
"How many Weight Watchers point is this?" *takes second chocolate chip cookie*

MISSION ACCOMPLISHED. MUWAHAHAHAHAHAAA 

OTHER NOTES:
*Soups, Salads, Sandwiches, and Ritual Roosters Coffee are also available
*Three small tables for two
*CASH ONLY for now until they get their CC system working
author: Cherylynn N.

description: I LOVE the Duck Liver Mousse, its so savory yet at the same time, there's a distinct taste that you can't really describe with words. Me and my girlfriend got the Sea Bass and Pork Belly, it was super good and worth every penny! Service is also way up there, my girlfriend is allergic to seafood and could not eat the Octopus in the Pork Belly Entree, the waiter gladly changed modified it to two portion of pork belly instead. Our waiter was also courteous and patient, made us feel very comfortable when we dined!
author: Ken H.

description:
Never been to a Japanese brunch place before and as soon as I arrived, I fell in love with the decor and aesthetics of this adorable, modern little spot! My aunt and uncle told me about this place and so my uncle and I went on a Saturday morning. Luckily, we got there right before the crowd of customers. 

A young Japanese couple run the place and the wife came and took our order which was pretty awesome because she was personable and warm, which made the experience of eating there so much more enjoyable! She chatted with her customers making conversation, and I thought that was delightful! It feels like the perfect brunch spot for a lazy Saturday or Sunday morning. 

I got the Japanese Breakfast and a spiced honey latte, while my uncle got the meatballs+curry and fried egg. Every plate of food that came out looked so delicious though! My meal was very simple and delicious and my latte was so good! I can't get over how beautiful this place is and how simply good the service and food is as well! The only downside I would say is how pricey it is, but despite the pricing, I will be back again! I highly recommend this place if you want to try something different from an all American breakfast! I also want to come back to try lunch and dinner on the weekdays and weekend to see if it is just as great.
author: Christina C.

description: This is one of my favorite places in the city and one of the first places I made my own when I moved to San Francisco. I no longer live in the Richmond district, so am not able to make it here as often, but I swear Yuka remembers my name every time I come in (even if it's sometimes five-six months between visits). The food is incredible and it's a consistent staple for recommendations when a friend is visiting SF or needs a great date spot idea.
author: Jordan S.

description:
Let's start with the food. I had the Liege Waffles with Ricotta. It. Was. Great.

The waffles were perfectly done -- consistently crunchy on the outside, warm and tender on the inside. Sweet but not drowning in syrup and cream. The only complaint is that I don't like the pineapple on it, but that's simply because I dislike pineapple.

The eggs were very well-seasoned. Normally when I go to brunch places I find myself needing to douse my eggs in ketchup. Not so here. Well salted, fluffy, and all around delicious.

The salad was good but seemed a little out of place and honestly could have been better. The bacon was good. No complaints there. Normal bacon.

What stops this place from being great? The wait time. I waited nearly 40-50 minutes for a table of 3. Ridiculous. Work on that and this place could become amazing.
author: Jaehak Y.

description: Came here for breakfast with a friend and we immediately fell in love with the cute vibe. She ordered the continental breakfast and I had their Japanese set. Their food didn't disappoint although I felt it was a bit on the pricier side.
author: Valerie F.

description: Wish this was better and lived up to the reviews. Perhaps it was an off night - we ordered variety from the menu. Across the board, the food was just ok. Nothing that exceeded our expectations.
author: Maya F.

description:
TLDR: Looks great, but food is bland.

Pros:
- great decor/atmosphere
- vanilla panna cotta is great!
- spiced honey latte is pretty good

Cons:
- slow service (we waited almost an hour for our food to arrive at our table)
- bland bland bland

My friends and I came on a Sunday for brunch. We ordered the panna cotta, liege waffles, the japanese breakfast, spiced honey lattes, and meat and tofu in curry sauce.

Our favorite was the panna cotta, with the meatballs and tofu in curry sauce coming up second. Everything else we felt was bland. The waffle tasted like plain bread with no flavor - the jam and ricotta cheese didn't really help. I asked for 2 eggs over medium and got 2 hard eggs instead. My friend had to add salt and pepper to her japanese breakfast, and the meatballs and tofu in curry sauce reminded us of spaghetti sauce and meatballs. 

In my honest opinion, I wouldnt come back for brunch. I might come back for coffee, pastries, and the panna cotta, but not for a meal. Everything looked appetizing, but the flavor and taste was not there. It also took a long time for our food to arrive at our table.
author: Annie L.

description:
Ohh Cassava, I've believed in you. Maybe my expectations was too high or I just have horrible timing...

I've came here the other day and didn't know reservations was expected for Cassava. But luckily, there were available seats along the kitchen area. The hostess didn't even recommend the outdoor seatings for us. We came around 6:45pm and the entire time we were there, no one sat outside! And it didn't seem that she wanted to have us there, maybe because we looked like young kids? I don't know, but I ignored the horrible vibe I was getting since I only came here for the food!

We ordered:
STARTERS
- Chips + Dip: It's kettle chips and a dip. Nothing special.

- "Barbeque" Pork Ribs: This was the HIGHLIGHT of the dinner meal. It's not the expected southern version of heavy barbeque sauce, but a more asian version. It's a hibiscus & apple cider glazed, topped with coleslaw (kimchi and bean sprouts). The meat just falls off the bones when you bite into it. Trust me, it's is mouth-drooling! (This should totally be an entree than a starter)

ENTREES
- Pan Seared Polenta Cake: It's okay. I was hoping it would be more flavorful. Presentation is a five stars though!

- Rib Eye + Fork "Smashed Potatoes": There was a huge chunk of FAT on one end of a slice. I'm not a fan, but there are some people out there that are. The veggies that came with it was delicious. However, the rib eye was bland... It needed salt and pepper.

DESSERTS
- Bread pudding: Pipping hot and delicious! Take a forkful of the bread pudding then dip a little whipped cream and add some citrus fruits onto it = SUMMER IN MY MOUTH! You must eat it with all the ingredients; otherwise, it's going to be plain.

-Chocolate Mousse: Chocolate by itself is rich. But with the kumquats, citrus, and bits of almond cookies is delish! 


I shall give you another chance...But I should definitely check the menu online first before going. (I was hoping the curry meatball was on the menu, but sadly it wasn't...)
author: Jane C.

description:
Loved this little gem!
Great food, beautiful presentation, low key and simple but classy design. 
Took the recommendation for Continental breakfast and honey spiced latte-delicious!
author: Meghan S.

description: Excellent food, excellent service, excellent environment, excellent everything. It's a very cozy restaurant to pick up a nice breakfast/lunch and it's definitely nice to sit and enjoy the inside. Everyone who works there is very friendly, constantly asking how your food is doing or just getting to know you. Food was great, I had the meatball+tofu curry w/ rice and it was very tasty. Great place to eat and I would definitely recommend and come back.
author: Kyle L.

description:
I can only comment on the Japanese breakfast and the sangria. Mrs. Spike had waffles and eggs and really enjoyed them, but I can't eat the waffles due to dietary issues.

So back to the Japanese breakfast. Jeez it's hard to find good Japanese breakfast in San Francisco and this one is good and priced right. Not as good as the ones I ate in Japan, but plenty good. And the sangria is very tasty. Definitely going back.
author: Spike S.

description:
Still my favorite spot in the city. There are fancier places, there are cheaper places, there are closer places... but Cassava is exactly what I want in a neighborhood restaurant - comfortably casual, but with an elevated menu and overall experience. I wish I lived close enough to be a regular!

The service is always super friendly, and (thanks to an over-indulgent birthday meal with friends) have now enjoyed everything on the menu. The duck liver mousse and pork never disappoint, and the seafood, salads, and starters all hit the mark as well. Keep an eye out for the tongue-in-cheek wallpaper, as well as other small details sprinkled throughout the cozy space that give it a warmly welcoming, lived-in feel.

Definitely one of my go-to spots for out of town guests, especially after an afternoon at Ocean Beach or Lands End.
author: Daron H.

description:
When my previous brunch plans fell through at the last minute, Cassava saved my Sunday.  After searching through pages and pages of San Franciscan brunch oases, they were able to take a reservation at a reasonable hour, and they offered up an interesting menu to boot.

The restaurant is adorable. There's lots of decorative charm, from the giant chalkboard mural along the back wall (which, according to its signature, has survived an impressive amount of time) to the baby-blue paint job to the table markers that ingeniously use playing cards instead of numbers.  I'm a huge fan of the list of specials next to the bar, which rewards patrons for dressing like cats and drinking wine on a weeknight.

The brunch menu has a fairly small number of options, but each of them sounded delicious.  The standout is the full Japanese breakfast, which serves hearty portions of rice, seaweed, and other East Asian staples.  I opted for the short rib "hash" while my sister ordered the waffle plate.

The waitress was very friendly, offering to swap out the bacon on the waffle plate for a more vegetarian-friendly avocado serving.  And by "serving," I mean an entire scooped-and-sliced avocado that looked like it must have weighed ten pounds.  In fact, the entire plate was a sight - and a bite - to behold.  These are not the tasteless waffles you get for free when you stay at a Holiday Inn.  They're hearty, sweet, and decadent.

At first glance, I was disappointed by my hash.  The quinoa looked out of place, the poached egg was a tad overcooked, and the two short ribs were just thrown on top whole, bone and all.  I was about to raise an eyebrow, but such skepticism was unnecessary.  These ribs redefined "fall off the bone" tender.  The bones were so clean afterwards, I could have used them to perform surgery.  The hash ended up being just as delicious as it was unique; a far cry from the greasy, sloppy mess many similar dishes can become.

A ridiculously-decadent chocolate mousse and a trio of delicious outsourced macarons ended a great meal.  I would have preferred if my hash was a bit warmer, and some acid treatment on the avocados might have helped their plate appearance; the side facing me was an unappetizing shade of gray-brown by the time it was served.  These are just minor issues, though, and I can't wait to try this place again.  Maybe for dinner and weeknight wine...
author: Eric W.

description:
It was my first time to this place. I went for dinner with my friends. Very nice space with huge glass window. The food had nice presentation. I loved the rib starter. The meat is so soft and juicy. I ordered the seared albacore and my friends ordered the scallop and pork. The overall experience in the restaurant was ok, beside it was kind of a long wait for the food to come. 

When I first had a bite, I felt some tingly sensation under my tongue, but I ignored. I only had 3 pieces then I didn't feel like having anymore. 

The nightmare came after I got home. It was about 1-2 hours later when I started to feel headache and burning aches over my body. I thought I was just tired and needed to rest. But soon, my husband noticed my face was red and swollen like a balloon and my eyes were so red too. My heartbeat started to rise. I was scared. I have only had 2 slices of the albacore, the rest I took home for my husband. I don't have any kind of allergies in my life. And I eat everything. Nothing like this ever happened. Soon, my body was covered with big red patches along my arm and belly. My hands were shaking, my heartbeat continued to get faster, my breathing was more difficult. I almost passed out. My husband had to rush to the pharmacy to get Benadryl. In the meanwhile, I tried to throw up and drank a ton of water, the symptoms lasted for about 45min. I thought it was just me, but my husband ate the rest of the fish after I got home. After I finally got better, his face started to swollen like mine.....then I was certain it was the fish. 

I have had albacore numerous times in my life, both raw and cooked. I never had any reaction. This was like a life threatening experience to me. Maybe I was unlucky, or maybe their seafood was just not fresh...but WATCH OUT!! Do not order the fish... I don't know if I would ever go back to the restaurant again.
author: Honeybee W.

description:
This is such a cute little shop!! It's petite and has a slightly old fashioned theme. The staff is polite and friendly and quite quick with service. 

I got the waffle with eggs, bacon, and a mixed greens. It was a pretty big plate and I was super full after finishing it. Their waffle had an interesting mix of flavors, their eggs perfectly soft, bacon well crisp, and the small salad was seasoned just right. 

It's somewhat pricey but it's worth the atmosphere. I'd definitely go here again!
author: Adrianne T.

description: We absolutely LOVED this place!! We couldn't decide what breakfast dish to order so we went for BOTH and shared. We chose the waffle dish and ham sandwich breakfast plate. We did not regret it whatsoever!!! Soooo good! This place is so quaint and the service is excellent! Don't miss out!!
author: Gab C.

description:
I came here for Saturday brunch with a friend and was immediately in love with this place right when I set foot in it! A clear, sunny SF day, the doors and windows were open, which created a very welcoming and light atmosphere. There were also small vases of cute flowers at every table. I also loved seeing the different ties the waitresses had -- it was so hip and cute at the same time! They also serve you your beverage in jars / water in wine bottles -- a nice touch to the whole "hip and cute" theme. :)

I ordered the Mr and Mrs Croque sandwich, which came with a fresh side of salad. The salad was very well dressed and just the right amount. The sandwich itself was generous with its portions of turkey and roast beef, and the egg was cooked perfectly. The bread was also very thick and toasted well, which held everything together nicely. I also added the avocado for an extra $1, and it really was the cherry on top! I was very full after my meal -- though I really wanted to try their desserts. Next time!

The waitresses were also very friendly and attentive throughout our stay, and even though there was a line forming outside, they never made us feel rushed. I highly recommend this place and will definitely be back again for brunch! :)
author: Hurnan V.

description:
Came here twice for lunch time. 
Today I had a tuna melt and it was super salty so i had to keep drinking water... Other than that, It is cute and clean spot.
author: Iris C.

description:
Where to begin? This was the first SF brunch that I had after moving here from MN, and I couldn't have had a better experience. 

AMBIANCE: Contemporary, warm, sunny. Beautiful decorating. And any place that gives you free dessert for wearing cat attire on a Saturday gets an A in my book. Ensue the "crazy cat lady" comments; whatever. 

COFFEE: The spiced honey latte is something not from this world. GET IT. It should come with its own mini red carpet - it's that damn good. And the best part? Our lovely waitress brought a free one to go and said, "Welcome to the neighborhood," after learning I just moved. 

FOOD: The Mr. & Mrs. Croque sandwich is phenomenal. Pesto and crunch and a melange of amazing flavors, I'm literally counting down the hours until my next one. We got the liege waffle also, which was equally mouthwatering. 

SERVICE: Excellent and not pretentious as some others have said. 

Make this your go-to brunch spot in the Richmond!
author: Alli H.

description:
It was the enthusiastic applause for a local restaurant that initially drew us here, but contrary to the darling table photos posted, I saw no flowers. This is a small, nondescript restaurant with mediocre food. My sandwich arrived alone on a plate, no garnish, sloppily put together--simply toasted white bread with an egg and a basil spread. Unimpressive taste, runny egg.  Note: The orange juice here is made from concentrate.

Tables emptied but weren't always cleared (diners sitting beside us pointed that out to their server). Sadly, a disappointing experience, nothing like previous reviewers' glowing reports. Maybe I should have ordered the quiche?
author: Lynn S.

description:
Bottomline: HORRIBLY unprofessional service, BUGS IN FOOD, and BEWARE, the restaurant owner may violate your privacy and leave a Yelp comment with your FULL NAME if you leave an undesirable review (which violates Yelp's Content Guidelines)

Issue 1: Two of us went for brunch on Mother's Day. The restaurant was only 70-75% full yet we were seated ~15 minutes past our reservation time with no explanation or apology 

Issue 2: Salad was nothing special except, wait for it, BUGS! My friend had a particularly enthusiastic FLY buzzing around under the leaves of lettuce and I discovered a oddly energetic WORM squirming in a pool of dressing. We didn't want to make a scene and politely flagged down the waiter to have him remove the insect-infested salads. The waiter half-heartedly apologized and joked, "the chef says 'at least you know it's fresh'". No one from the staff even offered to provide us with the alternate appetizer to compensate for the bug-salad. After we raised this concern, that was the last we saw of our waiter or any wait staff for that matter. They seemed to have just given up on us assuming we wouldn't tip well due to the fact that our salads already had bugs in them (heck, right?)

Issue 3: The restaurant owners and staff are incredibly UNACCOMMODATING and downright RUDE to handicapped/disabled people. I have a broken ankle (we're talking BROKEN, like screws, metal plate, wrapped in a bright red cast) and went in with my crutches. 1) No one from the restaurant offered me a seat to sit while waiting for our table (past our reservation time). Instead, a kind customer waiting to be seated saw me and pulled out a seat for me to sit so I wouldn't have to balance on one leg the entire time. 2) My ankle needs to be elevated so my friend and I asked to use a chair for a neighboring table since they were a party of 3 with 4 chairs. The neighboring table didn't mind at all and willingly let us have the chair to rest my ankle on. Once the party of 3 left the restaurant, the hostess literally, I kid you not, removed the chair from beneath my ankle, placed it back at the empty 4-person table, and walked away without even offering another chair to prop my ankle on. The restaurant was NOT full so there were empty chairs that weren't being used. My friend had to flag someone down to ask for another chair since the one I was using was literally taken from under me. This treatment was just appalling as I've been out to dine at restaurants many times while I've been injured and restaurant staff have always been very accommodating. However, the people at Cassava weren't just unaccommodating, they were aggressively rude and alienating about my injury. I can't imagine going back with an elderly person with a cane or a someone in a wheelchair. Who knows what mistreatment the rude people at Cassava will subject them to?

Issue 4: To make matters worse, my friend who I was dining with left a review about the restaurant documenting our extremely horrific experience. Immediately thereafter, the owner of Cassava left a passive aggressive comment on my friend's review and DISCLOSED MY FRIEND'S FULL NAME. This is a huge violation of not only my friend's privacy, but also Yelp's Content Guidelines as business owners are not allowed to publicize private information, especially full names. Makes me wonder what else this business owner is capable of doing with customer's private information. It's also just pathetic to publicize confidential information like a customer's full name in a sad attempt to get back at the customer and taint his/her reputation. LBR, the truth hurts and the truth is, Cassava service and food absolutely BLOWS.
author: L W.

description:
12.22.13

Quaint, cozy neighborhood spot.  Clean and quiet, perfect for a catch up session with an old friend.

You order at the counter and choose your seat.  I guess I had underestimated the time it would take to make a "Something Nice" - sparking wine, orange juice, Carpano Antica, and Byrrh.  Not your average mimosa, for sure; the additional ingredients take out most of the fizz and bubbles that I tend to enjoy.  But, with an open kitchen where you can see the magic happens, the show is almost as good as the drink.

I had the Japanese Breakfast - Koshihikari rice, ichiban dashi miso soup, sous vide "onsen tamago" poached egg, Meyer lemon "kosho" natto, daikon wakame salad,  and market pickles.  My favorite part was the egg, which I promptly broke over the rice and washed it down with the soup.  It tastes light but is filling at the same time, as evidenced by the remains of my plate (I had about 30% left when I was done).

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cassava-san-francisco?select=QrkLH4DQS18N0qnei5MHiw#QrkLH4DQS18N0qnei5MHiw

Overall, I understand the concept, but was not blown away.

Total damage for two: $39.10
author: Jenny L.

description:
Cassava is unique and delicious.  The service is off par for the dead beat service of most other Outer Rich spots. Most other spots are dirty and dated where Cassava is more representative of the SF reputation of quality.  

We love eating here and have never been disappointed.  Flavored, wine and excellent service.
author: Gretchen G.

description:
This place is great! We went here for brunch and had a nice experience. The service is awesome: I was silly and thought my drink had champagne in it, it did NOT, but they were sweet enough to pour a little cava into my spritzer! Such a nice touch.

The food was great as well, lots of choices and portion sizes don't make you want to sleep after. It's a good mix of variety but small enough menu that you know they take food seriously. 

Almond milk latte was delicious as well!
author: Nicolette L.

description:
Some good, bordering on great, food but terrible, incompetent service.  To start, my thimble of coffee in a wide flat saucer was cold before I could get it to my mouth.  Ordered the liege waffle, maple ricotta and eggs and my wife got the mr. and mrs. croque.  Proceeded to wait 45 minutes for our food.  Numerous people seated after us and served before us.  Had trouble getting servers' attention, despite being seated at the bar, almost on top of the kitchen.  When it finally arrived, mine was...awesome!  Perfectly cooked, creamy scrambled eggs and a delicious, not too sweet, waffle.  Crispy, melt in your mouth bacon.  One of the better breakfasts I've had in years.  The croque...meh.  Plain, small, and unremarkable.   Service problems continued trying to keep servers from taking our plates while we were eating, then trying to get someone's attention to get the check.  

The moral:  you can cook the best food but if you can't serve it consistently, professionally, and on time, it doesn't matter a lick.
author: Paul E.

description: I thought the food was great/ atmosphere great. Only thing, the service was kind of rude when my sister was asking about something for her dietary needs. She has Celiacs and is vegetarian and the server told her they don't customize orders. So beware if you have food allergies. I recommend you go somewhere else.
author: Tanuki T.

description:
Cassava is a small, cute eatery, nothing wrong about that. i prefer eateries with a bit of elbow room. (maybe it's just the china bull in me, need room to roam).

surprised they were open. didn't plan to eat here. as an afterthought, grabbed some baked goods.

eats: macaroons (5/$9 or @2)
-delicate cookie crust
-filling had a greasy feel, 
-flavors subtle, not overwhelming, maybe organic? 
nice texture

crumbs:
-accidentally bumped into a glass water container
from the top of the table it dropped to the floor, didn't break upon impact
*container bounced off floor and broke the 2nd time it hit the floor.
*surprised i knocked the container over, didn't notice it
also surprised i didn't caught it on the bounce.  
-feeling bad about the water bottle
us whales need room to maneuver, maybe that's why i dislike small shops.
author: Victor G.

description: I had the Japanese breakfast and the cured trout tasted awful and was off and slimy. Service was rude and unhelpful. Sad as the breakfast itself was nice, what a let down Cassava :(
author: Becks H.

description:
It is nice to have a hip little spot with creative food in a sea of grungy dim sum and Mexican restaurants. Not that I don't love those too! There's a time and a place. 
Had the Randwich here and loved it! Pricey but very tasty. Want to go back and try some more menu items soon!
author: Sam A.

description: Cute little restaurant. Stripped down menu, but with lots of good options. I ended up getting something small, just an appetizer, but the burrata with peaches, almonds, and strawberries was one of the best dishes I had during a weeklong trip to San Francisco. Combined with a great atmosphere and good wine, it was a great experience.
author: Jake V.

description: An awesome brunch / lunch find in Outer Richmond with an awesome ambiance + vibe! The Spiced Honey Latte and Bourbon Vanilla Mocha are must tries for coffee lovers and I really enjoyed the waffles for brunch. Such a cool spot. Hope to return on my next trip to SF!
author: Natalie H.

description: Nice brunch spot with a group of ppl who have different tastes.  I was a little confused with the Japanese dish along with other more typical dishes first, but I figured this can please many more ppl in group brunch situation :-)  I didn't have the Japanese dish, but everything we had was delicious.
author: Harue J.

description:
We were originally going to go elsewhere for brunch, but after seeing the large crowd waiting outside, we called an audible and ended up at this place, and I'm glad that we did.

We got here in the early afternoon on a Sunday, and we only had to wait about 10-15 minutes for a table to open up. They have a set brunch menu that has a couple of different appetizers and main courses. One friend got the smoked trout hash, and me and my other friend split the maple liege waffle plate. Both plates were really good, as were the coffees that we ordered. All in all, a pretty good place for weekend brunch with reasonable prices.
author: Wayne H.

description: Food was delicious and beautiful. Flavors had depth and creativity. Plating was lovely. Decor, ambiance, and service was welcoming. Overall experience was transcendent.
author: Rebecca C.

description: This is a hip little spot for sure! My biggest complaint is that they missed our appetizer and when they were reminded they brought out what looked to be half of what they served everyone else. Seems like they should have comp'd it for a check of $368. Overall seemed pricier than the listed $$ on Yelp. Party of 5 with normal orders and roughly 2 drinks each. Food was nice but small portions, so the men wanted to go get burritos after.
author: Amber U.

description:
Great brunch place with super friendly staff! Came by at 2pm on a Sunday and it was still crowded, but thankfully no wait. Got a delicious honey spiced latte ($4) and the carrot farro soup ($8). The soup came with some pea shoots and toasted quinoa, and had a great crunchy yet fine texture to the thick soup, very satisfying. My friend got the japanese breakfast, which had the sexiest poached egg I'd ever seen. When cut, the yolk oozed out, but more viscous than a runny sunny side up. Awesome. Turns out they sous vide the suckers, and one of the owners was happy to share their settings to create their "onsen" tamago, but also suggested how I could approximate it just by boiling (thanks for the tip!). She later asked us politely after clearing our dishes if we would be willing move in order to seat a family of 7 waiting to dine before they close. Of course that was no problem; we still wanted to check out the dessert menu. There was some intriguing stuffs listed there, but I didn't wanna over stuff myself, so opted to save it for another day. She still brought out a pair of macarons to say thanks for moving - woohoo, and they were quite tasty, too! They had a somewhat denser soft chew to them than others I've had elsewhere, yet with a lightly crisp exterior despite being chilled, and came with a nice layer of cream filing. May have to try their macaron sampler dessert plate next time!

They've come a long way since I first recall stepping through their door. They doubled in size roughly a year ago  - totally missed their Kickstarter around that. Pretty awesome that the community rallied around them to pull it off. Next time I stop on by I'm bringing a bigger appetite!
author: Linus W.

description:
Oh my goodness, I didn't know how popular this place was. My friend and I randomly came her one Saturday afternoon and they asked us if we had a reservation. For some reason, this came as a shock to us (not really sure why). We said no, but we were seated right away. The menu was small but we still couldn't decided what we wanted to eat. Eventually we did, and it was delicious. My picky friend even told me to finish my food when I said I was full (that's a big deal!). 

The interior is so cute and lovely. It makes you want to sit there all day long. They also have tables outside.
author: Stacy C.

description:
came here for the Japanese breakfast only to find out I was too late and they stopped serving it. The disappointment (not the food) can only be compared to being 2 minutes too late for an egg mcmuffin from Mcdonald's...soul crushing. 

after punching myself in the face, I ordered the meatballs in curry for me, and the veggie rice bowl for my girlfriend. Also, a hibiscus iced-tea thing that was a little too sweet. 

Food was great!! Appropriate portions and everything was fresh and flavorful. Any place that allows me to "add a soft-poached egg" is right in my book. 

Atmosphere was cute as well. Small, comfy space. I liked all the little DIY stations with water and flatware.  

will have to come back for the Japanese breakfast next time!
author: Kelly I.

description: LOVE the food here. It's a little pricey, and I think the dinner is way better than the brunch, but the presentation on the different plates is amazing, and the service is great. I also love the size of the restaurant itself - I grew up in SF, and these small intimate spaces are what real SF is all about. Thank you Cassava! Heart you
author: Jenn H.

description:
cute Japanese American fusion brunch spot.
Order first, then sit.

the Chorizo Hash was good but greasy.  But a side of rice with yuzu evens out the greasiness of the dish.

the waffle with scrambled eggs wasn't bad.  it was nothing special either.  

the warm honey spiced milk was also yummy.
the portions are small for the price.
author: Heejin L.

description: One of richmond's neighborhood gems. Every time I go here, the food is on point and beautifully presented. While not cheap, you definitely feel like you're getting a mission type brunch for a Richmond price. Winners include the short ribs and the smoked trout appetizer but I want to try everything on their menu. I love that you can sit outside on a sunny day in the Richmond. It's close by the marla's bakery and cafe promenade so that you can walk to on a nice day!
author: Y J.

description: Neighborhood gem is a term used too loosely in my opinion.  It's got to have great food, pleasant atmosphere, no lines out the door and down the block, and a warm welcome.  This place ticks all the boxes.  Initially, I was annoyed that the previous bakery that was there closed, and I no longer had walking access to Andersens bakery bread.  As far as I was concerned, it was Cassavas fault I had to eat shitty toast with my breakfast and now, I don't even eat toast anymore.  It's weird.  But then I found a French breakfast sandwich at Cassava, the Mr. & Mrs. Croque, and just like that, all was good with the world again.  I've probably had 20 of them since.  The missus goes for the waffle. Dinner is also awesome, anything they braise, panna cotta, eclectic beverages.  Do it people, make reservations though, and stick to them.
author: Darren M.

description: Very diverse selection for brunch. Amazing egg/bacon/waffle plate. Will be back very soon. Need more places like this in outer Richmond!
author: Harris G.

description:
This is not your typical breakfast and brunch hangout with eggs and pancakes. In fact, Cassava offers a wide selection of appetizing dishes, different and all mouth watering. 

Since its opening, I've been here a couple of times with my family and for an afternoon outing with friends. I have tried the breakfast and the brunch but I'm looking forward to come here during dinner. 

I love the decor of this place as well as the chalk mural plastered against the wall. The atmosphere is cheery and the place is always packed. The heated outdoor seating is also a plus! I will share some of my favorite dishes I've tried.

Japanese Breakfast: $10 
This dish is truly unique to Cassava. My only complaint would be the fermented beans, one of the side dishes of this plate. The taste is overwhelming and slightly bitter and sour. The first time tasting this, I almost spit it out. However, my second time getting this dish I requested to not have the beans. I liked the concept of the poached egg on the side and ended up pouring it onto my rice, giving the rice a more creamy and satisfying texture and taste. The miso soup is not the usual soup one may order at a typical Japanese restaurant, this one tasted heartier and had  slices of some vegetable. This is a blend of Japanese fusion incorporated into a single dish of heaven and is able to intertwine different flavors complementing each other.

Slow Roasted Pork Shoulder Sliders: $12
This would have to be my ultimate favorite dish here. Tender and juicy slices of pork resting on toasted warm buns. The meat is so yummy (fat included) but since I like my meat without too much fat, I had to remove the excess fat from the shoulder. This dish is served with a side salad, although it was nothing special to me. This is a must get.

Overall, I've enjoyed my different experiences at Cassava. The service is spectacular and the workers are willing and helpful. I will be coming back for sure, sometime in the near future. Now excuse me while I go back to dreaming about the pork sliders. :)
author: Jessica E.

description:
Tucked away where you can still find a parking space without a meter, Cassava is a lovely restaurant in the Sunset. My group was there for brunch and everything we ordered was delicious. Be aware that If you order the waffles, there is no syrup, just jam. The bacon is perfectly crispy with just the right enough of fat. Oh and the macrons are delicious! 

The latte is a bit on the sweet side.
author: Theresa D.

description:
The staff was super nice 
But the food I can do better
We were here for diner we had chicken and tri tip 
Boy the tri tip was so tough I can't even swallow it 
The chicken was bland 
Boston market had better chicken !!!'
We had kale said which I didn't. Care for 
The grilled peppers with the tri tip was good 
I expected
More but was disappointed 
Sorry
author: Hieu N.

description: Fantastic place! Delicious food presented beautifully. Lovely environment for a relaxed evening
author: Michelle M.

description: Different, hipster, fresh, healthy place for brunch! Glad we ran into this on Yelp! Thank God For Yelp.....
author: Leila D.

description:
Cassava is a very cute little restaurant in the Outer Richmond. One pro is that you can make a reservation beforehand so that you're not waiting an hour for brunch like most other places in San Francisco!

I highly recommend the coffee drinks. My sister got the bourbon mocha and I got the spiced honey latte. Both are delicious and made with Ritual Coffee. If you can't drink milk, you can choose to have soy or almond milk substituted for 50 cents extra.

I also highly recommend the smoked trout shared plate. I never thought that smoked trout, ricotta, arugula, and a bit of orange would be such a great combo. It is really delicious! It was definitely my favorite thing that we ate.

The main plates are okay. There is an interesting mix of Japanese and American comfort food cuisine to choose from. I got the Mr. and Mrs. Croque (fried egg, avocado, turkey, ham, tomato), which was tasty, but not anything too special. My mom got the Japanese breakfast (rice, miso soup, pickled vegetables, two poached eggs), which was cute, but very spare and simple. My sister got the curry with meatballs. I tried a meatball and thought it was a bit rubbery.

Overall, I would recommend it if you're craving brunch and don't want to wait forever to get seated!
author: Wendy S.

description:
I was lucky enough to be a part of Cassava's inaugural pop-up dinner after it re-opened post-renovations. I haven't been able to try its breakfast or lunch menu yet, so this review is solely about its pop-up dinners on Fridays. From beginning to end, the dinner was an incredibly fun, surprising experience, and I'm glad I was I introduced to it right when it reopened. 

Environment: The first thing you notice when you walk into Cassava is its homey environment. With recent renovations, it has doubled in size, allowing for four-or-five tables to be set up for dinner. The atmosphere is cozy, and one of my favorite visuals is its wall-paper. Look closely and you'll see the French detailing is actually made up of fire hydrants, rats and pigeons. 

Service: Kris and Yuka are incredibly warm and inviting. You can tell they love what they do. Yuka is a great hostess and was very attentive to our needs. Kris is a great cook specializing in fine dining cuisine. It may seem odd at first for a cafe/bakery place, but the husband-wife duo make a great combination. 

Dinner: First of all, the tasting menu features a quote from Rajesh Koothrapali of Big Bang Theory fame - "This, is the difference between eating and dining." The dishes were delicious from beginning to end. Some of the highlights for me was an onion consomme with onion jam, crispy braised oxtail, and cucumber/cumin gelee (which melted when the consomme was poured on top and created a really fresh taste); herlook tomato terrine with sturgeon caviar and queso Oaxaquena (suuuuuper creamy and went great with the saltiness of the caviar); the Brentwood corn pudding; and the burnt caramel lemon flan with pistachio nougatine. 

I'm no foodie so I couldn't pronounce half the words on the menu, but I can describe how it tasted with one sound : "yummmmmmmmmmm!"

I ended the night with a to-die-for bourbon honey mocha. Although the meal was light enough to keep me from feeling sluggish, I needed an extra pick-me-up before hititng up the city's nightlife. 

The whole experience ended up costing around $75, and it was money well-spent! I definitely recommend it for a date night or when you're feeling like going fancy with your friends.
author: Dyanna Q.

description:
My girlfriend lives in the neighborhood and we sometimes frequent local restaurants and cafes on Balboa when she isn't visiting me in Oakland.  Since I follow a vegan lifestyle, she made sure that there was something that I could eat here that was more substantial than, say, a salad.  She told me about a quinoa dish that sounded yum, that I was looking forward to trying.  

When we got to Cassava the hostess spoke to my girlfriend while I read the menu on the outside window.  The place was crowded, so it couldn't be that bad, right?  And then something caught my eye.  Duck liver was listed as an ingredient in one of the entrees and I couldn't help but wonder....so I asked the hostess "Do you serve foie gras here?"  She kind of blushed and said "Those items don't contain foie gras, but our valentines menu does.  We're thinking about discontinuing it..." And she kind of trailed off.  I don't know about you, but I would rather not support a restaurant that supports cruelty to animals.  I mean, cmon there is plenty of delicious food to eat without supporting the slow death of hapless ducks.  Needless to say, we left right away and had a delicious meal at a Vietnamese restaurant down the street sans cruelty.
author: Marcella K.

description:
This place is a joke. I lived in the hood for 8 years and I'm glad this place wasn't around when I lived here.

Visiting the old hood this morning and decided to give this place a shot. First of all, a bunch of people just hanging out - like some sort of wannabe scene or something - wasn't a good sign.

I step in, it's super crowded, and there is just chaos inside. I don't know where the line is or where to place an order. People are being called to get their pastry orders?! Never seen anything like this. So I just get behind some people and get ready to order. Still standing there -  waiting to get an order or just noticed and a woman comes in from the door and somehow they acknowledge her right away and she gets an order in. Whatever. 

I didn't get angry - I just left. 

Give me Simple Pleasures any day of the week over this joint. This place is too chaotic and a little too precious for me.
author: Art O.

description: Really great service - super fast and not very crowded. I got the butternut squash soup and I thought it could've had a bit more seasoning. Overall, pretty great.
author: Bryoni L.

description: So happy we chose this spot for lunch! We actually were across the street and did not get a good feeling from the staff or menu and jetted on out before we ordered. Cassava was clean and so cute. The staff could not have been more friendly and accommodating. The greens were fresh, crisp and the food was very artfully done and tasty. They made my daughters some beautiful coffee drinks and my girls are tough customers. (No Starby's for them, coffee palates trained in France and Italy) It really was a great place to stop and enjoy a nice somewhat quick meal after a morning at the cliffs.
author: J C.

description:
The food and staff here are both great. 

We stopped in after a long hike through Land's End and I ordered the Randwich for lunch. The sandwich was super tasty and fresh, though the side salad could have had a bit more flavor. My girlfriend ordered the veggie rice bowl and it looked to be loaded with fresh produce. 

All in all, this place seems to be a solid bet if looking for fresh, well-portioned and well-priced food. The space is cozy and the staff is extremely friendly. Oh, and the tea was awesome too.
author: Martin F.

description: Just had a great meal at Cassava.  I'm only giving 4 stars, as the decor and plate sizes were small... but the food was 5 star. We all had the tasting menu, salad, yellow tail, lamb, and desert.   Somehow  the quality and presentation of the food reminded me of a Michelin starred restaurant in Tokyo.  We all agreed that it was as good or much better than the famous Berkeley place. I'll be returning for breakfast soon.
author: Richard G.

description: DELICIOUS!!! Great flavors, cute interior, and friendly staff. Reservations recommended but two people at the bar is pretty comfortable. We tried the rib hash, mr&mrs croque sandwich, and the duck liver mousse. The two bigger dishes were absolutely wonderful.. Ribs were marinated very well and the perfectly toasted bread was accompanied by fresh veggies, perfectly fried egg(yolky but no run=no mess)... Etc. the liver for me, was delicious but for some (my boyfriend) the taste can be a bit strong. I recommend giving it a try :p SPICED HONEY LATTE IS A MUST!!!
author: Michelle W.

description:
Coming from New York I am an expert bruncher, and Cassava seemed just okay and definitely not worth the trek from the SoMa area.  My boyfriend and I shared the "mr & mrs croque" sandwich, and the liege waffle with eggs & bacon, which are two of their more popular items on the menu.  There was nothing bad about it, but I felt like both dishes were pretty ordinary and the eggs almost tasted bland.

One of friends got the pork ribs hash, which she enjoyed, so maybe we just ordered the wrong items!  The restaurant itself is pretty cute, and everyone was really friendly, so not a bad place by any means, and still worth checking out if you live in the area.
author: Angela W.

description: Absolutely fell in love with Cassava! Came here yesterday for the first time because of a friend's recommendation.  3 friends and I arrived around 1:50PM on a Sunday and were seated immediately.  The decor in the restaurant is very cute, with a damask print wall with little fire hydrants and city oriented details.  I had the Peaches & Pimm's (pictured) which was delicious!  I also ordered Cassava's "Continental Breakfast" for a lighter brunch.  Buttery croissant did not disappoint and the poached egg was perfect.  I also can't complain about the fresh fruit and greek yogurt! Granola seemed very fresh.  My favorite part about Cassava though was the portion sizes of plates.  The portion sizes were AMAZING! I hate going to restaurants where I either get too little food, or TOO MUCH.  My continental breakfast is pictured below, and I finished it all and was full at the end.  My friends ordered the Japanese Breakfast and the Meatballs in Curry with Rice + Fried Egg, and we were all very satisfied with our meals, and kept repeating "I could have this every day for breakfast."  I'd also like to mention that the staff at Cassava is phenomenal - between food recommendations and casual conversation, they were very warm and welcoming!  I will definitely be coming back!
author: Gina B.

description:
Cool neighborhood spot with good service and a variety of food choices.

Came in for a coffee and noticed they had a Japanese breakfast with natto?  What?  Never expected to find natto on balboa street.  The breakfast was fine.  The tofu in the miso could of been smaller and soft or silken instead but ok.  

House made jam was awesome on the eggs and bacon plate.  Nice bread too.

Will be back to try maybe lunch or dinner?
author: Kevin L.

description: Funny, I wrote a review for Cassava 5 yrs ago when it first opened up and for some reason it just reposted. Place is still great. Cheers!
author: Rayden A.

description: This is a gem of the outer Richmond.  My wife and I used to live in the neighborhood and would find ourselves here on lazy weekend mornings enjoying the shuffle of people on balboa street.  The Japanese breakfast is one of our favorite dishes, though there are many to choose from.  It's like how Everest is the tallest mountain on earth, yet it lies in the tallest mountain range on earth.  We haven't had a bad dish.  The service is always attentive and the owners can be seen working along side everyone else.  We love it here. The end!
