author: Chris G.

description:
Details details details! This place is cute and oh so tasty!  First off yuki(I believe was her name) was so sweet greeting me and making it feel like a very friendly and warm community environment. 
The jars the coffee is served in, to the magazine cut out "doilies", to the chalk wall mural everything was put together well!  just love it!
I ordered a iced Americano (it had cute mushroom shaped ice in it) and the truffle chorizo hash. The hash was amazing! I'm not even a fan of any of those things. But it was that good! 
Anyways best spot on balboa for sure! Ill be back for more soon! Thank you guys!
author: Velvet C.

description:
Do not recommend. Don't be fooled by their cool appearance! Everything is overpriced, and is not with it. Let me tell you why.

Their menu doesn't make sense. They somehow seem to pride themselves of their artisan food. But what is their theme? It looks as if someone put together a random combination of plates such as hibiscus glazed pork ribs, Japanese breakfast, and meatballs and curry. They don't seem to have a specialty. Honestly hearing them all in the same sentence makes me throw up a little bit. 

I had the Japanese breakfast. I'm Japanese, and I thought it was bad. Such little portions, and the rice was mushy. It's probably because they use brown rice and was afraid to cook dry because they tend to.  Japanese food, let me tell you, has a taste that flows, one small plate to another. They should compliment each other (as most dishes do). But this breakfast doesn't. They added some lemon flavor to the natto, the pickles were wayyy too salty and the only thing that complimented the huge mound of mushy rice was the miso soup. They also had an onsen tamago (egg) on the side which looked way out of place. 

It takes them SO DAMN LONG for their food to come out. Simple is best. Their stuff is over complicated and you really taste the mediocrity in their food. The table next to us got their food after almost an hour, and the waitress offered to buy their lattes for them. What kind of service is that? There was another waitress that was literally doing nothing. She was just pacing around the whole time we were eating. Maybe she should be helping out in the kitchen since they're struggling to get orders out here.

It almost seems like the makers couldn't decide on what to focus on, so just put a bunch of random things together, added fancy names and called it a day. 

Sorry for the novel but this place makes me angry.
author: Momoe K.

description:
service: very good.

environment: good.

noise level: normal inside, outside is loud due to cars and outside noise.

food: 4.5 star

price: $$ very reasonable

proportion: good

been here three times, love it.

btw, i am not a big fan of brunch and American food, but this place made me come back.
author: Zack Y.

description: It was alright. For the price. The sliders did not suit the prawn and avocado. Everything was hust a bit slimey. I would not go back here. The 2 stars is for the ambience.
author: Garner K.

description:
You know those places that wow you every time you go? Cassava is one of those places. Genuine, warm and delicious are the adjectives that come to mind.

The owners are so nice and truly appreciate you dropping by, everyone that works there is great and super efficient.

Now on to the food/drinks! If you like unique lattes, they have a honey spiced latte and bourbon vanilla honey mocha that are to die for. They use Ritual Roasters (which is my favorite) and they even do siphon coffee people!!!!

The food? Incredibly delicious. There is a certain care that is put into every plate that you can absolutely taste. My favorite is their breakfast croissant sandwich (black forest ham, eggs, avocado, tomatoes, arugula, vermont white cheddar w/a pesto aioli) - it's truly a harmonic flavor delight in your mouth.

Basically you absolutely have to go at least once for brunch, you will never regret it.
author: Lauren B.

description:
This is a hip neighborhood cafe with Japanese-inspired decor and menu with an Asian twist to typical American cafe fare. Not much indoor seating. 
They only serve tea and coffee as beverages but told us we could buy something from the store across the street and bring it in. I picked up a belgian ale while I waited for my food. I ordered the shrimp avocado sliders and my friend got the curry meatballs. The sliders were very fresh and came with a side of greens. Eating meatballs with curry was interesting but I didn't particularly enjoy the combination. Portions are quite small for most things on the menu so you may want to order more than one thing. 
The staff was very welcoming and service was quick.
Must try their breakfast/brunch sometime.
author: Alfred L.

description:
Started my day off with a Spiced Honey Latte, and an Open Face Avocado Egg Sandwich. At first I was a little bit sad because it didn't look like alot of food, but there was a hefty amount of avocado which filled me up! 

The Spiced honey latte was good but I personally prefer a more aggressive "bite" on the tongue. This was very mild and sweet. The honey leaves a pleasant after taste.

The menu is very diverse, so I will be back to try something else!
author: Jeff S.

description: I literally eat at this restaurant every other day, no joke.  I absolutely love this place.  Not only is it a culinary fusion gem in what is otherwise a neighborhood of by the book diner and Asian food (except for one other standout), it is also just a cool place to be.  Chris and Yuka the owners are extremely warm and welcoming.  The food they prepare has just enough sophistication to keep you intrigued but is far from pretentious.  I have their veggie rice bowl for brunch on a regular basis and it probably accounts for most of my nutritional intake.  Wonderful savory saute of veggies over brown rice with an optional poached egg to mix in .. get that egg, trust me.  The liege waffle is also a winner and comes with a side of some of the best bacon I've ever had.  The hash bowls are also fantastic and very filling.  last but not least, they generally always have a smoked ocean trout or salmon appetizer that comes with creme fresh, sliced baguette, fresh greens and tomatoes.  Stack these items together and get ready for some delicious.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!!
author: Evan R.

description:
I wrote my first review on March 2012 when they were first opening. I loved them then and I LOVE THEM EVEN MORE NOW. 

Kris & Yuka & their team is always so welcoming. Their place is expending so now it allows people to dine in or even hang out in their outdoor seating. The food is absolutely amazing. My new favorite is Hearts of Butter Lettuce + Egg. Trust me! Order it and you will be amazed. :)
author: Kalok L.

description: Incredible food and very kind staff ! My husband and I used to live in the outer richmond, and were so happy that this was in walking distance. Since moving to the east bay, I have made the drive out here for breakfast simply because I cannot get enough of their apricot jam! I also love the Japanese culinary elements in a lot of their dishes, and the baked goods are incredible. The outdoor seating is a very cozy place to be on a gray san francisco day (which is every day in the outer richmond). We love you Cassava !
author: Kim K.

description: This place's decor is so cute!! Went here for lunch with my friend and a little pricey but the food was really good!! I had the salad and sage mint iced tea. The salad was good but can use a little more salt. The tea was very refreshing but I suggest putting sugar if you have more of a sweet tooth.
author: Kathleen Leah C.

description: Ordered the trout tonight and was thoroughly impressed. The skin was crispy and didn't take too greasy. The fish was made to a perfect medium rare, just the way I like it. Husband ordered the rack of lamb.  It was done rare with lots of flavor and textures. The little gem salad was on point, with dried blueberries, strawberry and puffed rice for texture. The dressing was a nice balance of acidity and cream. Kitchen is a bit smokey but reminds you exactly where your food was prepared. I can't believe we have such a gem in our neighborhood! We will be back!
author: Kathleen T.

description: One of the best brunches I've ever tasted! Taking waffles and eggs to its own unique level. Even though it was crowded when we first arrive, we got a seat pretty quickly! The serve was excellent. Always checking on us and full of knowledge of the menu. The waffles were to die for! The fig added the perfect touch! Next time I want to try the Japanese food options on the menu.
author: Samantha S.

description: Went there for a very late brunch on a Saturday without reservations.  Waited about 5-10 min to get seated.  The host was very friendly and nice.  The place is very hipster and cute (big chalkboard on the wall, mason jars as your water cup, light blue wallpapering, etc).  The kitchen is open so you can see what they are doing.  We ordered the Mr. and Mrs. Croque and the Duck Leg Confit Salad.  The sandwich can do without the egg and the pesto for simplicity, but that may be just an preference for some people.  The duck leg was juicy and citrus vinaigrette dressing was delicious.  I liked the touch of the poached egg and grana padano cheese.
author: Victoria A.

description: Cassava is a neighborhood gem in the outer Richmond.  The staff are really welcoming, courteous, and professional.  The owners, Yuka and Chris, have really molded the restaurant in their image, ensuring consistent service and execution.  Their background in fine dining really helps to enhance and elevate the restaurant.  From our first visit, we've always felt welcomed. The space is tiny but really warm and comfortable.  On a sunny weekend, the space is bright with the neighborhood spilling in from outside.  The food is always well executed.  Cassava is a go to brunch spot, easily worth the drive across the city for our visits.  The liege waffle is my go to brunch order--simply the best waffle I've ever had.  The waffle is really flavorful in its own rite and I've never been disappointed.  The pork rib hash is also one of our standby favorites.  While we've only been to Cassava once for dinner, the food was still very good and slightly more refined but still very comfortable and approachable.  All highly recommended.
author: Nathan W.

description:
Quiche- #22 on the 2013 7x7 100 Things to Eat Before You Die list. 

Make sure you get here by 2:45pm if you want to order off their brunch menu. I was super lucky that they still had ONE quiche left at 3pm (snuck in right before closing), and I was able to take it to go. I also ordered a couple of extra goodies:
 -Mushroom Quiche (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cassava-bakery-cafe-san-francisco?select=xFYZ79UuM6spb8mEAB3tvw#xFYZ79UuM6spb8mEAB3tvw): Delicious! The crust was buttery and flaky, and the mushroom filling had great flavor. However, the quiche was on the small side, so not sure if I would be full just eating this for breakfast or brunch. However, this is still a great add to the 7x7 list.
 -Passion Fruit Poppy Seed Macaron (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cassava-bakery-cafe-san-francisco?select=xFYZ79UuM6spb8mEAB3tvw#CyUpV0rSbX55huVPjHfewQ): YUM! The poppy seeds added an interesting texture, but they could be omitted since the passion fruit taste was wonderful, and I didn't want anything to detract from it. The texture of their macarons are a little grainier (which I like since it usually means it tastes more almond flavor and is chewier) so they're not super authentic Parisian macaron. I still loved it and would highly recommend it.
 -Green Tea Yuzu Macaron (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cassava-bakery-cafe-san-francisco?select=xFYZ79UuM6spb8mEAB3tvw#e9b-KBV_pZotkwZ77NrZLA): This flavor was just ok. I would've preferred the green tea flavor on its own and no yuzu marmalade, since the yuzu peel left a bitter aftertaste on your tongue. Skip!
 
Cassava has a pretty extensive brunch menu, and it seems like they have a dinner service available (by reservation only) as well. The coffee also looked really good (they use Ritual Coffee beans), so I'll have to come back and try that out along with their other food items. They also sell items from Patisserie Philippe, and I purchased a bag of the Diamant Cookies (there were also bags of mini Palmiers). There is indoor (4-5 small tables) and outdoor (3-4 tables) seating available, but the cafe itself is pretty small. Parking is easy to find on this quaint stretch of Balboa Street, and Cassava is only a couple blocks away from Shanghai Dumpling King if you're also in the mood for xlbs! The staff here is really friendly and helpful, and they weren't shooing out any patrons even though it was closing time. Cassava is a must stop if you live around this area!
author: Amy D.

description:
This tiny place in the Richmond is just oozing with charm. From the cute decor to the blankets they give those dining outside to shield from freezing SF winds to the delicate little dishes they put out.. this place is adorable to the max! 

I was so impressed that the chef came out to explain the dishes and make sure we were enjoying everything. The Japanese breakfast that I ordered was clean and simple... nothing smothered in sauce or deep fried here. Just traditional side dishes and a sous vide egg to break over some rice. It was a great way to start the day and not feel gross after my meal. I also bought a morning bun to share with my friends and it was sweet and delicious all heated up. 

My only reservation from giving it a full five stars is that it's really not a practical place to have weekend brunch simply because it's so tiny with just a few small tables inside. There's more seating outside but like I mentioned, it can be brutally cold in the area and the winds kept me from fully enjoying my meal (though the green tea I ordered did help.) I'd happily stop by for a coffee and pastry if I lived or worked near here, but for a more convenient group dining experience I would just prefer a slightly larger place. 

That being said, if you catch them at an off hour, by all means - go here! It's the sweetest experience you'll have in a long time!
author: Christina P.

description:
4.5 stars for a great little neighborhood spot with friendly service, bright and cheery ambiance, and a selection of sandwiches with interesting flavor profiles.

Came here on a whim with a friend after spotting the bright interior and glass case filled with tons of delicious-looking pastries. I'm a sucker for anything with a poached egg in it, so I ordered a Randwich and also tried some of my friend's veggie panini. Clean and simple presentation, great side salad of spring greens and house-made balsamic with each order, and very well-seasoned vegetables in each sandwich.

You can most certainly tell that there's a lot of passion for food and great service in the husband and wife team that was behind the counter, and they cared a great deal about making sure my and my friend's experience was pleasant. I will definitely be back for their breakfast offerings and hopefully to one of the pop-up dinners with more friends in tow!
author: Bianca P.

description: Outstanding.  I haven't written a ton of yelp reviews, but I immediately wanted to shout it to anyone thinking of coming: YES.  Excellent food in the Outer Richmond isn't that easy to find, especially creative and thoughtfully-assembled meals like these.  The vibe of the place is light-hearted but curated -- in other words, the wall paper, which is gorgeous, turns out to be floral motifs over parking meters and fire hydrants.  Ha!  We had the burrata appetizer, which was rich and tasty, and we each had a fish entree (one trout, one sea bass, in case you've got a checklist).  Perfectly cooked, great quality, and unusual veggie combinations on the plate to make everything a delight.  Oh, and the wines -- holy smokes, but they know how to pair things.  Friendly service, can't wait to come back and try breakfast.
author: George G.

description:
Was trying to go here both Saturday and Sunday but the weekend/outside lands crowd made it pretty impossible. Finally for to try them Monday - 15 mins too late for brunch but I got their Tuna Melt which was INCREDIBLE. And let me tell you I've had my fair share of tuna melts since they are my go to hangover food at restaurants and I have perhaps had a lot of experience with hangovers...

The spiced honey latte was delicious too - ruined the rest of the coffee drinks I've had today.
author: Sarah D.

description:
New favorite place!!! 

Ordered the randwich and it was amazeballs. Like, I can't even fathom how good it was. 

It's super cute inside and the staff was very friendly as well :) Definitely have to come back again soon.
author: Jackie N.

description: My best friend and I decided to go for an out of the ordinary breakfast. This included the paneer & meatball curry dish on my part topped with a bright, sunny fried egg; my best friend opted for the Japanese Breakfast which includes natto by request. Luckily natto and I have met in the past, but the complex fermented flavoring and texture offered a new experience for my dear friend. In all, the shop had a bright environment, friendly staff and a constant flow of customers which always let's me know you're in for some good nosh!
author: D L.

description:
SUMMARY: A cute place that delivers on the experience but falls short on the food. 

PROS:
+ Great service
+ Nice ambiance
+ Well-dressed staff
+ Unique menu
+ Honey spice latte

CONS:
- The food had all of the components cooked perfectly, but unfortunately it fails to deliver because many of the dishes had unnecessary ingredients/ flavors. It's like they are complicating what should be an already good dish by trying to throw more into the mix. Trying to have unique food is great, but not when it comes at the expense of the overall flavor. We tried the Saturday brunch and has the grazed beef hash and the Mr and Mrs Monsieur. Both had great potential but were overwhelmed by the myriad flavors competing in the dishes.

I'd like to come back and try some additional dishes to see if this is true of the entire menu or just limited to the recent Saturday brunch.
author: Shamim I.

description:
So yummy!!!
The wait was only 10 minutes on a Saturday morning. 
I had the honey latte which was fantastic. As was the chilled pea soup and the croque Monsieur sandwich. Presentation was spot on, as was the service. Well done, a little pricey.
author: Alexandra R.

description:
My one and only time I was here was during the first couple weeks they re-opened a couple months back.  Stopped by for brunch and left feeling not quite satisfied.

I had ordered the Meatballs in Curry w/ a poached egg, which doesn't look like is on their menu anymore.  And good thing it isn't because it really wasn't that good.  If no one had told me, I would never have guessed that the the sauce was a curry.  It was bland and tasted more like a tomato sauce.  The meatballs were just eh.  On top of that, they had forgotten my poached egg.  And to rectify this, they just plopped a runny looking egg on top.  Was it worth the $11 that I paid?  Uh no.

Maybe I just ordered the wrong thing, because to be fair, I tried my friend's tuna melt and it was actually really good.  I also ordered the honey spiced latte and one of their macarons.  Latte carried a slight sweetness; it was all right.  For the macaron, I've had better elsewhere.

The place itself is kinda cute.  I like the colors going on in there.  Seating is a little cramped though.  Hopefully, you don't mind the next table eavesdropping on your conversation.
author: Vanessa C.

description:
Pretentious.  overpriced and over reaching for dinner.  service reflected the neighborhood.  we walked in on a Saturday night, only a handful of people in the whole place, were seated than promptly forgotten. food was good, don't get me wrong, but it wasn't great.  

the actual environment is super cute and beautifully done.  The whole place comes off as glossy.  A little LA in the Outer Richmond.
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
Arriving too early for Cassava Bakery + Cafe's Sunday brunch, we sipped coffees, ate quiche ($5 for a decadent mushroom & white cheddar variety--lovely, flakey crust), & leafed through their mini library of local publications. 

When 11am rolled around (the anticipation was killer!), we put our brunch orders in. I really enjoyed my Shrimp & Avocado Sliders ($10.) Perfectly cooked large shrimp smothered in a savory sauce. Loved the sprinkling of tomato & red onion. A totally unique brunch offering, but then again, I don't expect less from a lovely spot that serves 'Japanese breakfast' (now *that* sounds amazing) & throws monthly 'pop-up dinners.) The newlywed owners obviously love food & quality ingredients. 

Their cafe only houses three tables inside & a handful outside. Hopefully the more popular they get, the more expansive their space will be! Spread the word--Cassava's got yummy eats!
author: Fancypants X.

description:
One star for service!

I was introduced to this place by a friend that lives in San Francisco. My family took a trip out to academy of science and decided to use Cassava gift certificate that was given to us. 

First incident: my wife walks up to ask for a fork. And the lady ..probably the owner.. says to my wife, "we will bring the fork out to you." Like we need to raise our hand to get your attention. Why does that matter? And later, I went up to get a spoon, she looked over the table and hesitated because ...(I'm 6'1 and 215lbs, which probably worked)...she thought we didn't have one. 

Second incident: we brought a 14 month old child. We sat in the restaurant for ...about 50+ minutes. My daughter was finished with her food and was impatient. So I frantically grabbed the diaper bag and looked for the pacifier. The same lady came up and said, "could you keep your baby down..there are others dining." Let me say that ONE more time. 
"COULD YOU KEEP YOUR BABY DOWN..THERE ARE OTHERS DINING?" -with a smiley face. ** if you're the owner reading this...you probably remember us. **
Then I looked around and there was 1 table inside which was occupied and looked like a family of the owner.. And some dined outside.

You do not need a child to understand how hard it is to have dinner outside of your home. Just relax..we aren't at some fancy restaurant. 

That was a terrible service.

There are plenty of restaurants like this in the city. Why bother with a bad service?
author: John S.

description: Really nice place with a cool, relaxed atmosphere and friendly staff. I went for lunch and had the Fried Egg & Avacado Sandwich which had turkey, ham, pesto and other things on it. It was very good and came with a small salad to make a great little meal.
author: R S.

description:
Felt like brunching today and didn't feel like driving out to Hayes valley for some real brunching so decided to give this place a try. 

The positive! One star for perfect poached eggs. 

The negatives :((((( Had to wave servers down numerous times for different occasions, the coffee cup was dirty and stained, cloth napkin was very dusty, everytime I wiped my mouth there were dust particles flying about in the air.. Maybe it's from the wallpaper as well?

Food was mediocre and definitely overcharged. The $17 72-hour braised beef hash is a joke. Fatty beef pieces on a bed of lettuce and potatoes tossed with quinoa and "mandarin orange slices" topped with a poached egg looked more like a  summer salad than a hash and the presentation does not reflect the price paid. 

Curry meatballs didn't have enough flavor, could've gotten better curry baked entrees at random hk cafés not worth over $12.

This place is just another over-pretentious Asian restaurant misinterpreting the idea of "fusion" to justify the greedily inflated prices. Starbelly is another one but they play it way safer and the quality is way better. 

But it's okay, You can fool most San Franciscans that don't get out much because they are naive and into cute gimmicks like Daiso tableware. Good luck.
author: Catalina C.

description: The chicken was amazing! The shrimp were great if you are into whole with shell. Beat salad was very tasty! And yummy wine. We also had the cheese plate - which had a fav Port Salut.
author: Mr.x T.

description:
My friends chose this place for brunch today. This place is pretty nice and cute. The decor and atmosphere is very fresh. 
We had reservations at 1:45pm. We came half an hour early (just in case) and was told by this nice girl that the table was not ready yet. She is always smiling and friendly. When it was time she got our table ready and we were seated at a small table near the back. Although it looks small it was enough space to fit 3 of our orders. The nice waitress poured us some water from a wine bottle and there was some leftover if we needed refills. We shared the waffle with bacon and eggs, braised short ribs hash bowl and a mr & mrs croquet sandwich. I think the owner took our order -she was nice and friendly. 
The braised short ribs hash bowl has quinoa, potatoes and lettuce in it. It was pretty good and tasty. The ribs was so tender. I didn't really like the waffle that much because it was not very tasty/dry. I loved the figs on it though, they were so good! The eggs were a little too salty but still good; The bacon was good as well. The "Mr. & Mrs. Croquet sandwich was really good! I loved how they used pesto in it. The cheese was a little too salty though and also the bread was a little dry and not very tasty. 
Overall I had a good experience at this place.
author: Carmen L.

description:
Great lunch spot on Balboa if you're in the Richmond Area.  My co-workers and I often come here for lunch on a weekly bases because of the awesome food here.  You order at the cashier, but they serve you (you bus your own dishes though).  Quaint little place that was recently remodeled for more seating space as well as a chic counter design.

I would recommend the Japanese Breakfast for those who are adventurous or the Curry for those who was a sure-fire dish.  It's tasty and really hits all of your sense.  The portions are a tad small and it can be a little pricy for my liking, but its worth coming back to with friends.
author: Robert T.

description: Cassava is a good brunch and lunch place in the Richmond. It's a little hip for the area, and a little expensive, but I think they deliver when it comes to service, unique plates, and fresh ingredients. I think I've had everything on their menu, and my favorite so far is the hash. I like that they have Ritual coffee as well. Will be back!
author: Ryan Y.

description:
My husband and I had our Memorial Day lunch at this superb restaurant;)
We had the delicious Smoked Ocean Trout to start and we shared the Duck Leg Confit Salad and the Hibiscus Glazed Barbeque Pork Ribs "Hash" dishes. I don't have words enough to describe a such tasty food. 
Not counting, the cool and cozy place that they have intentionally set up. 
I obviously recommend Cassava restaurant!
author: Ana A.

description: Cassava is a fantastic neighborhood restaurant. Run by a talented wife and husband team, the food is interesting, yummy and inventive.  The service is also spot on.  The restaurant brings a level of sophistication and excellence to the Outer Richmond food "scene," that was previously lacking.  I love the various kinds of rice bowls they serve as everyday staples, with meatballs, vegetables or an egg over, but last night I had an excellent pumpkin soup, chorizo appetizer, and a scrumptious lamb dish paired with a wonderful aglianico.  Oh, and the lattes are good!  If you're looking for a nice neighborhood meal in the OR, Cassava is your place....
author: Jafer P.

description:
This review is being written as we wait for a table for two on. Sunday. We got here about quarter before noon and were told that it would be a 45-minute wait while there were anywhere between 3 to 7 tables available while we were waiting.  The bus boy moves at a glacial pace which may be part of the problem. A table for 3 was not cleaned and set in over 20 minutes while we waited. First serious fail.  You should not have tables sitting un-set for that long while people are waiting.  The hostess told me that they did not have enough people to take care of the tables. WTF??!!  There are 9 of them working!  They all just move around very slowly. My 80-something grandmother moves faster than any of them, and she has problems with her knees! Seriously, they need to get their act together.  So far they get a minus 2 stars.

So the food came pretty quickly, which is great. We got the pork ribs appetizer. They are tasty at first because we were hungry. I went back to them later on and thought they were kind if bland. My main dish was the meatballs + curry. It is under-seasoned. The paneer cheese was tasty and were the meatballs but the curry was really boring. 

The cheese in Mr. & Mrs. Croque sandwich was great. However, the sandwich is not worth the cost.  Heck, nothing we had was worth the cost. This worse than Outerlands, and Outerlands was bad already!  They get 2 stars for the food, and zero star for the value. Since we can't give zero stars on yelp, they get 1 star in the end. 

Don't waste your money or time at this place.
author: William L.

description:
Like Arnold says, "I'll be back." 

I love that an awesome restaurant that is worth visiting has opened up in the outer Richmond since trekking out to busier parts of the city can be a chore. Cassava's understated personality is a unique and subtle mix of quaint and modern with delicious food, warm ambiance, and decor. 

What we ate:
Coffee - was pleasantly surprised that they serve ritual coffee
Smoked ocean trout - 2 thumbs up.. I wish it was a main course instead of a starter. 
Japanese breakfast - huge portion of rice, fish, perfectly cooked soft boiled egg, light but flavorful soup, and tasty pickled vegetables. Very simple but delicious.. Like comfort food. 
Liege Waffle, house maple ricotta - the Waffle was dense and had a hint of lemon and not overly sweet and was covered in fresh berries and figs. The bacon was crispy but the eggs were a little too heavy & buttery for me. The dish is a perfect combination of sweet & savory. 

I will need to go back and check it out for dinner and also other brunch options like the duck confit and curry meatballs since it looked delicious on other people's tables. It's a great place to start a relaxing weekend!
author: Christine H.

description: A hidden gem in the outer Richmond, we went there after grabbing boba tea at Purple Kow. The menu had a mix of Asian (esp. Japanese) and American dishes. I got the curry meatballs with rice and liked it a lot even though it wasn't traditional curry in any cuisine - the sauce was tomato based, and meatballs tasted fresh with greens on the side. Would love to try other things on the menu, like the unique beverage options next time!
author: Jaclyn C.

description: This place is very pretentious. The pour of the very expensive wine was ridiculous- and when I complained waiter did not correct or change pour. The soup was good. Not great. The prices do not match the cuisine
author: Tina F.

description:
meh.

Ordered their breakfast croissant with forest ham and their honey spiced latte. Woman behind the kitchen served me a burnt ass croissant sandwich. Tasted awful, like burnt metal so I sent it back to the kitchen. Straight up left the half eaten one on the right and re-toasted half of a new croissant to replace the one she had burnt. So what did she do with the other half? So weird. Terrible, and NO ONE SAID SORRY. I've worked in the food industry for a long time & I was a barista for many years and I WOULD NEVER EVER GIVE ANYONE ANYTHING BURNT. I would remake it & apologize.

Clearly did not finish the sandwich. You don't need to toast "fresh" croissants. Clearly they were old croissants.

Also my honey spiced latte was SOOOOOOOOOOOOO SWEET. Like holy crap, straight up milk with hella honey. Didn't taste the coffee.

Sorry, not coming back to this place.
author: Jazzmin A.

description:
Lunch was lovely at Cassava Bakery and Cafe, a warm and lovely spot in the foggy outer Richmond, very near the Balboa Theater. Great for a coffee and french pastries or a savoury lunch. (It looks like they host some very interesting pop up dinners, as well.) The menu is inspired by japanese cuisine, but you'll see a strong element of French, too. 

I had the Japanese breakfast:
Koshihikari plum rice, ichiban dashi miso soup, sous vide "onsen tamago" poached egg, Meyer lemon kosho natto, wakame salad, simmered hijiki. 

The egg was sublime! The fermented soy is an acquired taste.... ;-)
The owners  are impossibly cute, too. It just has to be said: )
author: Mark N.

description:
Not sure where the recent negativity is coming from but in my opinion, this place is certainly a gem. I can go through, rating everything that I've tried on every occasion I've been here since they were a little shop with 6 seats but I would like to provide you with a larger sense of what Cassava is.

Cassava pays attention to the details and adds a tad bit of finesse to everything they do; their Japanese Breakfast is an excellent example. The onsen egg is cooked via sous vide (how many other cafe's can you name with an immersion circulator?) Their rice is cooked perfectly with proper attention paid to its texture. And there is natto. Oh that funky, snot-textured, fermented soy bean. I usually see about 80% of the natto return to the kitchen untouched but Cassava presses on and keeps it as part of the breakfast. Its an uncanny adherence again to the details. 

Their macarons are very good, sourced by Patisserie Philippe. Of special note, they offer green tea (not matcha, using tea leaves in the shell) + Yuzu jelly which is my favorite macaron in the city just by the over all flavor combination. Their cocktails are excellent, again with attention to detail: its not just vermouth in that Spiced Honey Red Sangria - its Dolin Rouge, some of the best damn sweet vermouth around. 

And at the end of the day, Chris and Yuka are wonderful owners who you can sense have a sincere passion for what they do and who they serve. Yes the service can be slow sometimes, try to visit at a time besides late saturday/sunday morning; if you ever take a look at size of the kitchen, you'll understand- theyre doing the best they can with the size they have. I have always felt at home at cassava and hope you might do the same.
author: Chris D.

description:
First impressions are everything. Just don't move my family after we have ordered our food and sipped our coffee for 10 minutes to accommodate others when there are other empty tables around. With the money that is spent on breakfast your service should be better. 

Scrambled eggs were too salty. Lamb curry meatball dish was a  plus.
author: A R.

description:
Been here a couple times. 

A couple before it became fancier: I liked the whole casual, order at counter, bring number to table atmosphere. It was good food. Consistency they needed to work on. The menu was small, I had the curry both times, liked it. But the curry was inconsistent. I liked it the 1st time and was eh the 2nd time. 

Fancier time: Hostess could only give us bar seating, which we were fine with. Everyone was friendly and we had our order taken in a timely manner. Nice staff. They were super busy. I had the liege waffles, I expected a bit more, like the liege waffle cart. This didn't remind me of a liege waffle at all. Fruits were good and so was the bacon. But the main part of the dish had disappointed me. Their drinks are awesome though. Heard it's getting more popular, so I probably won't be back soon, dislike crowd.

And on a side note, I was going through craigslist and this place was hiring. Weirdly enough, they didn't want anyone with 2 or more years of experience, which I was a bit ticked at because I wanted to apply. But this keeps their staff young and more than likely high school or college folks.
author: Kimberly S.

description:
FOOD 
1.) shrimp sliders = this is good
2.) Tuna melt = oooh, this was good. side of salad comes w it too

Going to try the Kris's salad next time since it looks so good. Feel like all their food here is going to be pretty good. 

SERVICE
Nice friendly


ATMOSPHERE
very cute. They expanded and it's more adorable than ever. Even though it's in Outer Richmond where you think there could absolutely be nothing cool out there, they made a successfully cute cafe that would make me want to visit more. Always a great atmosphere even before they remodeled. Now they have outdoor seating patio that is very cute too.
author: Angela L.

description:
Edit:

Overcharged credit card for meal by ~$30. Good thing my bf caught it.

Dealing with Chase right now. Way to start the weekend.
_________

I really wanted to like this place. It's located in my childhood neighborhood, I've walked by it many times, and it looks way too adorable to be real. I really, really, really wanted to like it. 

So why didn't I like it enough to give it a higher rating?

-------

Having brunch outdoors in San Francisco is a gamble. You're either going to freeze your toes off or you're going to...freeze your toes off. Okay, so there's not really a gamble. The great thing about it is that there's always an option to eat indoors, or at least wait for a table that is indoors.

Not in this case. There was at least 4 tables inside that were not occupied, but the host refused to let anybody sit there, stating that a party reserved it. That's fine. I understand, Sunday brunch is a very busy time. I didn't mind just sitting outdoors.

However, that party NEVER showed up. I was there forever and those 4 tables remained empty while people came in to see if there were any availability. People decided to leave rather than to wait for the 5 occupied tables outside. I guess people don't like to dine al fresco in the wind either. If people are late or don't show up for their reservations, for godssake, let  people use them. Have a 10 minute grace period and if they miss it, too damn bad. 


The heater I sat under did not extend far enough to keep me warm and I literally had my hood up and pulled around my head.


--------

Food was...ok.

 My meatball curry was bland and the salad was kind of mushy; nothing to write home about. I wish I've ordered the waffle and potatoes like the table next to me did. That looked better. :(

My friend enjoyed the Japanese brunch, so I guess that was the highlight.

Ordered the mousse for dessert. It was plated well, but took forever to come out of the kitchen. It was pretty looking, but it was pricey and was tiny. Think, ping pong ball sized. Taste wise, it was good. Very rich and complimented well with the billion things going on with it. 

------
author: Tiffaney L.

description:
This review is only for Brunch.

I've been here twice now with my boyfriend and we've both been happy every time we have gone.  They have super unique items for breakfast (i.e. Curry Meatballs & Duck Leg Confit Salad) that end up being really good.  

The carrot, apple, pear and celery juice is phenomenal (both for recovery after a long night, and if you're just in the mood for something tasty), and my boyfriend loves the Vanilla Bourbon Honey Latte.  

My only complaint is that the eggs were a little bland the first time I went, but on my latest visit, they added pepper to them (or so I noticed from a neighbors meal) so I think they have adapted that recipe a bit.

Give it a try!
author: Kelly L.

description:
This has probably become one of my favorite places to eat in the city. But you have to know what you are in for.

First, it is a small place,  tables are snug and waits can be long. Book online if you can.

Second, things move slow here. If you come to grab a quick bite you'll be frustrated. Instead, sit back, people watch, chat with the owner or your party, have a glass of wine and enjoy life.  It reminds me a bit of cafes in France in this respect. I spent almost two hours for dinner (4 courses) last time.

Third, the food is fantastic. Fresh, well prepared, constantly changing, and doesn't taste slathered in oil.  The chef obviously is passionate.

Last, the ambiance is quite casual. It is a bit at odds with the food which feels more formal and I feel like I should have a jacket on when I get the dish. But it is a happy place, the locals clearly are enjoying themselves, the owner is the friendliest person ever, and I always walk out with a dumb grin on my face due to such a pleasant experience.
author: Nathan T.

description:
I can't begin to explain how incredibly amazing this Restaurant is. It may be my new favorite in San Francisco.
Today was my second time eating at Cassava, both times were for brunch.
Today we started with the duck salad with peach, quinoa and poached egg. The duck was so tender and fell right off the bone, the dressing was so tasty but not over baring and the egg was poached to perfection, runny yolk included.
I had the Japanese breakfast, which I had the first time we came. It's WHY I came back. Why don't more Japanese restaurants serve breakfast in San Francisco?! I never knew about this until Cassava, and I feel like the food gods have been holding out on me for 24 years.
The breakfast comes with steamed rice, pickled (?) bean sprouts, a PERFECTLY poacher egg in broth; kale, mushroom and some type of root soup, pickled (?) mushrooms, and to top it off seared yellow fin tuna. If I could eat that for breakfast everyday, I would. I often fantasize about it.
My date had the meat ball and tofu curry, which he devoured which was tasty and plentiful.
The service here is great, the staff is friendly, genuine and really give it a neighborhood feel. They all seem to know what they're doing and enjoy doing it. 
To sum it up, if you haven't eaten here, you're missing out. And although I don't want more people to find out about this place because I will never again be able to walk in without a reservation for Saturday brunch, this restaurant and it's creators deserve it, with out a doubt.
author: Molly A.

description: My BF and I have been coming here for awhile and this place is fresh and clean. The food never leaves me too full but pleasantly satisfied.
author: Maria G.

description:
I've held off reviewing this place because while it was shaky at first, I knew it had the ability to settle into itself.

Boy has it ever.

Great service, the baristas know what they're doing (so long as you like Ritual Coffee), and they find space and time to inject some fun and creativity into what could be just-another-minimalist-wannabe-upscale-kitsch-comin-to-gentrify-you joint.

Get the croissant sandwich, make resos on the weekend and wear a cat shirt on Saturdays. Trust me.

Definitely worth the trip out to the Outer Richmond.
author: Jordan W.

description:
Cassava is more of a café than a bakery. The bread and pastries (croissants, morning buns) come from Semifreddi's, the coffee from Ritual Roasters. Look for their housemade café bites: soup, salads, sandwiches, and quiche. The bites have a refined touch.

* Mini mushroom, kale & onion quiche with side salad ($5) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/muX0aRES6vsp5DEuJaW_uw?select=ey6rkI17cIwdRW1GcrOd5A: a little salty but very good, cheese on top, very tender egg filling, delicious buttery crust. The salad was fresh and light, with arugula, thinly shaved radish and cucumber. I liked the contrast of the bitter salad with the buttery, rich quiche.  But the salad also was too salty. 
* Peanut butter cornflake cookies (free w/ Yelp check in) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/muX0aRES6vsp5DEuJaW_uw?select=WttT3Q6lzNLOIlY5Ko7FJw: tiny, about an inch in diameter, light and crunchy, with extra crunch from cornflakes and a sweet finish, really good
* Latte: good flavor but wasn't hot enough, they're kinda slow at making drinks

The décor is country rustic charming: plants in Saint Benoit Yogurt jars, hanging terrariums, a bookcase with cookbooks. They have free wi-fi but there are only 3 tables. In the future they plan on introducing Japanese breakfasts and pop-up dinners.
author: Lolia S.

description: Great little place! Simple menu with great flavors and beverage pairings. Visited SF for the day and stumbled upon this, glad we did. Yuka was awesome, the food was great, and it had a nice atmosphere.
author: Lucas G.

description:
What I love about San Francisco is that you can be walking down the street of a neighborhood and stumble across a gem of a place. This is exactly how I discovered Cassava!

I was on my way to dinner one night and saw a private dinner tasting at Cassava.  Intrigued, I pulled out my trusty iPhone and bookmarked the place on Yelp.

A month later I decided to give Cassava a try after browsing through my bookmarks for a brunch spot.

My friend and I both gave the Japanese breakfast a try, per all your helpful Yelp suggestions. When the tray of assorted breakfast goodies came out, I wasn't sure to make of it: poached egg in broth? Marinated beans? Vegetable assortment? We weren't exactly sure how to eat the dish so we just mixed the different dishes together (including the poached egg) with the rice, and it turned out really delicious!  A great combination of flavors and textures. 

I also tried the cinnamon spiced latte. The coffee was slightly sweet, but not overly sweet. It was the perfect weekend treat.

My only complaint is that there isn't much indoor seating and we played a little musical-tables: we sat outside then moved inside to a small coffee table and finally to a larger dining table. With that said, the staff was supper friendly and accommodating in helping us get a table to eat comfortably at. The atmosphere is bright and cheerful. 

Super friendly staff. Bright atmosphere. 

Cinnamon coffee is delicious!

I'm looking forward to trying other items on the menu and hopefully the dinner seating in the future.  Folks, Cassava is neighborhood cafe dining at its best!
author: Matt S.

description: Went to Cassava twice last week for SF Restaurant Week and based out of the few restaurants I got to try, this one was the most tasteful and fulfilling. The manner in which the food was presented timewise and presentation wise was superb and the food was most delightful. The second time I came in the host recognized that it was my second time and allowed me to try a dessert that was different from the first experience and that type of service I enjoyed immensely. I would definitely come back.
author: Jay Y.

description:
Composition of food=beautiful 
Decor=cute
Quantity of food= medium amount
Quality=B+, for the most part tasty
Service=S L O W....... Took more than hour to get our food! And there were less than 20 customers...
author: Jeanne L.

description:
I am a fan!  Not only of their brunch but of their special evening dinners during the weekends.  My friend and I had dinner at Cassava earlier this month, and I love how you can taste the care put into each dish, so thoughtfully planned with balanced flavors.  My favorites were the Japanese New Years small dishes with pickled vegetables, sweet soybeans, fish - yum!  And I loved the soup with clams and shrimp (mmm so comforting), spiced sake and the strawberry panna cotta (best I ever had! So creamy and dreamy and I am not even a big dessert person in general! Loved it!).

For their dinners, make a reservation and like them on Facebook to get their updates, especially when there is an opening for dinner.  

I can't wait to go back again!!
author: Maile N.

description:
Such a cute and sunlit cafe! 
First off, amazing and friendly service all the time! I usually have lunch at Cassava once a week. Secondly, they have the BEST selection of vegan plates in the Richmond (not a vegan, but I do enjoy vegan plates once in a while)! 

My 2 favorite LUNCH items: 
Veggie panini - a panini filled with various veggies, olive oil, and pesto. The outside is lightly salted with what tastes like salt, kelp, and other spices! The veggies are not always constant (e.g. enoki mushrooms vs white mushrooms) but no matter what, it is always filling and worth your $8. Comes with a rather small side salad (pretty much arugula with tiny slices of carrot).

Tuna melt - $7 and like the above, very delicious. The name says it but this is not your typical tuna melt; a pretty generous amount of tuna with a thick layer of cheese on white bread. Also comes with a rather small side salad.

Two of my friends have spoken highly of the tasting menu (a set menu on Fridays for DINNER). Very intimate and includes a number of illustrative courses. You must make reservations prior to Friday. I believe both were about $40-50 per person and you can call to inquire on the upcoming tasting menu. 

Cassava, I cannot wait for renovations to be done! (currently closed for 2 weeks in May 2013 due to expansion).
author: Marissa P.

description: Great neighborhood brunch spot. It gets crowded on the weekends so try to make a reservation. We had the Mr and Mrs Croque sandwich and the tofu and beef meatballs in curry. Both were delicious-the sandwich had fresh ingredients and the curry was interesting and good.
author: AJ L.

description:
OK, I'm going to keep this brief because while I LOVE Cassava and Kris and Yuka, I'm being selfish in not giving away all my secrets so that there is still good stuff left for my gfs and I.

They have AMAZING brunch.  My favorites include the curry meatballs, tuna melt, open faced chorizo, croissant sandwich, and curry puffs.  Best macaroons, I used to limit myself to half a dz, now I opt for the whole enchilada, FULL DOZEN!  Awesome soy lattés, even more awesome staff.

They have the most amazing pop up dinners on Friday nights, a multi-course fine dining meal that is the highlight of my month.  I love being able to sit down and fully trust that what the chef has planned for my friends and I will be an amazing experience.  We book our reservations 2-3 months in advanced for the date we want.
author: Alice L.

description: Made reservations for a Sunday brunch for 6 and a baby. Got there and asked for a high chair -- guess what? No high chairs (sad face). Service was friendly and prompt. The place is a little cramped so we had to park the stroller outside, and it was unfortunate that we happened to be there during unusually hot weather, because it was uncomfortably stuffy having to carry the baby on my lap while attempting to eat. The food was kinda meehh--mediocre. I got the croque and while I knew it wouldn't come with bechamel, I mistakenly thought the pesto would fill the void. The whites of the egg were still snotty, and a good portion of the sandwich was filled with HALF an avocado, so I ended up having to use a knife and fork. I did enjoy the ham and turkey but I don't think it was worth forking out $13 for a so-called croque. I am just glad we made reservations, because if I had to wait for meehh food, this review probably would have had one less star.
author: Karen Z.

description: such a cute place! I got the Japanese breakfast with seared salt and peppered Albacore for additional $3. comes with natto too if you request it. I forgot when ordering. it's a very light and healthy breakfast: rice, pickles, seaweed salad, miso soup, and soft poached egg. order and pay at register and open seating. self serve water and ustensils.
author: Jules L.

description:
Beautiful environment, friendly people, incredible food.

I ordered the meatballs in curry and rice with an egg. Oh wow. It was so filling but i just couldn't stop eating.

Before the meatballs arrived, I downed a refreshing carrot juice. 

Cassava was the perfect start to a wonderful day :) Worth the price
author: Evan W.

description:
Cassava Cassava Cassavaaaa. I've been wanting to try this place before they've remodeled. Cassava is located at the corner in the Outer Richmond. The location is perfect for a quiet but not too pricey brunch/lunch. I was greeted with a really warm welcome and was seated outside immediately. Tip* (outdoor seating is awesome on a nice day. There are heaters too!)

I ordered the curry meatballs +rice while my friend ordered the waffle/eggs/ and bacon brunch. Our food arrived in less than 15 mins and if you are a fan of meatballs... You have to get them here! :D the sauce was just heaven to my tastebuds. But beside the amazing meatballs & sauce, the salad & rice on the side was pretty normal. My friend said she enjoyed her breakfast platter but it wasn't "amazing".

Overall, if you are looking for a good little brunch place in the outer Richmond that is comparable to all the amazing brunch places in Noe Valley.. Go give Cassava a try!
author: Kary Y.

description: Cassava is a nice place, the atmosphere and service were great. Very helpful and well mannered. I had the Japanese breakfast, and I have to say it was tasty however it did feel lacking in some way. I couldn't place my finger on it exactly but maybe it needed a salty side dish. Usually it comes in the form of a whole sanma fried or grilled as a main dish in that kind of set. They opted for sashimi of something I don't know.
author: Jon I.

description:
Love it! We moved out of the Rich to the North bay, and went out on a little Richmond tour. 

Super cool spot and great addition to the neighborhood.
author: Andrey P.

description:
I've been here a few times for weekend brunches and weekday lunches. It's a small, cute, and dainty neighborhood restaurant. Although it's pricey, the food is delicious -- the liege waffle is the best! I am always stuffed after finishing this dish (portion is just the right amount). I also love their drawing blackboard of SF behind the tables. I would recommend you try this place at least once. 

Sorry, I failed to take a picture of the liege waffle. But here's the weekday breakfast of the toast and scramble and Japanese breakfast.

Tip: they don't do take outs on weekends
author: Anna Z.

description: I love, love, love this place! Amazing food that is so fresh and tasty, and the staff is very friendly. Definitely recommend this spot and especially the veggie panini!
author: Shelby D.

description:
Update: I spoke with Yuka over the phone and it turns out she is very rude, unprofessional, and childish as other reviewers have claimed. I called very calmly to attempt to discuss my experience and all she wanted to do was verbally attack me and call me a coward. She called my piece slander despite it being completely factual, called me a coward for writing a Yelp review, never let me speak because she kept interrupting me with how she thinks I'm such a bad person, then finished off with saying she didn't have time to talk to me or deal with me, and then hung up. She and her staff didn't even remotely try to help us have a good experience while we were at the restaurant and she didn't make any effort to remedy the situation after I called reaching out. She claims she did, but all she did was attack me.

TLDR: Awful service and multiple bugs in food. $30 per person meal and I'm STILL HUNGRY. 

We went on Mother's Day so it was a set, prix-fixe $30 menu: 2 available appetizers to choose from, 3 entrees to choose from, 1 dessert. It wasn't as busy as you'd think so they can't use that as an excuse for the poor experience. We had a 12pm reservation and the restaurant was only about 70-75% full when we sat down with 1 other party waiting to be seated. 

My friend and I both got the salad, mine had a live fly buzzing around. Waiter took it back and gave me a new one. After I take a few bites of my salad, my friend discovers there's a live worm squirming around in hers. I lose my appetite for this bug infested salad which apparently normally costs $16 (just dried berries and almonds and several pieces of radish. It wasn't anything more than a basic salad). I didn't have the patience or will to dig through my salad for worms as well. The waiter comes by to take my friend's worm infested salad and asks if I've lost my appetite for the salad and I said yes. I didn't have more than a few bites of it so I basically didn't even get to eat an appetizer despite paying for it. He didn't even offer me the bug-free liver mousse appetizer option or anything to make up for the disgusting experience of our first course.

We were extremely polite about the whole bugs in salad thing and didn't make a huge scene about it (since I don't want them to spit in the rest of my food), but it was clear after the 1st course, the waiter gave up on us and didn't bother to serve us anymore. The table of 2 next to us received their appetizers 1-2 minutes before we got our appetizers, yet they received their entrees and completely finished their entrees before we even received ours. They were enjoying alcohol as well so it's not like they just scarfed it down in a few minutes. It took forever to get our entrees. The waiter never once bothered to check on us and our water jug was empty and I had to flag down a different server to ask him to fill up our water. Dessert similarly took just as long. The table beside us (who started at the same time as us) got and finished their dessert, had more alcohol, paid, and left and finally ~20 minutes after they left we finally we received our dessert. 

At the end, it turns out they took 20% off the tab which explains, but does NOT excuse them giving up and stopping service to us after the 1st course. The least they could've done was tell us they were doing that at the beginning so I didn't have to spend 2 hours being pissed at them and holding in my anger. A tiny discount that barely covers anything doesn't make up for the horrible service throughout the entire almost 2 hour ordeal (again, it wasn't even a crazy busy day). 

Now I am sitting at home eating yogurt and granola because after a 3 course $30 meal I'm still hungry since I didn't even get more than a few bites of the bug infested appetizer. 

Side Note: I noticed they were very unfriendly and unaccommodating towards handicapped/disabled people. My friend has a broken leg and came in with her crutches and cast and while waiting for our table, no one from the restaurant even offered her a chair to sit on. A very nice customer waiting to be seated saw my friend and pulled out one of the chairs from an empty table outside and told her she should sit, but no one from the restaurant even cared. Secondly, her leg NEEDS to be elevated so we asked to use a chair from the table besides us since they were a party of 3 with 4 chairs. The party next to us had no problem with it and after they were done a party of 4 came so they needed the chair. That was fine, but the hostess removed the chair from my friends leg, walked away, and didn't even offer her another chair to prop her leg on. The restaurant wasn't even full still so there were at least 7 chairs that weren't being used. I had to flag someone down and ask for another chair. We eat out every weekend so we've been to many restaurants together while she's been injured and people are always very accommodating and attentive about her injury, but these people couldn't be bothered at all.
author: M K.

description:
One word to describe this place: Blah. 

My friend and I visited for brunch. I chose the meatballs + curry, per the recommendation of Foursquare tippers. What ... the ... hell ... dude ... 

It was so bland, and the meatballs tasted like the ones I could get from the frozen food aisle at Trader Joes! I mean, curry's supposed to be packed with flavor and spice, right? This was a sad, sad excuse for curry. 

My friend got the Mr. and Mrs. Croque sandwich, which she enjoyed but felt she could have emulated it at home for half the price.

Definitely not coming back here.
author: Kathleen N.

description: Great place to get brunch. Amazing coffee and the bourbon vanilla mocha was nothing short of perfect. And the owner is super nice and the service was great.
author: Juan T. K.

description: Great sunny spot! Went for brunch w my girls and while vegetarian options were limited, they offered to make any dish veggie! I had the carrot ginger soup which was delicious- will go back!
author: Elana R.

description:
Yes, you should. That's why you're reading this aren't you - to figure out if you should eat here. So, yeah, do it.

But not because I told you to. Do it because the staff is amazingly nice. Because the food and drink pairings are extremely helpful and tasty. Because the food is beyond tasty, and crafted with love. Because the place is oh so cute and romantic. At risk of being sued by a sports retail giant, just do it.
author: Darrell L.

description:
Highlights
- When I visited their original smaller location, it was cozy, quaint and the perfect spot to grab a cup of joe and enjoy a little lunch. Each table also had fresh flowers, which added character to this cute shop. 
- They even had a bookshelf with books to read during your stay and a small bathroom. 
- During my first visit, I enjoyed a tuna melt with a cup of coffee. Everything was delicious. I even got a mini bag of cookies for checking in on Yelp. 
- The 2nd time, I came back to try their Japanese breakfast that I initially came in to try the first time. Rice, miso soup, poached egg, meyer lemon natto, daikon wakame salad, and market pickles. Brought me back to Japan and the mini dishes that they serve with rice or porridge for breakfast. Love!
- Service was fantastic and the cute couple that opened this restaurant is the best. The wife was so accommodating and made sure that I enjoyed my cup of coffee and everything was okay. 

Improvements
- Their old location was really small and limited in seating, but ever since their recent remodel there is a lot more space and plenty of seats outside. 

Tip
- They have a beautiful web site that allows you to view and make dinner reservations too!
author: Tracy T.

description:
I ran in to get the FREE Scoutmob deal, curry puff and peanut butter cookie! The curry puff was just ok nothing exciting. The peanut butter cookie was amazing! It was flaky, and tasted like a butterfinger! I want more.

The place is really cute but small. Not a whole lot of choices when I was there.
author: Karen T.

description:
I have wanted to come by here since their opening week. A scoutmob deal and a day off finally brought me here. Win.

The environment is super cute! Well thought out decors and interior designs. They have three small tables that each seat two and two extra chairs. Comforting.

The staff is pretty friendly. They're attentive, quick, and sweet. One of the other customers had a dog just outside, and they offered them water. Awesome.

My roommate and I had their chilled tomato soup, salad, curry puff, and their rendition of a peanut butter cookie. Appetizing. 

The soup $5: I've never had chilled tomato soup, but it was delicious. 

The salad $7: The thing that stuck out the most for us was the ginger. It's surprising and refreshing. I don't generally eat ginger by the spoonful like my roommate, but I ate it with the salad because it goes well with it. 

The curry puff: Flaky, tasty, and savory. Be right back, I think I'm going to get another one. 

Done. Got a brownie too. 

The peanut butter cookie: Different. They have cornflakes sprinkled on top to give it some crunch. The texture is very similar to a shortbread. Make sure you have something to drink with it. 

Their food presentation is beautiful. They do outsource some of their pastries, but they make the curry puff, peanut butter cookie, brownie, and the quiche in house. 

They serve Ritual coffee.
author: Becca I.

description: Their Randwich was delicious. It had avocados, truffle oil, turkey, and everything thing just tasted very good together.
author: My P.

description:
Great atmosphere, food & service - worth a trip out to 37th & Balboa if you don't live near this burgeoning, outer-Richmond enclave.  It's a small menu, so the options are limited for vegetarians.   I ordered 3, non-meat appetizers, which was more than enough food for dinner.  

There are outside tables, with heat-lamps.

Reasonably priced for good quality, wholesome food.
author: David H.

description:
I am in love with this place. Breakfast, Brunch, Dinner. Some of my favorites: the randwich, japanese breakfast, their tuna sandwich, their macarons (chilled and chewy!), their apple pear, carrot & celery drink

dinner was cute, intimate and yummy.
author: Shum S.

description: The food is ok, nothing really special about them.  We came here for the brunch,  not much choices on the menu.  The waffle is good, but pair w/ bacon is kind  of weird, wish there's more waffle instead of bacon.  The seating is very small, not comfortable at all.  Either they are too cheap to order nicer chairs or don't want you to sit there too long.   Their average dish is about $15, which I don't think it's worth it.     The reason I only give so few stars is because it's expensive,  considering the portion and off location of the restaurant.  It's just that the price of the dishes doesn't match with the ambience and the location of the place.  Way over priced!!!!!!
author: Lucy J.

description:
Cute decor/presentation and great atmosphere but food is BLAND! 

After getting seated and ordering, the food took about an hour to arrive at our table. Another table that got seated and ordered after us had already received their food way before ours came. We had the liege waffles, japanese breakfast, meatballs in a curry sauce and the vanilla panna cotta. Although presentation was great, the dishes lacked flavor. We had to add a generous amount of salt. The japanese albacore set included a few pieces of albacore or some sort of slightly seared fish, and that gave me a severe stomach ache. The panna cotta was the only thing that stood out and we all enjoyed. 

Bland food, slow service. Not worth the visit
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Cassava Bakery and Cafe is the latest hidden gem to bless the Richmond. I just redeemed my free curry puff and peanut butter cookie courtesy of Scoutmob. Delicious! The curry cream puff was hands down the best I've had, and the peanut butter cookie had the perfect amount butter, achieving decadence without guilt. They also have Ritual coffee -- a major plus.

The husband and wife owners were really sweet folks and provided one of the best costumer service interactions I've had. They were engaging, friendly and struck up a conversation about my screen printed "Gay for Gosling" T-shirt that lead to an awesome convo about the merits of Ryan Gosling. 

If you're ever out in the Richmond or nearby at Ocean Beach stop by. Even if you aren't Cassava is worth the trip west.
author: Quentin J.

description: The leige waffle plate, the grapefruit brûlée, and warmed chocolate croissant are definitely not healthy and totally delectable.
author: Jacquee P.

description:
The coffee is okey . But the food very disappointing. I had high expectations for this place because looks nice  and different compare to the other restaurants in that area.
The  people look too pretentious for the quality of food. all in all  is a mediocre restaurant
author: Cecilia C.

description:
Ahhhhh my old hood. My friend and I didn't have a reservation and there was 5 empty tables and the wait was 40 mins.  We left. 
Turn left and right hipsters are everywhere. Stay out of the Richmond District!
author: tina M.

description:
Came here for the scout mob deal - one curry puff and peanut butter with corn flake cookie for free! I checked in on Yelp and got a free cookie sampler as well! Score! 

Staff is friendly and patience.  I told the lady I was here for the scout mob deal and she held up a very professional attitude towards me.  (Some places automatically show annoyance after you tell them you're there for their free stuff).  She not only didn't pressure me in purchasing something, but her and the boss lady started chatting with me while I waited for my curry puff to come out of the oven.  

This place is small, but cute.  Prices are reasonable.  I felt bad for grabbing so much freebies, so I ordered a 12 oz regular coffee ($3).  It's a bit pricey for just coffee, but I was more than happy to pay that price for the amount of food I was getting. 

The peanut butter cookies were a little rich, but had a good taste texture along with the corn flakes on top.  Curry puffs had beef and potatoes in them - delicious! 

I would come back for a coffee date!
author: Nancy S.

description: This is the cutest place! I got the Maple Liege Waffle Plate. It filled me up! I actually don't care too much for bacon, but the thick cut bacon here was SO GOOD! Actually, everything on the plate was good so you should definitely order that ;). My boyfriend got the Japanese breakfast. He said it tasted healthy and it filled him up. I think natto is a acquired taste, so he wasn't too fond of that. Overall, amazing place! I cannot wait to come back next time I'm in SF!
author: Christina L.

description:
Never again. A very strange experience. I should have listened to my gut feeling when I first entered. Let me start with the service. I felt, that the waitress was very pushy. When we ordered the chicken and the lamb she told us that its going to be at least 30 minutes until the food was ready. Therefore we should get an appetizer. 
When the food came, the chicken was not cooked enough and so I send it back to the kitchen. The lamb was a disappointment. When we came home we both felt bloated, not a very good sign. On top its very expensive compared to other small restaurants in SF, they did not offer any bread. Overall its overpriced and
author: Guido W.

description: I have never felt so alienated about bringing my child to a restaurant. My child is relatively good for a 20 month old. It's very sad that the owner would be so unwelcoming - I am hoping it wasn't intentional. Food was great and so was the rest of the staff.
author: Jeannette L.

description:
An elusive one for me, their brunch schedules never seem to match up with mine! But my last trip to this quaint little shop for early lunch delighted me with a variety of healthy-feeling dishes. The staff were welcoming and charming! I had the pleasure of sampling their pork sliders, which had surprisingly slightly crisped pulled pork with a tangy coleslaw complement, their veggie bowl with poached eggs and their bourbon vanilla honey mocha latte. Their pork sliders were the perfect proportions, albeit a bit messy to devour with sauce dripping from all the sides! But I loved that it came with a side of minced, yes, minced(!) lettuce, which made eating it easier. The sliders surprisingly complemented my latte quite well with the slightly sweet tang of pork balancing out the bitterness of the mocha latte. I'd definitely get that combination again! Their veggie bowl had their signature koshinihikari rice with lots of different vegetables (zucchinis, lettuce, avocado, tomato, etc.), mushrooms, nuts and pesto sauce. The poached egg was a great touch. 

Their coffee was not bad, but I think I'll stick to their spiced honey latte next time. Their house coffee blend tended to be on the sour side, which I'm not sure if it's due to slightly burnt brewing or just the beans they use. However, I do love that they have milk alternatives (soy, almond) and always ask what milk/substitute you prefer.
author: Purnima G.

description:
After a good jog through Inner Richmond, Cassava hit just the right spot; their freshly juiced Apple+Pear+Carrot+Celery drink was immediately refreshing, and the chef did an awesome job with their signature Kris's Meal Salad.

I left for Ocean Beach feeling clean, fully energized, and ready for a full afternoon of exploration. We need more restaurants just like this.
author: Thom F.

description:
One of the best places for brunch, lunch and dinner in SF! Brunch on Saturday is extra cool because if you wear clothing with a cat on it (Cat-erday!), you get a free sangria or dessert! Pretty cool. Also, every Wednesday is "Wine Wednesday" and all bottles of wine are half off. 

My favorite brunch item is the waffle. The restaurant is intimate and very nice. I highly recommend it for dates or with a small group of friends!
author: Paul R.

description: I love Cassava and I don't want to share it with anyone. The owners are amazing & the staff is always ready with a smile. The food....let's just say that there are things on the menu that no one makes better. I've hunted the city for a better panna cotta and it just does not exist.  Eating at Cassava is not like going to a line cook restaurant, it's a personal experience.
author: B S.

description:
3.5 Stars.

Stopped by once for lunch on a weekday when the boss wanted to celebrate his new job. We just stumbled on this place and decided to try it, plus i wasn't paying.

What I had:
I had Kris's Meal Salad ($8): Mixed young lettuce, arugula, boiled egg, avocado, 
fennel, basil walnut pesto, sunflower seeds, apples, citrus vinaigrette. I really enjoyed this salad, and surprisingly felt satiated after my meal.I normally don't like large slices of avocado in general, but it was good.

Boss had the Shrimp & Avocado Sliders ($10): Poached shrimps, avocado, shredded lettuce, tomato-red onion salsa on challa buns. Can't really say much as I didn't try it, but he did eat everything.

We shared Noel's Panna Cotta ($4.5): Super creamy Italian milk flan with macerated berries for dessert. [Okay, he had two bites and I devoured the rest BUT in my defense HE was the one who ordered it. He claimed he just "wanted to try it" I can't waste a delicious dessert so I manned up and took one for the team] It was good, but a bit overpriced for such a small cup.

Why only 3 stars? Service left some to be desired. They didn't deliver our dessert until waaay after we finished the meal, and it seemed like they flat out forgot. We had to go up to the cashier and remind them we were waiting for it. We overheard the cashier (who was also serving as a barista) tell a cook, and then proceed to finish a drink order AFTER we told her we were waiting for our dessert. Um..it's Panna Cotta. It was sitting in their display unit, and all it required was a little mashed up fruit on top. She could have did it in less than a minute herself. But no, instead she continued to make a drink and then take two orders. Okay...so maybe a chef had to do something special that the cashier couldn't do? NOPE. The cashier brought it out almost 7 minutes later. We were a bit puzzled at what the wait was about, considering it was sitting in the case already made.

It was good, but nothing special that I'll be returning to anytime soon.
author: Jenna H.

description:
What can I say about Cassava that hasn't already been said? This place is for foodies who want a casual neighborhood place to dine that feels "special" every time you go. The cafe has quirk and style, and you always get service with a smile. And oh, the food.  They put love and care into everything they do, and it really shows in the quality of their offerings. Sometimes it can take longer to get your order but that's because this is not an "assembly line" type of place -- Kris is a talented chef who serves *cuisine*, not mere food. True art takes time! 

I've been there for breafast, lunch, and dinner and have left satiated and happy every time. I adore their Randwich, Kris' Meal Salad, and Meat Balls and Curry. My kids love their grilled cheese and tuna melt sandwiches, which sound ordinary but are somehow elevated here to SF foodie quality. They also have THE BEST macarons. Prices are reasonable considering the very high quality of what you're getting. 

The outer Richmond is super lucky to have Cassava!
author: SfMom O.

description: I came here for the Japanese breakfast and it was mmm mmm good! The resto is pretty small but they have a nice patio. Love the ambiance and the service, I would definitely come back.
author: Ennie L.

description: 3 of the stars are for good service and 1 star because I loved the cold brew but minus 1 star because I was pretty disappointed with my meal. I ordered the curry/tomato/meatball dish, it was in serious need of salt and it would have benefited from either more seasoning or a spicy element. I'm kinda bummed because I had wanted to eat here for months, I'll be back when their seasonal menu changes.
author: PJ L.

description:
It's a cute artisan food shop - only for foody people
it's really great, I love it ^_^ and their staff is super friendly
author: Kendra Z.

description: Very Good food, but the service was extremely slow even thought it wasn't busy. They have a nice beer selection, and the food was very tasty, but a little on the small side in regard to portion size.
author: Kirsty L.

description:
I love this charming cafe. It's hip and delicious. I come here often and have tried pretty much everything. For comfort, I get the tuna melt, which is top-notch. All of the sandwiches are pretty good, especially if you make it there for weekend brunch and order the Croque. The rice bowl is delicious. 

I also always get the spiced honey latte. When it is made well, there is no comparison! However, with this drink I've noticed some inconsistencies and it is not always the same. Another meal I wasn't too fond of was the quinoa salad. It lacked flavor in the citrus vinaigrette. Besides these 2 flubs, I will still return here weekly.
author: Michelle B.

description:
This is my favorite breakfast/brunch in the Richmond.  Everything I have tasted has been great.  It has the brunch trifecta: good food, good coffee, and good people.  

Note: Small/realistic portions. lots of dog friendly outdoor tables.
author: Courtney C.

description:
I have gone here a number of times for breakfast and lunch since they moved into the Richmond because the food options are somewhat limited around. They cater to the hipster crowd. The food portions are small and the prices are not exactly cheap. It's like Asian fusion..not quite Asian..not quite American...doesn't taste right. Every time  I leave here, I'm still hungry and dissatisfied, so hence, not coming back again.

2 stars because I haven't had food poisoning from them yet and they are not a neighborhood type restaurant (just watch the hipsters roll in all smug and rude).
author: Elena R.

description: This is my neighborhood spot and I am so happy to have it! Consistently great food. The smoked trout board is to die for, so rich and perfectly portioned! I just had the Japanese breakfast for the first time. I was craving something light and it perfectly hit the spot. I've had other brunch dishes, like the waffles with soft scrambled eggs, and they never disappoint. I've seen several reviews saying this place is expensive, but I feel like the price points are fair and what you would expect for a decent restaurant in the city. Also their wine prices at happy hour are outstanding and the selection is super on-point! Thank you Cassava for being in the Outer Richmond! We need more restaurants like yours!
author: Jessica E.

description: So many great things about this spot, tasty menu, sweet vibes, and they take reservations. For me it's a short walk through the park to this gem.  It is now my go to for brunch with visiting family and friends.  Takes me out of the bustle of inner/outer sunset food spots and into a sweet little slice of neighborhood. Their dishes have a great California flare, reasonable to SF prices, and friendly servers/staff.
author: Tatiana I.

description:
