As always, the food here is spectacular. Even to go, I thought it wouldn't be as great, but still, AMAZING.

Yuka read my reviews of the waits and less than stellar customer service and was so  taken aback that I had this experience at Cassava that she was upset that I would have to deal with this.It takes a smart business manager to recognize that social media has become such a huge soapbox for alot of people, the take into consideration what their online reputation is. Im such a stickler for customer service. The meals at a restaurant can be down right terrible, but if the service is great, It can be its saving grace.

She approached me and said that they take these posts very seriously and will make her staff aware of the areas they can improve.

Its so refreshing to see this happen. They actually listen to what people have to say and then make the necessary changes. She let me know, they are working towards letting people know, if they are busy, they may have a longer wait, as they do have a small kitchen. Yuka and Chris really work hard to make sure everyone  has a great experience here.

Ladies and Gentlemen, Please do not let my previous reviews discourage you, Cassava has redeemed itself ten times over, sometimes just the simple act of acknowledgement goes leaps and bounds.

BTW, the breakfast combo (waffle/toast, eggs (cooked perfectly every time), Jam, and salad has been GREAT every time I get, AND they serve Fatted Calf bacon, need I say more.

Ive laready told my husband here, I want to do the pre-fixe dinner for my birthday!
author: Poonam G.

description:
Other than the block of my front porch & the ocean, this is becoming my favorite block in SF. In the hinterlands of the Outer Richmond, Shanghai Dumpling King, the Balboa Theatre, plus Cassava, we have ourselves a classic dinner + movie situation. 

Cassava might be the perfect food proprietor. They're own baked goods, this thing called a Japanese Breakfast, traditional-over-the-top dishes like Truffle Chorizo Hash + truly-traditional scrambles & croissant sandwiches + savory puff pastries, and rounded out with Cassis juice & Ritual coffee on siphon pots, I have no idea how this happened. Wait, yes I do, someone -- read Cassava -- sat down to really think about this, created a list, and continues to create a list, of being a remarkable business in the face of SF's competition. 

With only three tables inside, and three tables outside, clearly this is difficult to deal with. News on their website states they're expanding next door! So... hopefully that remedies that situation. And really that's the only remedy to deal with. 

Looks like the dinners book up pretty quickly, and the chef's tasting menus are remarkable. I'd say I'll be re-routing my commute sometimes, or Saturday morning routines for baked goods, siphon pots, and a movie. 

Also, this was the most adorable brunch I've ever had.
author: Jon A.

description: Dear Cassava, thank you. Thank you for freeing the simple people of the Outer Richmond from the tyranny of Simple Pleasures and Zephyr! I've been waiting for this day a looong time. Gone are the days of rude service, smelly furniture and depressing decor. But best of all, gone are the days of bad coffee! I can't tell you how much I enjoy ordering a cappuccino and actually getting a... cappuccino, and not some ambiguous, frothy/wet, sloppy, overly bitter coffee mess (that's right, I'm talking to you SP). Plus, they serve almond milk here (which is pretty rare for a coffee shop) and the food is good. To summarize: this place is awesome. Simple Pleasures and Zephyr, shame on you; take notes and step up your game!
author: Eugene M.

description: The portions look small but they're very tasty. A bit on the expensive side. I had the breakfast sandwich and a coffee - no complains about either
author: Ryuta O.

description:
This place is fantastic, all day, every day.  

Yelp - please remove the ridiculous review of 2/8/2015 below from Marcella K.  While I absolutely respect anyone's decision to live a vegan lifestyle, how is it fair to rate a place 1 star because it does not conform to your opinion?  Ridiculous.  

Yelp's review guidelines state : " reviews aren't the place for rants about a business's employment practices, political ideologies, extraordinary circumstances, or other matters that don't address the core of the consumer experience".

The extent of this person's consumer experience was to look at a menu in the window.  

I have flagged Marcella K's review.  I hope others will do likewise. 

Of course, my review does not conform to Yelp's guidelines either, but I'm only able to mark Marcella Ks review as "Helpful", "Funny" or "Cool". It's certainly none of those 3.  A 4th option ("Ridiculous") would be great!  It's potentially damaging to a small, community focused restaurant loved by many of us in the neighborhood (and elsewhere).

Rest assured I have had many consumer experiences at Cassava, and it is truly a wonderful place.
author: James F.

description:
I live on Anza near the 40s and all of us that live in the Outer Richmond seriously should be thankful to have such a high caliber restaurant like Cassava in our backyards. 

Everything about the restaurant puts a smile to my face, from the playing cards acting as your order number, to the sharply dressed servers (knit ties anyone?) And the food is equally as enjoyable.

Coffee? Check.  Honey Spiced Latte
Brunch? Check.  Pork Sliders
Dessert? Check. Pistachio and Raspberry Macarons

Also, remember that you don't need to be waited to be seated. Just order and grab a seat inside, or heated seating outside if you're lucky and the fog hasn't rolled in!
author: Kevin C.

description: Over priced,mediocre dishes with poor atmosphere. I had a steamed halibut that was tasteless and even the veggies it was served on were devoid of flavor.
author: Gerard C.

description: This little bakery is super cute! I'm so glad I was finally able to stop by. Babe got a chocolate chip cookie and he said he was really yummy. I, on the otherhand, got the peanut butter + cornflakes cookie and the mushroom quiche. The cookie was delish! It wasn't overyly sweet, which completely won me over. As for the quiche... ohhh my goodness. HEAVEN. This was so amazing, even though I didn't eat it until 2 days later. Imagine what it'd taste like had I actually ate it when I bought it! The crust was so crisp and buttery, I want another one right now. I'm excited to go back and try new things! The owners are really friendly and I know this place will do really well.
author: Ann T.

description:
Like Cherylynn N. has said, this place is CUTE (all caps necessary). I'd been wanting to try this place for some time, and am so glad I was finally able to visit post-remodeling. The new space is full of natural light and cute touches: succulents, chalkboard murals, adorable Etsy-esque wallpaper. I wanted to eat it all up! but had to save up my appetite for the real food.

Service was fast and incredibly friendly. You get the impression that they really care about the customer experience. I was allowed to order a breakfast item, the truffle hash bowl, for lunch. It was really good, although I did wish it was a bit warmer and a little less oily (though, on the flip side, I appreciate that they don't skimp on the truffle oil, like so many restos tend to do). My friends enjoyed their Kris' meal salad and grilled cheese as well. I ended my meal with a green tea and yuzu macaron -- impossibly light and subtle. How could I ask for more?

So very thankful that a place like Cassava exists in the neighborhood. You can be sure I'll be back!
author: Julie D.

description:
YUMMY!

I was lured out to the Outer Richmond by the Scoutmob 100% off deal for a peanut butter cookie and Curry Puff. However, after experiencing this little gem, I would make the trek back in a heartbeat. I almost wish I lived in the neighborhood because this place is AWESOME. My new favorite cafe, hands down. 

The owners are incredibly friendly, enthusiastic, and adorable, and the decor is welcoming, well thought out, and a bit whimsical. My favorite touch was definitely the quotes on the wall. They all really spoke to me and added a level of personalization that I found endearing. I really could go on forever with adjectives about Cassava. It's so great to go to a place where the owners are clearly really excited to be there and to share their passion with their customers.  

Not to mention the food was awesome. The Curry Puff was crazy delicious, all their coffee is made from Ritual Roasters, and they have a some crazy bourbon mocha drink that I'll have to try next time. 

Highly recommend.
author: Talia G.

description:
Delicious food! Nice to have a younger establishment in our hood. I'd say they are gluten-free neutral... Good options/subs but couldn't recommend for celiacs. Staff are really helpful, a little on the pricey side for the neighborhood but honestly it's comparable to what you'd pay in the Mission- and I don't have to find parking!

P.S. Hubby wants you to bring back the croissant Black Forest ham, egg and herb breakfast sandwich!
author: Michelle L.

description: Went there to celebrate my moms birthday. It was a great choice! My boyfriend is a Michelin star chef and loved it too. Nicely presented well thought
author: Amanda A.

description:
I was dragged here on a gorgeous sunny clear day because one of my girls insisted on coming here for brunch. This was around when they were newly opened in 2012 (yes, long overdue review). Quaint little shop that only had about 6 tables (before the renovation) so definitely not recommended for groups.

Our order:
Meatballs in Curry: ($10) Half Tofu & Half Beef Meatballs in "butter chicken" Tomato Cream Curry Gravy, Paneer, with Koshihikari Rice 
Shrimp and Avocado Sliders: ($10) Poached Shrimps, Avocado, Shredded Lettuce, Tomato-Red Onion Salsa on Challa Buns
Macrons: Green Tea w/ Yuzu, Earl Grey, Pistachio

Meatballs were really tender and juicy and packed full of flavor. The sliders had very fresh ingredients and were mouth watering. Good flavors and texture in the macrons.

Owners are super friendly. Highly recommend!
author: Kitty K.

description:
I had read a lot of the reviews on the restaurant and really wanted to try it based on the reviews. This is always risky because your expectations based on high reviews is always higher. We were able to set up a reservation through yelp which was advised (because this place is small I would also recommend). We arrived, we seated and were impressed. The service is everything that has been commented on - staff is friendly and helpful. 

Food was everything I expected from the reviews. It was brunch and I had the short ribs which were tender, but what I loved most about this dish was the different textures in the dish - there was a creamy element, a crunchy element, and some savory flavors from the braised meat. 

My boyfriend had the meatballs in curry sauce and WOW - nicely done. A good portion of meatballs and the only challenging part of this dish is to figure out the best way to get it all in your mouth.

This restaurant is a little out of our way, but we will be back. 

Well done.
author: Apryl H.

description:
The 5th star is for Kris and his wife! 

I came here for a Sunday morning breakfast after hearing so many wonderful things. We indulged in the famous Japanese breakfast and the curry meatballs on the downward sloping street outside. We were served piping hot coffee and a heated up croissant as well, which were very welcome in the brisk air.

It's well covered in the other reviews, but Cassava is a bright, shining gem even when it was drab outside. The owners told us that they'll be shutting down for two weeks starting 5/13 so they can expand to a new space to better accommodate diner appetite.

Space-wise; it's tiny, cozy, and apparently impossible to for diners to get dinner reservations (but Yuka did mention following their Facebook = hope for cancelled reservations). Hopefully all will change with their new space, and I'll be back then!
author: Merlyn D.

description: Such a good place! Definitely try Panna Cotta, it's melting on your tongue. Take it with Madeira.
author: Alexandra S.

description:
Really cute cafe in Outer Richmond, its kind of hard to spot but it is a good place to go with a friend and just to have a cup of coffee. But, the drinks are pretty pricey. I order the bourbon vanilla honey mocha, sadly it wasn't up for the standards. I paid $4 dollars for the drink, but all i tasted was just a standard mocha. I couldn't taste the vanilla or the honey. It just makes me question whats so special about the drinks? The bakery selection was interesting, I had the curry puffs, it was pretty good. The aroma of the curry was tempting and your first bite of the curry puff would definitely leave an impression. The peanut butter cookie was also pretty good but didn't leave as big of an impression. 

I liked my experience at Cassava the people were nice, although there could be more selections for the menu selection. One thing I like about Cassava is that there are a lot of promotion going on, meaning FREE STUFFs! if you get the scoutmob app on the android or the iphone, you get a free curry puff and a peanut butter cookie or if you just want a cookie check in on YELP and get a free bag of cookie samplers.
author: Amy T.

description: Amazing- from the wonderful family that runs the restaurant to the beautiful in season, local food and great service. Went for the first time to try the Japanese breakfast and it was delicious. The brunch menu - every item on the menu is delicious from the eggs- to waffles- and my fav the japenese choice. Came back for dinner last week, and again was impressed. I had the quinoa porridge with an egg- and it was so good- it had trumpet mushrooms and butternut squash and each bite was great. The rest of the family, had the steak- perfectly grilled, and the salmon was perfect- and the gorgeous flowers on each plate- really were the perfect touch. It was my a friends birthday and they gave us the last berry cobbler- and topped it with a candle. Service is delightful and energy of the place is calm, not too loud and the perfect amount of tables. Can't wait to go back!
author: Jill S.

description:
Came here for brunch on a Sunday, and it was hoppin'. It's a smaller restaurant but well decorated with lots of flowers to give it this kind of fresh, airy vibe. Also some nice outdoor seating.

The food is excellent. New twists on some familiar dishes and absolutely delicious. I got the mr & mrs croque sandwich, which I recommend if you love pesto and avocado. The service was a little slow, which was understandable since they were so busy.
author: Trisha K.

description:
The best brunch in San Francisco!

In addition to incredibly delicious food (the Croque sandwich and the Liege waffle are my two recommendations), Cassava really stands out due to the great customer service. 

The owner goes out of her way every time to make us feel at home, even going so far as to surprise us with mimosas and a truly amazing panna cotta during a recent birthday celebration. 

It's a little out way for me, but the thought of a spiced honey latte and a delicious brunch is more than enough to merit the trek into the Outerlands.
author: Madeline S.

description: We decided to try Cassava as an alternative to Marla's and were hugely disappointed. It took the good part of an hour to get our entrees and mine (pork rib hash) didn't even have any potatoes in it! They rectified it and didn't charge me for it, but it was so late at that point. Basically, my husband waited all that time for a grilled cheese sandwich with ham. Big $$ for little food...
author: Antoinette S.

description:
Cassava Cassava. Finally was able to try this place.  Cassava is located at the corner in the Outer Richmond on Balboa - near George Washington High School. The location is great and very quiet for a mostly inexpensive place. 

I ordered the scrambled eggs with toast. The food arrived in about 10 minutes.  It was GREAT!  The scrambled eggs were completely different than so MANY other places I've been to for brunch.  Not to mention, they also have macaroons, and I LOVED them.  The green tea macaroons were very good and light, but on the inside there was this sweeter jelly which added great flavor.  The coffee was made much, much differently than any place that I've tried before, and even though I know it was made healthier, it wasn't my favorite - but still good!

Overall, if you are looking for a sweet little brunch place in the outer Richmond that is comparable to all the amazing brunch around the Richmond area, i'd definitely say that this place is worth a try easily! Great staff, great food and great environment.
author: Alex B.

description: Came here for brunch after spotting out of the car window a little while back & noticing that it looked busy/buzzy! We were incredibly impressed with both the quality of the food & the extreme friendliness of the service. I ordered the tofu & beef meatball curry (served with rice & a fried egg) & my partner had the rib hash. Both were completely delicious. My bf (who can be a hard man to please) said the meat was succulent & melted off the bone. In fact, it was so good he ordered the bread pudding for dessert! Now he's a bit of a bread pudding obsessive so I was slightly nervous tbh (we're British so we're raised on this sort of stuff) but - as the waiter jokingly commented - he completely polished it off. I didn't need to ask whether it was good or not because his first question was when we could come back to try their evening tasting menu with wine pairings. Very soon I should think! Thoroughly recommended for people who appreciate good food and great menu design.
author: Fi M.

description:
When a friend suggested we hit up Cassava for brunch, I was more than happy to give it a whirl. Once I saw the menu, I was a little distressed though, as their brunch options seemed pretty meat heavy. Luckily, the waiter and chef were willing to make me a veggie version of the Fried Egg Croque Monsieur, since I wasn't in the mood for a waffle or breakfast salad. The pesto really made the sandwich, and my friend's Japanese breakfast was stunningly beautiful. 

The coffee they serve is from Ritual and in great big mugs. I found it to be a bit sour but decent. You order coffee by size, and unfortunately neither of us were able to drink our 16 oz coffees before they were cold. It'd be much better if there was a refill option (even just one refill that you pay for) so you could have hot coffee both before your meal and during. 

We got there right when they opened, and within about 20 minutes, there was a considerable line and the place was packed. We ended up moving outside right after being seated as it felt rather sauna-like inside. Loved sitting out on the sidewalk, people watching, dog watching, listening to the conversations around us. It was also really neat that the kitchen/cooking area is right next to the window, so you can see the food being prepared. Go support this newish business, because they absolutely deserve it and are clearly putting their hearts and souls into making something really interesting and lovely.
author: Amanda A.

description:
I truly LOVE this place. I've really loved it since the first visit, when I stepped inside to see what kind of new adorableness was going on on outer Balboa-my soon to be new home drag. Since then, the love affair has only grown. The proprietors are sweet lovely people, working their asses off while maintaining a smile for everyone. The food, the ambience and the service all clearly show what a labor of love Cassava is. Truly a little gem. I wish more businesses showed such attention to detail and love. The outer Richmond is quite sparse on finer dining. Thank goodness for cassava.  

 A few lovely things:

1.They warm up my morning bun.....Mmmm, sweet, sugary, crackly indulgence
3. Shrimp sliders
4. Creative drinks
5. Cool books to pick up and read and be inspired by

I can't wait for the expansion into the building next door. I haven't had one of their pre fix dinners yet, but my mouth waters in anticipation.
author: jessica h.

description:
I love this place! It has a nice feel - beautifully decorated with a cozy outdoor patio. I always bring my dog and they offer her water and have a heater overhead.

Their spiced honey latte is absolutely amazing, I can't go there and not order it. The food is very yummy, healthy, and reasonably priced, used with what seems to be organic and local ingredients. I think their lunch offers the best deals: especially their grilled cheese with arugula and tomato. I also had a fun dinner date night here; great sangria (also with spiced honey) and truffle and cheese chips! I'll have to go back for brunch. 

Cassava is definitely one of the best spots in the Outer RIchmond.
author: Jamie O.

description:
This is one very long over due review... came here on May 27th 2012. I remember because it was the Golden Gate Bridge's 75th Anniversary.  

My Friend and I decided to hike to the GGB in the early morning to beat the crowd. We started around the VA Hospital around 7 am, and well... the crowd beat us.
When we got back into the Richmond District by non we were starving, tired, and ready to chow down. 

We ordered the Japanese Breakfast, Honey Latte (my fave), and Green Tea Latte. 
We never had a "Japanese Breakfast" before so we were curious... yes it's mostly just rice and some of the add ins were new to me. For $10 yo get
Koshihikari rice, ichiban dashi miso soup, sous vide "onsen tamago" poached egg, Meyer lemon "kosho" natto, daikon wakame salad, market pickles.
A light yet filling Japanese Breakfast was surprising satisfying after a long hike. and on a cold windy day... the latte was just soothing and perfect. 

we also received complimentary cookies for moving over to let family have room to sit together. Thank you Cassava! now can you please open up at 7am so i can order a latte before work?
author: Lynn T.

description: Great breakfast place! The breakfast croissants are delicious. Also they have a huge variety of drinks, I really liked the honey mocha. I thought the macaroons were not that great though, the flavors were a little weird: raspberry was delicious, but the brownish and rose ones were not that good. Overall, a great breakfast, and less expensive than most. It gets busy closer to lunch, I will have to come back and give it a try.
author: Nikita K.

description: Had the waffle plate today for brunch first time there it was ok :-/ plate presentation looks amazing on everything but For sure everything is over priced and you and food is just barley ok all thought I do not recommend this place for brunch I will give them another chance for dinner
author: David J.

description: Stopped here for brunch before a hike. We had the smoked ocean trout starter, Duck confit salad and the lemon panna cotta. Everything was fantastic. Very glad we decided to stop here. Will be back!
author: Faiz S.

description:
This. This is what I want. Open up a cute bakery + cafe, serve people delicious amazing foods -- it's perfect.. 

Randwich - super truffle-y turkey, avocado, tomato, (perfectly) poached egg sandwich. Not a huge portion for $10, but decent brunch price and tasty. 

Curry Paneer Half Meat, Half Tofu Meatballs w/ Rice - YUM. They torch it. Kind of awesome, really delicious. 

2 small Lattes

Super small but adorable space. Communal tables inside and out, but they were full, so they set us up with a tiny table on the edge of the sidewalk. Ahhhhh adorbs and hilarious, and weird that we're sitting next to someone's car. Cute table, cold street, but we luckily got moved indoors when a small table opened up. The couple who owns this place were really nice. I'll be back to try more -- there menu looks amazing!

I imagine the wait gets crazy as there is such limited seating, but the food was worth it.
author: Donna H.

description:
Pork Sliders = 4.5 awesome! 
Meatballs with poached egg =3.7 egg didn't make a difference 

Gibraltar 4.8
Southern ice tea 4.3
author: Andrew S.

description:
The owners and employees are all super sweet and the food is delightful :) not to mention the interior design is KAH-YOOOOT! Love the tiny flower arrangements on the tables.

Coffee: they use ritual coffee. Good.
Espresso: (sipping on a cassava latte as I type this, no lie) lattes are good! Never burnt-tasting
They do not serve decaf. They have 2% milk! Unlike those other snobby coffee places that only use whole milk for their lattes. There are people trying to watch their figures here, yadadamean?!

Food: I love the croissant breakfast sandwich, their quiches, the fluffy buttery scrambled eggs and house made (I think?) jams/jellies/preserves etc... 
They have semifreddi's morning buns!!!
What else.. tuna melt good, meatballs and curry good, randwich gooood.
I want to come back and try the Japanese breakfast.

Love you cassava
author: Bianca Y.

description:
After spending half an hour looking for parking in that area, I dropped by that place and asked for a coffee to go. The rude waitress looked at me with very cold eyes, said that they were too busy to make coffee and pointed me to the door.
I just wanted to enjoy some coffee from there but it seems they don't welcome you as a customer if you won't pay for their overpriced menu.
author: Vincent L.

description:
I also tried to like Cassava. I think its what the Outer Richmond area on Balboa really needed, some new culinary taste for diners dying to empty their pockets. Trying to tap into the yuppie high end, with their "higher than any other in the neighborhood" prices for pastries and Asian influenced flair, they have a growing following. Add that the "limited special menu" closed dinners - normally for the occasional pop up dinners, this is Cassava's secret to bump up business.

Pros - clean and inviting environment, fresh menu selection.

Cons - higher prices, management being able to track menu availability (once we went there, we had to wait an additional 20 minutes after paying and seating due to "out of rice", second time was turned away all together at their "GRAND RE-OPENING  on July 4" because the RAN OUT OF FOOD!!).

I may try to see if they get their act together and give them another shot, we'll see how it goes!
author: Mark M.

description:
A quick hop, skip and a jump from The Legion Of Honor! Bonus way to skip the crowds, but get some art first! Warm service. Generous glass of GOOD " Curator", ( a Red blend) helps the morning pass,with ease. Warm, busy, urban chic ambiance, very young cosmopolitan (NO  - I mean .... San Franciscan). 
Flavorsome food  i.e. "Flavorful" ( in Americanspeak), with no supersizing. Come for brunch, keeping in mind the weekend menu. Just right!
author: Tim C.

description: Food here is great, really fresh ingredients and cooked very well. The reason for 3 stars is the service. Wait staff does not seem organized or aware of how the tables are doing and checking in. Hostess there was great! She even came to clean our table and check on us when the waitress was barely seen. If you want good food I suggest coming but be prepared to flag your waiter often.
author: Micheal B.

description: This place is small and I heard it can get quite crowded. We came on an off-hour though and managed to get seats at one of the tables inside. I love everything about this place. I enjoy the way it's decorated, the food, and the friendliness of those behind the counter (as well as other patrons). I got the green tea macaron with yuzu jelly, a rose water honey tea concoction, and the tuna melt. The macaron was good, though I wish I could taste the yuzu flavor more. The tea was very refreshing. The tuna melt was scrumptious and "cute" too. Yes, cute may be a weird adjective but I enjoy food aesthetics. I thought the shrimp slider was even cuter, and that tasted yummy also.
author: James K.

description: its def a lovely spot with very friendly people.   Yet my waffle seems to be quite bland without much fresshness or egg-ness I could taste.   The food looks beautiful but could be improved with flavors.
author: Shuting Z.

description:
Totally overrated.

How come people can rate a place for 4 stars or 5 stars if you still hungry after the meal?  Sorry, I don't.

I paid $10 for Japanese Breakfast.  It was terrible.  Since I live in Japan for long time, don't fool me, ok?

The wait staff explained to me what's on the plate.  Sushi Rice.  

Sushi Rice?!  In Japan, they don't serve sushi rice for breakfast.  Let me tell you dumb ass yelp bloggers and yelp readeers, "Sushi Rice is cooked short grain rice mixed with rice vinegar, sugar and salt".  That's the only the definition of "Sushi Rice"  Get it?

Anyway, since the waiter told me that "Sushi Rice", I smelled it before I ate.  Of course, it's not "Sushi Rice".

And one table spoon of seaweed salad, one table spoon of marinated kelp (Hijiki), one table spoon of natto, Japanese poached egg, and miso soup.

What do you want me to do?  When I saw the portion of natto, I felt RAGE in my heart!  If I put the natto on the rice, it would be done by one bite.  I expected at least 8 more bites of natto with rice for my breakfast!!

Then they charge $10 for this peice of s*#t?  And eating on the F cold sidewalk table in Outer Richmond?  give me a break!!

And my friend ordered Quiche with salad for $6.  It was good.  But $ 6 for 4 bits of Quiche?  Rip off.

Right after the pathetic breakfast, I ran to a corner store and got a pair of twinkies.
author: Mike N.

description:
13.07.24  - 2nd Visit - after remodeling


4 1/2          Food
4               Place



This is one to check out.

The following list points out why they are successful and going places.
      They do not stop improving
      Strive to get the best local products like:
              Phillipe Pasterie
      Beautiful, bright, and sparkling clean and easy on the eye
      Each dish were beautifully plated
      etc


Japanese Breakfast (For Here Only) 
        koshihikari rice,
        ichiban dashi miso soup, 
        sous vide "onsen tamago" poached egg, 
        meyer lemon kosho natto, 
        daikon wakame salad, 
        simmered hijiki
 and konnyaku noodles 10.00
        Trout ... you gotta add this or you will regret it


Truffle Chorizo Hash Bowl
         pork chorizo, 
         truffle oil tossed baby potatoes, 
         cauliflower, 
         zucchini, 
         brussel sprouts, 
         mushroom, 
         soft poached egg, 
         arugula.

Warning ... the above dishes are not HungryMan sized
They make up in parcels of tasty morsels that enlightening your taste buds.




Warning ... They close down at 3pm!!!

                   WHY ... close at 3pm?

We we rushing through our meal ... more and detailed review to come.\

Cannot wait to revisit this exciting place!

CHOW
author: S.K. Y.

description:
This place is really cute...including the young couple that runs the joint. They were both very friendly and helpful.  I got the FREE curry puff and peanut butter cookie deal from Scoutmob!  The food was good, so I'll definitely be back to try their breakfast and lunch items.  I'm glad it's only a few blocks away from my house.  

Although, there is one thing I hope they would offer in the near future: Filipino cassava cake!  I'll keep my fingers crossed.
author: Lyn D.

description:
I could not love this place more!  Every time I go there is something new and yummy.  
After being disappointed by Outerlands (again!) I am reminded that the 'it' place can still be awesome without being pretentious and expensive.

Cassava is the 'it' place that keeps on giving!  Delicious food, good portions and worth the not ridiculously expensive prices.

I love the cocktails and my tween/teen kids love to try all the interesting food.  Gotta love that they also support my adventurous kids!

Kudos to the owners for keeping it fresh, delicious and fun for over 2 years!
author: Christine G.

description: Wonderful staff awesome dishes- delicious bites, creative cocktails, outdoor seating. Perfect little spot for fresh deliciousness in the neighborhood. Thank you kindly Cassava!
author: Kai W.

description:
Cassava is the best!!
Not just a simple cafe where they serve some coffee and tea.
They have the most tasty, delish, rich flavored brunch menu with coffee that fits perfectly. My boyfriend and I used to go there on weekends to have this bomb ass shrimp avocado sliders and tuna melt sandwiches. OMG, they just melt in your tongue, it is a MUST!
Plus, the owner Japanese lady who usually takes the order is really nice and she remembers the customers very well.

Anyways, it is just a must-go-place for weekend brunches!!
author: Yoon Ah K.

description: I love this place! Been here three times for brunch.  Food, employees, and the business itself is great. The place is cute with a relaxing atmosphere. The environment is laid back and casual, which makes you feel comfortable when you eat there. There's seating inside and outside. The waiters/waitresses were kind and so was the owner. Food is definitely worth a try; different and stands out. Not a typical brunch place because it's a mixed of American and Japanese food, which I think is great. So far the two dishes I had were the Japanese breakfast and Quinoa. Since I'm vegetarian the server offered to substitute the meat with avocado, which made me really happy because I'm a big fan of avocados!
author: Tiramisu W.

description:
It's great to have a bakery in the outer Richmond. The other coffee shops do not serve breakfast and brunch so this place is a nice go-to for the weekends. 

I've only had the croissant sandwich. It was so tasty and I gobbled it up. It was a little greasier than most croissants (the kind where you have to wash your face after you eat) but overall the buttery crunch is a definitely satisfying start to a lazy Sunday.
author: Kelly S.

description:
I'd been curious about this place for a while, and finally saw the chance to get a table inside and took it. 

Ordered a quiche for $5 which turned out to be very small but extremely tasty and came with a $1 salad option, which was disappointingly tiny, and sort of like charging for garnish. 

I left rather hungry, and went out and got some Raisin Bran at Better Food Market down the street and had a bowl to complete my breakfast.

Maybe I'm just not used to this kind of eating, but I don't feel much pull to come back.  It's obviously good food, but I'm not generally willing to spend $9 for breakfast (incl $2 for tea and $1 tip)  for such a small amount of food.
author: Lawrence S.

description:
I love this place! I wish it wasn't so far away from where I live!

The atmosphere is cute and cozy and the servers are VERY friendly.

I had the rand-wich and it was amazing! Mmm the pesto, mmm the poached egg! MMMMM!!! It was just the right portion too. I also had their special spiced honey latte which was sooo good! Granted a little pricey for a latte but I'd still go back to order it!

I definitely need to try to come back here for their dinner option!
author: Michelle L.

description:
My review hasn't really changed. This is still a wonderful place which just keeps better as the owners continue to perfect their craft. 

The reason for this update is that I have a beef with some of the foodie reviewers who don't seem to really know Japanese food. First, 'ichiban dashi'--no idea what is so special about that. One should ALWAYS use ichiban dashi for dishes where the broth takes center stage such as soups. Niban dashi is saved to use in dishes where you need that bit of dashi flavor, but other elements are also important (maybe use niban dashi in the hijiki side dish?). This distinction of ichiban vs niban is a nod to the resourcefulness of Japanese culture, and less of an artisanal element. The real point is that they MAKE THEIR OWN DASHI PEOPLE!!!! No dashi granules or dashi tea bags here.

Onsen eggs?? I think it is a marketing strategy, but they are basically poached eggs which Kris does with care and skill.  What is really special about their Japanese breakfast is how they make it special in their own way. The natto is cut with lemon and chili to make it a bit more palatable to non-Japanese, but it is also a wonderful version of natto itself. The yuzu kosho on the rice is also a lovely touch, neither of which you will find in a typical Japanese breakfast.

With regards to calling the rice 'sushi rice', I agree that it is not sumeshi, or the vinegared rice to use for sushi. Rather, it is high quality short grain Japanese rice. In local parlance, it seems to be used to distinguish it from other types of rice such as long grain used in many Chinese and Indian dishes. I think the staff are just trying to explain Japanese foods to non-Japanese?

I am glad this place is doing so well. I just wish foodie critics would stop focusing on the bathwater (ichiban dashi?) and discover the baby (meyer lemon natto? now that is news)!!
author: 和子

description: Really wanted to like this place.  Perhaps I miss-ordered?  Went for lunch today and got the shrimp sliders and grilled cheese.  The grilled cheese wasn't grilled and the shrimp sliders were just not good.  Bummer.
author: Scott L.

description:
Really cute and cozy space. 
Coffees are good and so are their non-coffee options. 
Food is good and playful fusion, but would not go again for brunch as we spent around $60 for 2.
author: Cindy C.

description: We ordered Japanese Breakfast and Meatballs in curry with rice, both are pretty good. Nice place for hanging out with friends and family.
author: Xiaorong Z.

description: Cassava is a great neighborhood spot. Love the place. Their staff is super friendly and their food is tasty. I love their shrimp sliders and curry meatballs. I've been to a few of their dinner services, and they do not disappoint.
author: Albert L.

description:
They need more tables and a better name. Other than that, this place is AWESOME. They make a honey chai latte (I think that's what I drank) that will knock your socks off.  Reminds me of the cute little fusion cafes in Japan. 

Blink and you'll drive right by this place. So how did we find this place? We were waiting for a movie outside Balboa and a random stranger was telling anyone who would listen that he was drinking the best coffee of his life. He was speaking the truth.
author: L. M.

description: I love discovering new brunch places and so excited about Cassava! My partner and I had Saturday brunch here and made reservations via Open Table. I highly recommend it so you don't have to wait. We got there and was seated immediately! I ordered the tofu meatball curry dish it was sooo delish!! The pomegranate white sangria and bourbon honey mocha with almond milk was also amazing!
author: Mango Lover ..

description: Came for a weekday breakfast and the place is charming and pretty clean.  I ordered croissant sandwich and drip coffee.  Both were ok.  I think the eggs in the sandwich could've used some salt, and my croissant was almost burnt.  The coffee was nothing special.  Good service though!
author: Winnie L.

description: I've tried the the avocado/egg toast, the meatball curry, and the Japanese Breakfast. All were delicious and perfectly cooked and presented :) Really impressed with the quality and attention to detail at this local spot, especially for the prices! Would recommend it to anyone.
author: Miko S.

description:
In brief -- scant staff and cozy fit result in long lines that are only worth the wait if you're ready to spend $43 on brunch that is the size of your fist. Don't be legitimately hungry and don't get legitimately hungry over your wait time. Don't park at the meters if you can help it.

Scant staff - food orders seem to only be taken by the owner.  Everyone else are food runners or kitchen staff.  Be prepared to wait 15 min. at least to be (i) noticed and (ii) approached again if you weren't 100% decided.  Ex. My bf and I stared at the tiny menu outside as much as we could without crowding the doorway and outside tables. We thought at least 1 dish sounded good but were ambiguous as to the other dishes. Sign says "Ask Cassava and not Yelp" so we thought we'd respect that and ask the owner that took food orders once we got seated. "We're trying to decide between the curry and meatballs versus the Japanese breakfast," I say. "Everything's good here," she answers. So enlightening. No conflict of interest at all. Yelpers had preferred curry, but I didn't want curry for breakfast so I went with Japanese. SO MISERABLE THAT I DID. (Food reviews below.)

Cozy fit - not a bad thing nec. because the restaurant is arranged adorably and you kind of get the benefit of an open kitchen. Benefit being that you can tell they're working back there. (Somehow working.) However, having that the open kitchen steams up the restaurant a bit, so you'll feel warm in your Outer Richmond clothes.

Long lines - lemme just advise that you ask what the wait is and then assess how much you want to pay on top of food cost and tips just to sit out the wait time plus lunch time plus bill waiting time.

$43 on brunch - managed this bill with only 2 breakfast orders and 2 coffees. NEVER ORDER COFFEE HERE. You will be served drip coffee in an espresso cup without any offer for refills YET CHARGED $4!  It's not great coffee either. I felt the need to polish off all the cream and sugar just to avoid continuously gaping. Food here appears to be health-conscious, which is good, but lacks salt and seasoning, which is too basic to be acceptable. 

Food review:

- Braised shortribs were tasty but the meat comprises 10% of your $17 bowl. That is, I got about 5 pieces of shortrib bites in my bowl. Savor those bites. The rest of the bowl is cold salad and quinoa and egg. Warm shortrib and over easy egg are served on top of a cold salad, so you end up with cold items getting heat in this bowl. Food Network judges would NOT approve. Cassava could have served the hot and cold items separately in this case or by employing the compartmentalized tray used in Japanese breakfast. Duh? Overall, this breakfast item scores 3 / 5.

- Japanese breakfast is THE WORST. You'll get rice, cold miso soup, sour/bitter canned fermented soybeans, and pinches of pickle and wakame (seaweed). The rice was the best part. Everything else was bland and cold... BUT WHY DID IT TAKE SO LONG TO ARRIVE?!?? Except for the soybeans, which I described above as not bland but regrettably potent... but still cold...and slimy. WHY. My bf and I were bitterly waiting to move on to a real breakfast and had eaten everything served to us but the soybeans because we just couldn't. The owner commented on how neatly we picked up every grain of rice (durr, that's all we got for food!) and how we apparently didn't take to the soybeans. "My sister can't handle the natto either," she says over-graciously. Uhh, maybe when someone is asking about the menu items prior to ordering, you should mention that 20% of your breakfast tray is notorious for acquired taste! A simple translation "Natto = fermented soybean" would have been nice from the menu instead of requiring your customers to Google Translate, ergo waive ordering the 1st time that they win the lottery of being noticed. Overall, this breakfast item scores 0 / 5 because it does not cost $10 to serve 1/3 cup of rice, canned soybeans, pickles, and miso soup mix in children's portions.  

- Free dessert for Yelp check-in?  Sorry, only on Saturdays!  (a.k.a. "Caturday")


Just 1 star?
Sure, we ordered something that we regretted. HOWEVER, we got no advice or translation or notice. Sure, we decided to spring for modern Japanese and fusion food after seeing the prices. HOWEVER, no food was available on other tables to even realize what portions we could expect for the $$. (Blame that on the long wait and demands on the kitchen? Not that they had big portions to cook or much attention to detail tho since everything was served cold and incongruous.) Normally, you'll feel comfortably fed on $15 even at a modern chic restaurant for breakfast. NOT here. Cassava upholds the Japanese small portions but the service and products here just don't deliver.
author: S J.

description:
FYI they don't start doing their real breakfast on the weekends until 10am.  I drove all the way out to try them on Sunday at 8am, but had to settle for a simple pastry and coffee.  The pastry was excellent, and the coffee(Ritual) was decently prepared.

I had heard great things about their full breakfast menu, so I was really bummed out to not be able to try.  I can't give a full 5 stars because there was nothing particularly amazing about the pastry and coffee I did have, and it seems strange to start serving the full nelson so late in the morning.
author: Yan L.

description:
Cassava is fantastic! I might have become instantly addicted to the Spiced Honey Latte. Even my boyfriend (who's a tea drinker, not a coffee person) ordered one and absolutely loved it. I had the "Mr & Mrs Croque" Sandwich which was pretty large and filling, but it was light enough that I didn't feel overly stuffed. It was very tasty, but I still wish I had gotten the Waffle, which is what my boyfriend ordered. Personally, I HATE when waffles are too soft and squishy; I feel like I'm eating a sugar soaked sponge. But this waffle was nothing like that. "Crisp" or "crunch" may not be quite the right words to describe it, but those are the words I'm going to use. It was a crisp waffle that had a nice crunch to it. It wasn't overly sweet either, which waffles tend to be and what usually contributes to my feeling like a pregnant elephant after brunch. And the bacon was great, which is always a huge plus for me.

The restaurant itself is really cute, with indoor and outdoor seating. It isn't very big though, so I wouldn't recommend it for large, gaggly brunches, but it's perfect for, I'd say, up to four people in your party. The staff was really nice as well, which contributed to the overall pleasant atmosphere at Cassava.
author: Stephenie S.

description:
Casssava...where have you been all my life?

My fabulous foodie girlfriend Cherylynn N. reviewed this spot right around it's grand opening, so I really don't know how this flew under radar for so long!

Where in the Richmond district can you run in for your morning cup of joe and a curry puff? Sure, there are probably places up and down Clement and Balboa. However, those places aren't serving Ritual's smooth coffee and they sure as heck aren't serving you a flaky, buttery pastry wrapped around silky curry filling with even 1/4 of the warm welcome you receive from the very cute and endearing Yuka. 

The BF and I jaywalked over here upon the recommendation of my optometrist located directly across the street. Since Dr. Cheng has never steered me wrong and my -10 blind eyes see damn close to 20/20 because of her, I listened to her again and obediently went across the street for a very late lunch. I need to buy Dr. Cheng a present for this kind referral because I now have a place to brunch on the weekends and in my very own neighborhood, thankyouverymuch!

BF and I decided to share the Meatballs in Curry and the Shrimp and Avocado Sliders. The tender, juicy meatballs are made of tofu and beef, come with super sticky Japanese rice made just the way I love it and a lightly dressed salad. Sandwiched between a toasted challah bun and consisting of way more fresh, crisp shrimps than I expected, the sliders are an A+ in my culinary adventure book. I've had many a mediocre shrimp and avocado sandwich in my day, but these were exceptional due mostly to the skill of the chef and the fact that he took the time to sprinkle salt on the avocado - such attention to detail! Salt + avocado = super happy Veronica. P.s. I ABHOR onions, but  I happily ate delicious mouthful after mouthful of the tomato and red onion salsa in that slider.  Remember how I said we'd decided to share? Sharing happened like this - BF ate 3/4 of one slider. In return, I was allowed one tablespoon of rice, one tablespoon of sauce and 1/2 of one meatball. Someone needs to learn how to share his food, wahhhhhh. 

Their monthly pop-up dinner menus sound amazing; bone marrow and/or beef cheeks anyone? There's already a waiting list for the month of July, but as soon as August opens up, you can bet your tush my fine food-worshipping girlfriends and I will be there complete with salivating mouths, waiting tummies and open wallets. $45 for a tasting menu by a Le Cordon Bleu trained chef who has worked at not just one, but two Michelin starred restos, hello? Run, don't walk!

I cannot emphasize enough how high quality their food is and how reasonable the prices are, so I'm combining clichéd phrases and I'm gushing so much it's embarrassing, but this is THE neighborhood gem find of the year.  

We've only just had our first date, Cassava, and perhaps I'm jumping the gun a bit, but I think this is the beginning of a long and grand relationship.
author: Veronica C.

description:
Before my trip to SoCal, my friend and I decided to grab some breakfast here. The little cafe was adorable! I just loved the simple and fresh decor. The service was excellent and the food was yummy. I had the meatball curry while my friend had a ham and cheese sandwich. The food was great but i feel the prices did not match up with the quantity/quality of the food. My small meal was about 10 dollars ( basically a cup of rice and about a few meatballs and curry.) While my friends sandwich came out to be about 9 dollars with a very small side salad. I know 20 dollars for a meal for two isn't much but there are plenty of cafes in SF that can keep your tummy full and is equal in quality for less. 

Summing things up: 

Prices: 7-10 dollars
food: pretty good
service: great
atmosphere: great
coming back? yes!

O the macaroons made my eyes widen when i shoved it in my mouth ( shits good)
author: Reiko n.

description:
Love this gem! 

The service is awesome and Yuka and her staff always are smiling and friendly.

The food is the best in the area. Love the Randwich, shrimp and avacado sliders, curry with meatballs, and Americano coffee.

Not to mention the atmosphere is warm and inviting.

Yum!
author: Miharu Y.

description:
*On our quest to try 52 new places in 52 weeks.* 

Only I drag people to the Outer Richmond for breakast food. But I think we all agreed it was well worth the trip. 

My friend (and fellow Yelp! Elite) Meredith flew in from Baltimore and I wanted to start the trip off on the right foot. I was slightly nervous about it being packed (there are three two person tables inside) and having to wait an hour. Be it the fog, the Balboa & 37th address, or the before noon timeslot, we somehow lucked out. Thank goodness. 

The three tables were full, but they had a mini table near the window that we were able to sit around and they brought out an extra chair to fit our party of three. I ordered the Bourbon Vanilla Honey Mocha  (seriously delcisious and pretty big, I couldn't even finish it) and the Breakfast Croissant Sandwich (which was delicious albeit sweet, I could only finish one half). The staff was SO attentive and the food came out quick. Not to mention this place is ADORABLE. If I lived closer I would come here all the time. Or at the very least stop by every morning and get a coffee to go!
author: Melissa N.

description:
Clean, bright, smart, and relaxing. I Yelped this on a Thursday trip to the Golden Gate Bridge for my first time in SFO. After a dip (of my toe) in the ocean I found this place. Parked up the hill because I did not have change. And walked right in to order. Never had it before, but I went for their Burbon Honey Vanilla Mocha and Yum! Sitting by the window gives a comforting view of Balboa street - having just arrived from Philly the irony is not lost on me. So from the window their outside seating looks just as cozy. 

Good Food! I went for the grilled cheese with ham. And it spoiled me for life. Also got the pistachio and raspberry macaroons at their suggestion for later.
author: Telaina M.

description:
Admittedly, my first trip to Cassava only happened because I liked their logo [Cassava || bakery + cafe] outside and curiously stumbled in.. but thank you happy logo! what a great find! 

Why Cassava does not appear on every best of SF/must do while visiting the city list, I do not know, but this place is a charming hidden gem. Definitely rivaling Outerlands across the park, the food is perfectly seasoned and the flavors dance in your mouth. I cannot say enough accolades for every menu item I have tasted. 

Bonus, the service is as good as the food :] Everyone is friendly and looking to accomodate in whatever way they can. 

{Tips} forego pastries for menu items, the honey spiced latte [4$] and mushroom quiche [5$] are musts!, they happily take cards [thank you! so convenient!] but I always try to use cash because it is better for them&the inside has epic decor and makes this design lover very happy, but it is a bit tiny -- if you end up eating outside they have snuggies to keep your warm in that outer-richmond fog :]
author: Kim C.

description:
cute japanese feel cafe in the balboa.  interior was comfortable and warming.
they serve ritual coffee and japanese breakfast.
pastries looked good and they toast the croissants in an oven instead of microwaving them.

very friendly people.  no minimum required on credit card...just a smile and be polite!
cute!
author: Linda T.

description: Adorable. That's how I would describe this tiny, vibrantly colored restaurant. Not to mention, the friendliest of people work here and you are sure to be greeted with a smile. What's a Japanese Breakfast? I had the same question which is what lead me here. Fresh ahi with sushi rice, poached egg, broth, natto, and seaweed. All served in individual bowls designed for consumption by the hungriest, breakfast-eating human being. Not your typical breakfast but I did enjoy the combination. I wouldn't call it by go-to breakfast but for adventure's sake, give it a try!
author: Allison M.

description: We just moved to the neighborhood and are so delighted to discover Cassava. Unique, delicious food and especially friendly service. We had dinner and everything was beautifully presented and delicious! The octopus with pork belly and the quinoa porridge w a poached egg were especially good. We're bound to be regulars!
author: Audrey D.

description: I came here for the first time for brunch. I didn't know what to expect but I left there feeling very satisfied! I ordered the curry meatballs with rice and my friend order the waffle with bacon and eggs. Every bite we took, we kept saying, "this is so good!". The curry meatballs were light but full of flavor. The rice, with a dribble of salt and the vinaigrette lettuce paired well with the meatballs. The waffle came with a sweet chutney and the bacon melted in your mouth. We sat outside, which had a heating lamp. The staff were friendly and had a good sense if humor. I can't wait to come back!
author: Annie M.

description:
This was my first meal in San Francisco and I have to say this was nice introduction to the city. Small store front, you walk in and review some of the house rules, look through a simply prepared menu for fresh and health choices starting with breakfast through lunch. 

I ordered the grilled ham and cheese (hello delicious) and an Americano. All of which was very good and fresh. The coffee was strong and served well, so I would highly suggest giving them a try if you have time.
author: Abra B.

description:
Wanted to throw a surprise birthday party for my girlfriend but didn't want to do it at home nor at a big, fancy restaurant. The perfect alternative...private party at Cassava Bakery + Cafe!! Arranging this was super easy with Yuka who seem more like a close friend than an owner of a restaurant. 

First off, the space at Cassava provided an intimate and homely feeling that provided the prefect setting where people could chat amongst each other in normal tones. We had 12 ppl at dinner and we all fitted comfortably in the restaurant. It was neither stuffy or pretentious. Just casual, warm and welcoming...check out the various paintings on the walls. They are pretty inspirational.

Second, the food that Kris prepared for us was awesome and mouth-watering delicious. At certain times during the family style dinner, not a word was spoken and all that was heard were the utensils making contact with the dinnerware. Words alone would not do Kris's food justice. Food perfectly seasoned and expertly prepared by a chef that know how to use fresh and seasonal ingredients. Suffice to say people have to try the food here to believe...

*******************************************************************
Starter:
Beef and potato curry puffs, cilantro aioli

Salad:
egg and tomato "caprese"

Soup:
"start of the autumn" seasonal soup

Main:
72 hour braised beef short ribs

Sides:
Roasted potatoes/ truffle oil,Black pig company bacon

Dessert:
chocolate pot de creme

**********************************************************************

Third, the service for our dinner was top notch. Yuka, Randy and Scarlett were our servers and they were awesome to say the least. Efficient, friendly and all very cool...they could rival any Michelin starred restaurant in terms of service. One thing that will forever stay with me was that one of the guest didn't eat beef, which escaped me, but Yuka and Kris were about to come up with a separate main dish for that guest...i will be forever grateful to them.

Tying all three together provided my girlfriend and our friends a night to remember at Cassava Bakery+Cafe...
author: Alex P.

description:
I was so excited when this place opened. Fresh, delicious pastries in this neighborhood. I was so thrilled, I don't even mind that they aren't made in house.

Take away one star for not having decaf. The owner contacted me and said it was because decaf "compromises the integrity" of the coffee bean. Ummm.  I get that they're a Ritual-only cafe and Ritual doesn't make decaf. But even the coffee snobs at Blue Bottle have decaf.  

Take away three stars for the fact that I have to move two chairs and a table in order to get my stroller to the counter (a normal-sized stroller), while customers and staff are staring at me. Unacceptable. I'm used to people not helping me in this town, but at least pretend like you're busy?
author: Lani M.

description:
Amazing! I love Yuka and Kris! They're extremly friendly and I definitely feel like a regular there.

I work at the hospital nearby and go here all the time for coffee or lunch.

I love their tuna melts, sandwiches, and meal salads (with their pesto dressing-- mmm!)

All the pastries/cookies I've tried are delicious too! They have Ritual coffee and some great unique drinks (honey-bourbon mocha)

Their little space is very classy and cute. Nice decor and if you sit outside they can even bring you a blanket.

I've been to one of their pop-up dinners (Reservation only, weeks in advance, $45/person) It was their Japanese New Years celebration and I'm not super adventurous, so my sister ate some of my share, but I'd definitely go again! It was really fun and they even got me flowers at my table because when I booked it I had mentioned it was my birthday outing!
author: Mari F.

description:
Cassava Bakery + Cafe is definitely a cute little place.  I came by to pick up a couple of treats before my drive back to Sacramento.  It's in what seems to be a pretty quiet area, but inside, there were a few customers.  It kind of has a shabby chic type feel to it and I was quickly greeted by the staff.

I tried:
-Peanut butter cookie: a bite sized cookie.  It's not too sweet and a has an interesting texture to it (not like other cookies).  It is somewhat flakey, yet somewhat melts in your mouth.  I thought it was okay.  I can see why others may like it, but it wasn't for me.

-Curry puff: I didn't eat this in the store, and the lady told me that I needed to heat it up before eating it.  I toasted it in the toaster oven when I got home and it had a nice flaky-ness to it.  The pastry is not very thick, it's pretty light.  The curry filling is also not as heavy as I was expecting.  I think I was looking for a denser curry, but it's just lightly curry flavored, which works fine, too.

-Morning buns ($2 each): this was probably my favorite of the things I ordered.  The morning buns were simple, yet tasty.  They have a nice buttery, richness to them and the chewiness of the bread is just right.  The coating of sugar on top is nice too.

Overall, this place is a bit out of the way for me to make a trip back just for the morning bun.  But I would maybe stop by if I were in the area.  The staff was friendly and the shop was cute.  

Notes:
-Metered parking in front; free street parking on side streets.
-They brew ritual coffee.
author: Samantha L.

description: I'm new to the area and started exploring cafes on balboa and passed by cassava. I immediately fell in love with the cute decor! My friends were planning on visiting from LA so I decided to take them so we would all share our first time experience here. We finally came one Friday during brunch and I absolutely loved it! I got the open face avocado toast and my friends got the breakfast croissant. We all had a mimosa and split a blueberry cheese Danish! Yum! We loved the food. So light and fresh and you can tell the the quality was excellent! I'm determined to come back with a cat shirt on Saturday and to try their honey spiced latte!
author: Marie N.

description:
Every time I come here, the service & people are perfect.  Always friendly, always smiling.... I love their coffee (they brew ritual) and they have a yummo honey spice latte.  But... I can't leave out the food. When I go, I try to order something new.  For being small, they offer a ton of goodies and meals...! So don't be shy... EAT! 

One of my favorite things about Cassava is how refreshing the atmosphere is.  I love that it is different from the other coffee shops in the neighborhood.  It's not an oldie hippie joint... It's fresh, inviting, and relaxing.  You must go!
author: Andrea B.

description: I just had their quinoa citrus salad. Nicely composed and balance of flavor and texture. The dressing has a light citrus taste which is complimented by the bursts of citrus from the Orange chunks. The walnuts as a nice crunchy texture to the salad. Wonderful.
author: Robert C.

description:
A nice, friendly atmosphere coupled with cool, friendly staff makes for a new staple cafe within my neighborhood. i really like the tree that they have in the front; it's so awesome. Anyways, here is my review:

coffee ($2.50): the coffee that I ordered was a large, though definitely a small by peet's/starbucks standards. The coffee's flavor was more hot water than coffee, but still decent. 3 stars.

Quiche ($4.00): the quiche was interesting. It's not very often that I find myself ordering a quiche, but i had to try it upon reading yelp reviews. It was.. not bad. The quiche is a combination of cottage cheese, creme spinach, and mushrooms on a buttered cookie crust. They will also warm it up for you in the oven, and lightly flame it with a torch after it's warmed up. Though $4 is reasonable for a unique taste, I feel that it's an item that's good only once in a while. overall, it was decent. 3 1/2 stars

Secret Tip: now, although both the coffee and quiche are only slightly above average, if you take a bite of the quiche, and follow it with a small sip of coffee, the entire world will change within that very moment. THE FLAVORS truly come out when the two are combined, and then you can easily taste why this is a 4 star cafe.

-wifive-
author: simon k.

description:
We came here on a cold saturday morning hoping to try their Japanese Breakfast to but to our dismay, they ran out at 12:30pm. Which sort of makes sense since its technically not breakfast anymore.

I decided to try what they had remaining which was a ham and cheese croissant. The sandwich was tasty enough but due to the small establishment and it being too cold to sit outside, we had to wait some time to get a table.

I will have to try the Japanese Breakfast next time I visit and will have a follow up update to this review.
author: Rich L.

description:
Let me preface by saying I have only tried one entree on the menu and I will update accordingly. 

The Chorizo hash bowl is excellent for multiple reasons:

1. It is original - I am always going to give points for thinking outside of the standard breakfast box (or bowl in this case).   
2. It has all of the great chorizo flavor without any of the "what the hell just happened, I suddenly need to take a nap"  aftermath that most chorizo breakfast plates will award you. 
3. It is sufficiently fulling, but not overly so (see point 2).

However, there are a couple downsides. Granted I have only been on weekends, it is often hard to find seating inside. You may find yourself awkwardly standing in the middle of a crowded room, scanning for near finished customers, while dodging busy servers. This place has a nice ambiance, but I think it is a little pricey for a seat yourself cafe. A two entree, two coffee breakfast was pushing $35. 

If you can handle the potential downside, you are in for a treat. Oh ya, their coffee is excellent as well.
author: Derek H.

description: Excellent. Cozy, yummy, fresh simple food. EZ parking.
author: j r.

description:
#500! Can't believe I hit 500 reviews. 

Cassava is a cute little place. They are always booked for dinner, but I emailed them 2 months in advance and got a reservation. The staff is super friendly and the food was good. There are only about 4 to 5 tables. 

The March Menu:

Ocean Trout "Puff" Wrapped in puff pastry, asparagus, flowering garlic chives, lemon aioli, arugula-This was cooked perfectly and it was so yummy. I wanted more

English Spring Pea & Mint Veloute Eggplant chorizo, pepper mint, peas-I tried, but I coudln't drink this soup. I hate peas. It's my least favorite thing, but the color was very pretty.

Warm Le Puy Lentil salad Cara cara orange, hearts of palm, onion jam,
balsamic reduction, Charlotte's cream cheese-ate everything but the lentils. Was way too much, but everything else was good. The cream cheese was nothing I ever had. Made fresh. I wish I can buy some to eat with my bagels at home.


Potato Gnocchi Hand rolled potato dumplings, brown butter, sage, pine nuts, Prosciutto de Parma, broccoli rabe-Amazing! Love it!

Intermezzo: Fennel & Lime Gelee-Just to clean your taste buds

Slow Braised Osso Bucco Farro, cauliflower, kabocha squash and sesame puree-they give you bone marrow too! What a huge piece of osso bucco. So tender and flavorful!


Waffles & Berries Liege waffles-wasn't a huge fan.

I think for all this, came out to be $54 a person, not including tip and tax.
author: Karen H.

description:
I've been subletting a place in the outer Richmond, which seems soooooo far from anything, but Cassava has been a life raft in a sea of barren outer Richmond streets (I exaggerate, but you get my point). Cassava (and the weirdly nice weather) has made my 5 weeks out here enjoyable. Good coffee, excellent friendly service (My 3rd time there Yucca remembered what I had ordered for takeout the previous visit  and asked how I had liked it) and delicious, tasty food and pastries. Also, the place is freakin' adorable. I love the flowers on the table, the random books on the shelf, the changing menu, the smallness of it (on my first visit a woman at the neighboring table was raving about the shrimp sliders and the 'heavenly avocado on them', which I promptly ordered the next time I came in).

My husband and I (individually and together) have been here about 6 times in the past 4 weeks. When Cassava closed for 4 days this weekend (opens back up tomorrow!) it almost ruined our Saturday. I don't hold this against Kris and Yuka, but the fact that we were distraught only highlights the awesomeness of this place. We ended up going across the street to Simple Pleasures which was ok (we were in despair after all), but slow, crowded, dark and in comparison way less friendly. 

I briefly considered giving 4 stars because the food comes out a bit slow and it is a little pricey for a cafe, but I think that's what it takes to get this quality stuff. So 5 stars it is!

Thanks Cassava for making my outer Richmond experience that much better.
author: Sonia F.

description:
a clean and bright place! Food is all regular, but the atmosphere is a plus!

I will come back.
author: Alex S.

description: breakfast and brunch is off the charts good.  the lamb meatballs, waffles and the japanese breakfast never fail.  they have great coffee as well as sangria too.
author: Charles W.

description:
Came here to try their curry puff ended up getting a quiche for my son on this warm sunny day in SF. As I approaching this place I can see its pretty crowded. There are tables out in front so you can eat outside. Too bad that it's on the south side of balboa because there's no sun in the afternoon. 

This place is tiny and super crowded. I had to take my stuff to go bc there were no seats available. 

So onto the food...the quiche is amazing. It's like a chawan mushi consistency and really the best quiche I've ever had. I'm not really a quiche person. The puffs were good too. It was pretty early in the afternoon and it looks like I grabbed the last quiche an d the one of the last remaining curry puffs.
author: Leena C.

description: Food is simple and delightful; the kind of place you can go for a healthy brunch or something a little heavier. It's beautiful inside and out, welcoming, with lots of air. Friendly service. The spiced honey latte is delicious--ask for it a little less sweet though. Japanese brunch and house smoked trout are both top.
author: adam b.

description:
Had a great latte the other morning. Also tried their Honey spice a couple weeks ago, that was great. Quiche was good, it had pumpkin in it. Clean kitchen. Nice staff! Going back to explore more of the menu. I heard they serve lemon natto...living in Japan for 20 years, I've never heard of it, but  I'm looking forward to trying it. 
Update: just tried the randwich (takeout) they put it in a box and it was great! Still havent tried lemon natto...:)
author: Rose M.

description: The menu changes pretty often and they serve different things during different times so it's important you do your research to make sure they're serving what you want.  They didn't have what I originally wanted so I opted for the braised short rib bowl instead.  I really liked how there was a variety of texture and a light citrusy flavor.  The meat was really tender, but there were only a couple pieces.  Also tried the liege waffle but it wasn't anything too special.  Wouldn't come back for the brunch, but I do want to try the sliders.
author: Tina L.

description: I really enjoy their Japanese breakfast (natto, miso, pickles, seaweed, seared fish, and perfectly poached eggs with rice). Food is healthy, fresh, and clean. It's great to walk out of here not feeling like a fat piglet post-brunch.
author: Christina C.

description: Came here yesterday to have a quick bite and it was really good! The food was awesome. Had a variety off the menu, everything was great. A bit pricey but the atmosphere and coffee were great!
author: Pauline C.

description: creative and full of flavor, the food is local and delicious,  best place to eat in the avenues
author: Rafe B.

description:
Boiled. Poached. Baked. Puffed.

Boiled: "Perfect" egg. Served upright on a small plate. Pinch of salt. Perfect.

Poached: Chicken Salad Panini. Shredded poultry. Caramelized fennel. Foccacia. Superb.

Baked: Peanut butter cookie. Delicious.

Puffed: Potato filling. Flaky crust. Indulgent.

Americano was served large. Granola was served customized with skim milk instead of whole yogurt.

Staff are as charming, endearing and welcoming as the decor. Free WiFi to keep you around and eating the excellent food.

No matter how they make it chances are you'll love it. And I do hope they make it. Great spot.
author: Jason B.

description: Good food, great ambiance, small portions, but satisfying. Great service.
author: Linh D.

description: I used to come here for brunch on weekends and some special dinner like my birthday. They gave me a bouquet of roses on my birthday dinner and it was pre-fix menu so we had appetizer, main course and desert.  I also love their French macaroons I would buy 5 different flavors and get it to go when it is available as it is seasonal.
author: Cherry C.

description:
This refined cafe' is great! Normally I'm in to order an Americano, which is always hot, smooth and bold, yet today had a breakfast croissant that was really good to say the least.
 The owners, Kris & Yucca always greet us by name and remember which drink I prefer which is rare these days. In addition to outstanding personal service, the food is fresh, tasty and done with a unique twist.
 Definitely the go to cafe' in the Richmond area...
* Addendum - they're the best!
author: Mike S.

description: "Mr & Mrs Croque" Sandwich - delicious!! My egg was a bit overcooked but the pesto and perfectly toasted bread made up for it. Also, the side salad was lacking but the service was pleasant and I loved the decor.
author: Talia R.

description:
Cool spot! I really like the atmosphere here, and even though I only had the free cookie that came with the check-in offer, I'll be back!

The whole neighborhood around here seems like a nice hidden gem (at least for me who doesn't live nearby).
author: Mike G.

description: Love their hot water mugs, my well done fried egg was just perfect! They have heater over the outside seating, very thoughtful of the owner.
author: Rachel W.

description: This is a wonderful little place nestled in the heart of the Outer Richmond! We are new to the area and Cassava was the perfect spot for us on a cold and rainy evening. We were greeted cordially by Yuka (I hope I spelled that correctly) and were led to a nice comfy spot by the window. I was a little under the weather so I decided to get some hot tea. The tea was absolutely sublime (honey rose mint tea) and I even got a second cup! We ordered the quinoa salad as a starter and was perfect! Just the right amount of everything in every bite! Including tomatoes, citrus fruit, quinoa, and greens. Just when we thought it couldn't get any better, we got our entrées. Albacore tuna seared to perfection a top a bed of white beans, citrus, tomatoes, and a few greens for garnish. The dish was absolutely exquisite! The tuna just melted away in our mouths. Every bite was a creation of delectable flavor! The only regret was not getting the three course meal!! So when you want a cozy gourmet experience, head on over to Cassava and get ready to be amazed! :D
author: Maynor S.

description:
OMG this place is so good. I unfortunately missed the Scoutmob deal, but we finally made it over there today. After grabbing a table and one of their cookbooks off the shelf to peruse, I got myself the poached chicken panini, since they were out of the curry puffs. 

This turned out to be a FANTASTIC DECISION. They use Semifreddi's foccacia bread for this sandwich, which took it up a few notches to begin with. The chicken was really tender and tasty, complemented by the bit of fried egg white and carmelized fennel, which gave it a subtle herb-y flavor. It tasted like a bit of curry was spread on one of the slices, which gave it a really nice kick. Totally delicious. 

They make really smooth lattes, too. I'm not much of a Ritual person as it's a little too strong for me, but the way they blended it together mellowed out the taste just right. 

The staff is super friendly and sweet. I definitely recommend it as a place to get a quick bite or a quiet spot to get work done.
author: Rachel F.

description: Cute and well decorated. I never knew this place existed until my parents told me about it. The food here is really good. The menu changes often and their portions are huge! I had the quinoa salad and ribs (which was an appetizer sized dish) and was full. The panna cotta dessert was also YUMMY. I hear this is a great brunch spot. I hope to try it soon!
author: Natalie S.

description:
I came in here last weekend and ordered the poached chicken sandwich with roasted fennel and harissa.  Delicious!  The peanut butter cornflake cookies are also yummy. I think I ordered 20 of them in total last weekend.

Friendly service, cute ambiance, and creative food. Also, it's inexpensive. What's not to love?
author: Dwigt S.

description: the japanese breakfast is so unexpected and a refreshing menu change. some of the breakfast items are like $20 which seems aggressive. nice ambiance, good layout, and pleasant waitstaff. would love to see broader menu choices..
author: Sonya Z.

description: Long wait for very unusual, tasty Japanese style brunch. Everything was perfectly cooked and presented. Delicious pork ribs as a side is a good complement to the entree. The outside is freezing in the wind and the heaters useless. Better on a sunny day in the Richmond!
author: Helen M.

description: First off... We received water in cups that smelled like a dishwasher and chemicals it was disgusting. My girlfriend got the Japanese breakfast. Everything about it was just bad, absolutely no flavor at all. The miso soup didn't taste like miso was just watery vegetable soup. They served us what looked like they just cracked a egg in a bowl, very cold. The fish portion of the meal was bland like if came straight out a can... I got the waffle which the only good part was the 5 pieces of fruit on top and they forgot my syrup for the waffle. By all means try the waffle but a fair warning it tastes like rye bread... It's the Last time we ate there.
author: Alex S.

description:
Here's my summary: cold food, expensive, worst customer service ever.

First of all, I am irked by the demand for a tip when you use your credit card. First, you have to line up for 300 years and order your food at the counter. The people then take another 200 years to get your food. In fact, I have been regularly and I still have never had prompt service. Ordering a quiche is an ordeal. They take FOREVER. And you want a tip for this????!!! A latte here is $4 for the Outer Richmond.

The lady, Yuka, who owns this place is a dragon woman. She's rude, abrupt and into herself. When you try to engage her, it's ice ice, baby. You cannot ask her for anything. God forbid when this place screws up your order, customers are afraid to let her know because she's the rudest person alive.  Perhaps a career at the DMV is more suitable place for someone with her oh so sunny dispoisiton.. Learn some manners, lady. Eating your food is like swallowing broken glass after interacting with you.

The food like other reviews is cold. It goes back to my original point-they take forever. By the time that they get your food, it's cold as hell. (this is generally done after waiting 15 minutes to get them warm up a pastry) My coffee was iced by the Richmond District wind from the Pacific.

They charge a lot of money for OK food. It's slim pickings in the Outer Richmond. However,  I might even take my chances with the cockroaches at the Americana Grill than deal with her attitude. It's so San Francisco hipster-I am just too cool to provide you decent customer service.
